#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Not a fake model, excellent EDC!
reviews:
Not a fake, for those who are concerned about all the fake versions online, a fake has a waffle print button, black o-ring cap seal, silver color spring in the end cap. The real ones come with a "streamlight" brand CR-123,& "Energizer" brand AA next to the flashlight with a nylon pouch in the back, a "S" in the shield streamlight logo printed button, red o-ring, and gold colored spring on the end cap. These are the real dealüòä so feel confident in your purchase.

This is the most versatile flashlight in terms of battery options, that I know of, without needing any adapter. AAA, AA,(14500), CR123,(16340), there are probably other options that will work to be honest, but these are just what I tried so far... 16mm diameter (maybe16.8mm if you want exact maximum)√ó38mm, any longer will need be a smaller diameter 14mm √ó57mm length are about the maximum dimensions that will fit the lower section. Basically the lower section is tapered a little smaller on the inside diameter, making the AA, AAA center nicely, but just the fact that I can use such a variety of rechargeable, or single use batteries makes this the perfect EDC, at least in my mind... the "ten tap" programming is excellent, I prefer the "low" setting, where I can 2 tap to get the "high" setting when needed.

This is my second "streamlight" my first was well used, dropped, submerged, lost & found a few times, and never failed me in 7 years of daily use (some weekends off). It was pretty scratched up, but worked without fail, in the end, unfortunately it was lost, and I had a few other cheaper ones that I used until now... This is a nice replacement, it's brighter, the "ten tap" is also a nice upgrade, and a better fit in my hand.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
Finally a EDC flashlight I can use with either CR123A or AA batteries.

I'm ex military, and ever since Streamlight came out with the Sidewinder Compact II that used either CR123A or AA batteries, I'd been hoping they would do the same for an EDC size flashlight. I own several Streamlight products, either for work or outdoors activities they all were one battery type or another. Now I tend to always carry spares, but if you run out, some types are harder to find than others, ex: CR123A.

Now that they offer the ProTac 1L-1AA, it takes care of that problem. It runs on CR123A Lithium, AA Alkaline or AA Lithium batteries. As for those that don't read the info supplied by Streamlight, they DON'T TAKE RECHARGEABLE batteries.

Comes with a 2 way pocket clip. Folks say it comes off easy, to fix that problem get some mini zip ties, and put it around where the clip attaches to the body, won't come off.

Solid construction, great materials, and made in the USA. Lifetime warranty and comes with both CR123A and AA batteries as well as a small belt pouch. All at a great price. Pick one up, you won't regret it!

review_title: One of the best flashlight I could have bought
reviews:
One of the best flashlight I could have bought.

First it can run out of 3 different battery type(CR123, AA or AAA) makes it the life saver wherever you are. I prefer to use CR123 for the more powerful light output, but with AA Lithium it run well and long.

The switch is just perferct. High output right on then strobe and low output using quick push to cycle, it is really simple. The possibility to change the way the switch operate through the "programmable" function is interesting also, even if i do not use it.

Coming with a belt/mollee pouch is awesome. The 2-way clip allows to carry in a pocket, to attach the light to you cap for hand-free use or like.

All in all, this is the best EDC flashlight you can buy.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews: This light served as my vehicle light for close to three years. Replaced the batteries once, and treated it to every imaginable horror it could face. Freezing cold -40 starts, extended runs while searching for lost tent pegs, doused in muddy water and energy drinks, rattling over dirt roads at 80 kph surrounded by loose change and tools. The anodizing has held up, and the lens remains scratch free. There's no failures on the light at all, and everything works perfect - so much that it's now been passed along to be my significant other's purse light - a task I would only let the more trusted of lights fill. There's no real chance of accidental activation, and the tailcap remains tightly screwed on. Every time I reached for that light. it worked. That simple. There's a lot of other, fancier lights out there, with higher lumen counts boasted *cough cough every budget overseas light out there cough cough* (sometimes falsely) and more crazy modes *cough cough nitecore sr7 cough cough*, but this light offers everything you need. Instant high mode, with a second low mode, and the ever present but equally useless, strobe. No mode memory means the batteries never phantom drain, *cough cough thrunight tn12 cough cough* The beam is am excellent white and flawless - a rarity for some cheap lights. All in all - this is one light that I've never second guessed once, and it's never given me a reason to.

reviews:
Great torch. Very happy with it. I chose it for the reversible clip (can be cap-mounted; handy when taking it camping, or helmet mounting), and the amount of light it can put out. I'm a structural engineer so a solidly built flashlight is handy on site; I wanted something that can illuminate structure from a decent distance but still fit in my pocket.
It's support of two different battery sizes is a really nice feature too; the CR123A batter will pump out more light, but it'll also take a AA battery which you can pick up anywhere. And you can program it to default to full-power, or a reduced power (usually you only need the lower setting, saving on battery).
So far it does everything it says on the box. Very happy.

reviews:
Bright enough to light up a small dark room. Its small and compact, fits in my pocket and at times I forget its even there. I bought one for myself, my friend had an interest so I bought him one too.

* Updated - June 2016 *

I purchased this flashlight back in January l2013 and I had broken the lens during that time. Dust gets into the head/LED housing, and I was careful not to get it wet. After these years I finally decided to have it repaired or replaced.

I registered my information on Streamlight's website, and regarding my purchase and how it got damaged. I then was entered into their system, and then printed the label and sent it to Pennsylvania. I paid about $20.00 with Canada Post for tracking.

Please be advised their lifetime warranty has caveats, but it appears they are understanding on accidental damages. Repair or replacement is their ultimately their decision.

After three weeks I received my a brand new 88031, and I now use this as my EDC personal flashlight only.

**Here are my opinions after having used this flashlight for three years.**

I had no technical issues with it during this time, but I learned that the lens are not shatter proof. Don't hit it on anything that will directly impact the lens.

It's bright on high it got me through parts of the blackout during the Ice Storm of 2013. I do feel that it gets hot quick though. On low it's not that bright, I use it when I only need a little light or to conserve battery. There is also a strobe option which is good for tactical purposes.

Having only three modes is limited for some people in 2016 when there are other flashlights with more options for the price, some even at a lower cost. I paid $40.00 and couldn't be happier in 2013, but I would not pay its full price now because there are newer flashlight with better specs.

It uses 123 lithium batteries which are generally more expensive and not widely available. I bought a pack of 12 Energizers EL123 from Amazon, definitely worth it for the money.

I also tried using an 18650 battery and it appears to work but doesn't shine as bright. I don't believe it's recommended by Streamlight as it is not indicated.

Overall I am still satisfied wit this purchase, it's definitely my EDC as its compact and light, bright for my uses and something I can use for self defence. I actually brought this with me when I went on vacation in Vietnam and then to a Mexico.

I recommend to get this if it's on sale for about $40.00, however for this price you can also get a Thrunite Archer 2A V3, which has more lumens and uses AA-cell batteries. I'd say it's a personal preference e

Thanks for reading my updated review, and have a great day.

reviews: I bought this in October. #83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
Hello Everyone,

I was very pleased with the initial experience with this light. Having the light come with both fuel options as well as a very well built sheath was a pleasant surprise. The light out of the package is extremely ready to do some serious work for you. At 350 lumens this light is very bright and found no issues with the beam pattern. The flood/spot ratio is right on point for basic EDC tasks. The pocket clip was wonderful. It sat really nicely in my jean pockets and I never felt like it was going to fall out. On the Streamlight website they claim that the pocket clip is ‚ÄúUnbreakable‚Äù, I wouldn‚Äôt go that far but it will definitely hold up for many years of use. Waterproofing on the light works like expected. I left it inside a full sink of water for about a minute and it came out fine. I‚Äôve had wonderful experiences with Streamlight products lasting in very harsh conditions in the past. No harsh testing was done in this review but it held up to basic day to day issues a light will face.

There are a few things about the light that I wasn‚Äôt overly fond about however. I wish there was a bit more texture on the body to help with grip. This light is naturally a little slippery and with the light in wet conditions I had to make sure to keep a very firm grip on the light to keep it in my hands.

I also had some issues when trying to use a rechargeable CR123A in the light after the one that came with the light was finished. When attempting to use the rechargeable CR123A the light would not turn on. I‚Äôm not sure why this is so I have regular non-rechargeable Streamlight CR123A‚Äôs on order. So just be aware that in some cases only certain batteries will work.

My recommendation: This is a great option for a redundancy light. Place it in your vehicle, bug-out bag, in the garage, and other places where you need a good reliable light. My personal preference when it comes to having an EDC light is something with a little more options in terms of brightness levels. I‚Äôve really become fond of lights with .5 lumen options as I often find myself in situations where anything over 50 lumens can be just too bright (e.g. checking pupils in medical situations, or trying not to wake up people next to me when I need a light in the middle of the night.) The TEN-TAP system does help with this a little bit but it would be nice to have other options then simply high, low, and strobe. I would say if you are on the fence about buying this light then definitely do it. You won‚Äôt be disappointed. If you are in a field where you require much versatility out of your light then this might not be for you as a primary light is concerned but it makes for a wonderful back-up.

Have an awesome day,

Rylan
Canadian Survival Company.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: A solid flashlight, as bright as indicated, worth the price
reviews:
*I carry this light with me on night shifts for the past year, did not purchase through amazon rather via local knife dealer.

PROS

1) 600 lumens as described in the review. Lots of these types of flashlights offered on Amazon boast about lumens i.e. 300, 1000 etc. Most of these are Chinese knock offs of real lights (LIKE THIS ONE!). Streamlight is a reliable brand for torches.

2) Tough, robust, kubaton. Can be used as a self-defense tool in numerous ways

----a) Blinding light can be used to temporarily compromise an attackers vision. Even 1 second of seeing the light is
debilitating.

----b) Can be used as a kubaton to add solidity to a punch.

----c) The jagged edge around the rim at the end where the bulb is can also be used for striking.

----d) Is just big enough that it can be used as a baton, would deliver a heavy blow.

3) Stands up whether rested on bulb end or back end.

4) The button that turns the light is just flush with the beveled edge, limiting the lights ability to be turned on while in a pack or a pocket.

5) Can be programmed to exhibit a certain level of luminosity, although I have never used this function.

6) Button is touch sensitive so it can be temporarily turned on or press harder till it clicks to be turned on permanently.

7) Its a tactical flashlight, meaning that the brightest light is set to go off on the first push of a button.

CONS

1) If you shake the light the battery is a little loose, potentially making a rattle sound, its not a major problem but somewhat annoying.

2) The bulb end is TOO big, it bulges out and really compromises your ability to keep it in a pocket, and sticks out of one of those cell phone pockets on most tactical pants.

3) Drains batteries fast, have already went through a pair only using it off and on for a combined time of about 30 minutes. The light doesn't just die, it just fades away... so for the last part of your battery cycle you may have a 200 lumen light. I've yet to see whether or not this was due to the batteries I used or not.

*All around a good light, would give it a 5 if it was slightly smaller.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Excellent flashlight, with a great runtime, efficiency, modes, and settings. Note: Product description on Amazon is incorrect.
reviews:
Excellent flashlight. Before I get into specifics, I must make some corrections to the product description on this page as some of it is incorrect (Not a bad thing, as the actual specs are even better than the ones on Amazon). Here are the proper specs:

-High:
260 Lumens
3h
150m
5,600cd

-Low:
13 Lumens
50h
35m
300cd

Now on to the flashlight itself. It's default mode has three settings (High, high strobe, and low) which one can switch between by gently pressing (not clicking) on the flashlight's button (When gently pressing, the desired mode only stays on as long the button is being pressed), and can select by transitioning from gently pressing to clicking the button when the desired setting is seen (This leaves the desired setting on without the need of a button press to keep it on).

The modes can be changed however. The other 2 pre-programmed modes are:
- High setting only
- Low and high settings only (no strobe)

You can change modes by pressing (not clicking) the button 9 times and holding the button down on the 10th time (not a click) until the light turns off, then release.

Onto my opinion. My only gripes with this flashlight is that there is no SOS mode, and no ability to program the order of the light settings and which ones I want outside of the pre programmed modes. Other than that, this is a superb light with a sturdy and waterproof build (Up to 1 meter underwater) as well as the cheapest flashlight with this high a lumen output (Other brands often have false lumens advertised, so double check before you buy).

The reason why I bought this flashlight is because I live in Canada where it's illegal to carry anything that is purely for the purpose of self-defence or use as a weapon. Canada, namely Ontario, is relatively safe but I always like to be prepared, especially when I walk in areas I consider "ghetto", or places where wildlife is less than friendly. This powerful flashlight fills the role of being a good self defence EDC (every day carry) because it has the lumens required to temporarily blind someone (120 lumens and over) in low light situations as well as being made of anodized aluminium and having a bezel which makes it effective enough for striking if an assailant managed to get that close without breaking the lens. One can easily use it to to fill a large area in front of oneself with light in order to survey one's surroundings in low light environments. It is also useful in day to day life like when messing with wires behind a tv, or in power outages.

Overall, I would recommend everyone to have a tactical flashlight as part of their daily kit for both self defence and general utility. I've owned it for just about 2 months and I still haven't had to change the already included batteries. It also comes with a Velcro holster for those who don't have a backpack with a holster or don't want to carry it in their pocket.

I would also recommend everyone to immediately buy a 12 pack of streamlight's CR123A Lithium batteries from Amazon, as you will inevitably use up the ones that come with the flashlight, and all stores sell those batteries for higher prices that are sometimes as ridiculous as 10 dollars a battery if not more, so save your money and buy them along with this flashlight ahead of time because I haven't found them this cheap anywhere else.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
I'ts a really nice light, if you get a true Streamlight. 3 settings: Hi, strobe, and low. Hi is bright enough to easily shine across my backyard about 100 feet long. Small enough so it just barely sticks out from my closed fist when held, just enough to use as a strike weapon if needed. Great for EDC. The clip is the key - lets you attach to your cap visor.

The problem: I've bought 5 of these now. Two of them: randomly they would not turn on, when they did work, would not shine brightly, and would make a very soft but high pitched noise. These were counterfeit, but by the time I had used them enough to figure this out, many months had passed, could not return. My last purchase 8/28/18 luckily a real streamlight arrived and works great - below is the list of things you have to check right away, and if these are present, then send it back - see attached photos:

Signs of counterfeit Streamlight:
1. ten-tap programming does not work --> counterfeit
2. unscrew the end cap: if O-ring is BLACK (instead of orange) ---> counterfeit
3. take the end cap off, remove battery - if there is NO SPRING in the front end of the flashlight, where it should contact the battery, --->counterfeit
4. end cap with grid texture pattern instead of the "SL" streamlight logo ---> counterfeit

See attached photos.

product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster
rank:
#9,282 in Tools & Home Improvement (See Top 100 in Tools & Home Improvement)
#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
Small, bright, lightweight, programmable. Perfect EDC light. There really isn't a reason/excuse to not carry a flashlight - everyday. The ProTac 1L-1AA is a great flashlight and I think it will end up passing up the ProTac 1L and 2L models in popularity. If you were like me, you are wondering - "how can a flashlight take a small CR123A and a AA battery?". When you unscrew the cap, you will notice the AA battery slides down into a retainer that has a spring on the bottom side. The AA will protrude out of the end of the flashlight, but you just compress the battery down as you screw on the end cap. Easy. The CR123A's fit flush. It's a great concept. Ten-Tap programmable so you can run it in different modes: High, Low/High, or High/Strobe/Low. Just momentary press the end cap 9 times and press to click on the 10th. Great flashlight.

*UPDATE*
It has been one year since this review. I have carried this light in my left back pocket daily. A few drops, scuffs and scratches but it is holding up just fine. Wrapped 14" inches of duct tape around the middle because duct tape is always good to have with you. And, it adds a little grip too. It's a great light.

* Please let me know if my review has helped. Thank You.*

reviews:
I have had this light for about 2 years , and have found it to be an excellent light for the price. It works wonderfully off of primary cells (CR123), but is somewhat touchy when it comes to 18650s you have to make sure you get the right ones. I can also verify that the button top cells from orbtronic work well. I'm sure there are several other brands that will work fine, but I tried at least one brand that would not contact the terminal on the inside of the flashlight because the tip of the battery would not reach down far enough. Just stay with a brand that tightly follows spec.

All that aside, the things I do like about this light a lot are:

1: The belt clip is great for deep pocket carry though I wish that the small part of the clip were about an inch longer to get a better grip on your pocket when the flashlight is being carried tip down, and the pocket is not quite deep enough. That is not a problem if you're OK carrying the flashlight tip up.

2: Two years later, I still feel the output of the flashlight is spectacular for a light of this size, having a slightly larger head then many lights in this class it has a much better more focused throw then some other lights with the same lumen output. I'm sure other lights are out there that are brighter, but this is right at that place where it's "bright enough" and if you make it brighter it eats batteries and just kills people's eyes.

3. Burn time has proven to be so much better than I initially expected from a light this bright and powerful. I've used it with the afformentioned orbtronic 3400mah 18650's and gotten through entire evenings of standing in the rain doing service work on only a couple of batteries for 4-5 hours of mostly continuous with some intermittent run time. I generally carry (4) 18650's when I go out on a night call and I've never used more than 2 and just starting into the 3rd when we wrapped up the call (which was 5 hours) Buy a good multi bank charger, because these larger cells charge slowly if you drain them all the way. It's better for them if you stop half way ( soon as it starts to dim) and swap to another battery than to burn that one to the ground. So buy around 8 cells and rotate them through the charger. Get yourself a StoreACell for 18650's for the other 4 to keep on you in a bag.

4: This flashlight also has the right modes, especially for a tactical light or a work light. I prefer run mine on the mode which gives you high first/then strobe/then low, but as a work light it can also be set on High Only.

The great thing about it is, you don't have to cycle all the way through in order to get back around. If you turn it on high, and turn it back off that's all you'll ever see you don't have to click through all the modes. If you turn it on high and double bump it you'll get strobe, but if you turn it off you'll never see the logo mode, because when you turn it back on again it starts over at high. That's what I want in a tactical light, I wouldn't even care if this light didn't even have a low on it.

It does have two other modes, if you prefer A different selection or order of the settings.

5: Durability: having now owned this for almost 2 years and carried it literally every day in pocket...this is a tough light. Mine has dings, scratches, road rash, most of the anodizing is wearing off (which means I'm rubbing the outer layer of aluminum off the barrel in my pocket)... but the light is as bright as when I bought it, the switch still works perfectly (which is where all my other lights normally fail) and I could not be happier with the small exception of just wishing for a slightly modified pocket clip design.

Compared to other brands I've owned that were this durable and pleasant to use with features anywhere close... I could buy two possibly three lights like these for the price of the brand I was using before, and those did not use recharging batteries, only CR123...so cost was killing me.

Best compliment I can give to any tool...

If I lost it today, tomorrow I'd go buy another one...

review_title: USB charge great. Bright light! Okayish battery. Lacking low batt warning!
reviews:
I've had this light on my duty belt for a little over a year now. I've used it nightly as my main flashlight during my shift.

Pros:
1. Very, very, bright. This will light up any space you're looking to light up, whether a room or vehicle. It's also great at temporarily blinding anyone you shine it at.
2. Comfortable and light on a duty belt.
3. Charge right in my car without the need for anything other than what I use to charge my phone.
(micro usb charger)
4. Feels very well made and reliable. I don't worry that dropping it will turn it into a $100 paper weight.

Cons:
1. Battery life. I feel like I can't get more than 4 days of routine patrol work out of this light. Perhaps using the light for a few minutes a handful of times a night.
2. Battery life (again). If I don't use this light the battery somehow still discharges. I can leave the light in my locker for a week while on vacation and return to a dead battery.
3. No low battery warning. Time and time and time again the light has surprised me in turning itself off at the absolute worst times. It gives me no indication that the battery is low or needs recharging. I've been caught walking up to traffic stops with the light suddenly turning off within a second of me trying to use it.
4. Expensive. I lose flashlights like I lose sunglasses, both equally as expensive. You can buy a cheap Chinese light at 1/10th of the price. At the end of the day I still bought this Streamlight for the same reason I still buy Oakleys.

The product loses two starts because of the lacking low battery indicator. Streamlight markets directly to law enforcement and a low battery indicator is pretty critical to our profession. Flashlight going dead without warning is like being caught with your pants down and having to run back to my gear bag for a second flashlight isn't ideal in every situation.

reviews:
This is a great light for several reasons. I keep one in all the cars with a cr123 in them for emergency needs. They just work when you need them. Nice and small, also carry one on me or in my briefcase.

It takes at least 5 different types of battery that I have found so far. I know that streamlight specifically states not to use Rcr123a rechargeables, but they work fine. Even better is that it runs on 14500 batteries. Now you do lose the low brightness when using rechargeables, it‚Äôs more like bright and slightly less bright. Strobe still works fine. But it is brighter than using cr123s for sure. I‚Äôve done some pretty extensive testing with this and have run into no reliability issues yet. So you can run off 1AA, 1AAA, Cr123, Rcr123a, and 14500.

In my testing a 800Mah 14500 will run bright for about an hour. Then it will diminish from about 280 lumens to about 50 lumens (as unscientificly measured against other flashlights of known lumen output) over the next 30 minutes. I stop testing at 1.5 hours, but expect it would just continue to dim and probably give you another 15-30 minutes of useable light. The light gets just as warm as it does with a Cr123 and then cools as the lumens decrease.

The best part is that as compared to my Streamlight 2L-X it has slightly better throw. The 2L-X most likely still puts out more lumens, but it is hard to tell in the dark. They look nearly identical. This light just throws slightly farther and still has great spill.

This light is nice and small and the clip is perfect for a hat brim or a pocket. The emitter is a bit more neutral white, but still a cooler color. Certainly not as yellow as a zebra headlamp in neutral. It is a nice bright neutralish cool white.

I suspect streamlight doesn‚Äôt advertise the battery capability because they want to keep selling their Cr123 batteries. That or what I‚Äôm doing will kill the emitter quicker. Maybe both. Regardless, I have a bunch of these little lights as they have become my favorite.

Stash them with Cr123s for emergencies, EDC/ use with a 14500 and carry a Cr123 as a back up.
I‚Äôve had luck with this but don‚Äôt recommend it since you ‚Äúcould‚Äù fry your light. Hasn't happened to me yet. But just to be safe....

reviews: I carried a Streamlight ProTac 1L-1AA every day for about a year until it ended up at the bottom of a bay in Florida. I became very familiar with the feel and function of this little light, and I loved it, so I immediately went shopping for a new one. I checked in a few stores with no luck then I found this one on Amazon. When the light arrived, I immediately knew I'd been had. This light is much lighter than the real ProTac. Also, the "Ten Tap" function is nonexistent. This light has 3 modes: bright, dim, and strobe, and there is NO way to program it any different. Turn the light on and it's bright. Turn it off and back on and it's dim. Do it again and it strobes... annoying! I may have the order mixed up, but you get the idea. Do not be suckered in by the cheap price. There is a reason this light is $30-40 cheaper than a real Streamlight ProTac 1L-1AA, and the reason is because this light is counterfeit junk.

review_title: It's a streamlight, it speaks for itself
reviews:
You're buying a streamlight so you should already know what you're getting. But i'll briefly go over everything.

Drawing the light:
I planned to carry this tip down, but it turns out, the tip-up carry constitutes a very fast draw. You slip your thumb into your pocket and you've basically already got a full grip on the light, your thumb is already in place to actuate the tail switch. Great for tactical situations.

The Tail switch:
Has a sort of long travel before it switches all the way to constant on, but I like this because it gives you more wiggle room to keep it on momentary on without accidentally clicking it in. The interface is simple and easy to use as well.

The Clip:
The clip is genius. It is strong enough to make sure it won't fall out but smooth enough so that drawing it is very smooth and does not catch on anything. Very useful in a tactical situation. I was afraid the clip would be flimsy from the pictures, but it's a very durable clip. You can even clip it to your hat or shirt collar for hands-free light. It conceals in the pocket nicely and doesn't stick out like you think it would.

The Beam:
It's kind of weird. There is a blue ring around the spill area and the hotspot has a somewhat orange glow around it. But it is very bright and can blind someone, which is what I was looking for. 500 lumens is bright! The low mode is great for EDC use and not blinding yourself. The strobe is slow enough to be effective.

The construction:
Very durable yet very lightweight. Nice and thick, also has good seals and the threads are lubed. If you are familiar with the amazing protac 2AAA, you'll notice the finish is slightly different. I personally like the finish better on this one and noticed it hasn't worn off like my old streamlight.

reviews: At first I was disappointed, when I tried the light in the kitchen; it seemed yellowish and didn‚Äôt appear to be much brighter than some of my less expensive lights. I prefer a whiter light, which appears brighter. Then I took it outside and wow, I was impressed. It‚Äôs obvious the engineer‚Äôs paid close attention to the optics, as it has a nice spot with seamless spillover for great peripheral vision. This light totally illuminates my back yard. Whether you‚Äôre a home owner trying to see what went bump in the night, or a LEO clearing a room or backyard, you will love this light. While I still prefer the whiter light, if I were to buy another light at this price point, I would buy another Streamlight 88065. I was so impressed with the Streamlight 88065, I bought the Streamlight Protac HL5-X Series with 3500 Lumen output, it‚Äôs insanely bright. If you want something larger and brighter, check it out. I‚Äôm now a Streamlight fan.

review_title: Not what I expected of Streamlight...
reviews:
I own seven Streamlight products. Weapon lights and flashlights. This unit was just comparatively below par. The finish was blotchy, the LED was off-center in the reflector, and the tail cap operation was just imprecise and cheap feeling. I immediately suspected a counterfeit, so I went on YouTube and found videos on how to spot Streamlight fakes. By all indications, the light I received is NOT a fake...it's disappointingly genuine. I really hate to think this is a trend in the quality of Streamlight products, as I like to buy from USA based companies...especially ones who support our troops and first responders... wherever possible. I have to add that, by comparison, the Fenix brand lights I have seen recently are obviously superior to this Streamlight, both in terms of value and function. I really hope this was a one-off for Streamlight.
UPDATE: I ordered another of this same light from a very reputable photo/video website, to see if the quality might be better somehow. Although the LED was better centered in the reflector, the tail cap switch was still odd. There is a lot of "empty" space in the rubber switch before actuation, and even then it feels as if there are loose BBs or something similar inside to make the activation. As a result, you have to push your thumb or finger deep into the cavity of the tail cap to get a momentary or instant on. Difficult with bare fingers....likely impossible with gloves or when in a hurry. Just mystified as to why Streamlight would think this is good function.

I would like to be able to cycle the light High - Medium - Low, as opposed to High - Strobe - Low. I understand there is a Low - Medium - High option... but that doesn't work for me. All the Lumens, remember? Nudge, nudge... Streamlight.

review_title: Bright and Functional; Not Too Big For EDC
reviews:
Love this light. I previously had three ProTac 2Ls and wanted some more power after losing my last 2L. Bought the 2L-X and was concerned it was going to be a bit bulky for EDC in casual clothes... It's not. While I wouldn't want anything larger, this is a good size for EDC while being big enough to get a solid grip for tactical use.

This light is plenty bright for any application. It's really great how powerful lights this size have become. The beam is great with a strong hot spot for distance use, while having a nice wide spill for peripheral illumination of close objects. I also find the low setting really good for indoor non-tactical use, like looking under a couch for the remote or under your car's seat for your phone.

I can attest to this being plenty water/shock proof in casual use. It's been in the rain with no issue. I haven't submerged my 2L-X but I will say my first two 2Ls were killed by short term submersion (within what they're rated for), so I don't trust that I can submerge my 2L-X without issues. Not the end of the world and I can't take a star off because I haven't tried it.

review_title: The Streamlight Protac HL works well in the end, but not without hastle and more money spent in the begininng.
reviews:
I bought this flashlight because I work security detail in an ugly part of my city, and when I need a flashlight, I need it to work consistently every time - because my life could depend on it. For a standard flashlight, that may be too much to ask for, but for a flashlight of this reputation and price, I was expecting much more. I bought the Streamlight Protac HL 2 months ago. It worked for about a month (long enough for the return time to expire), and then the 600 lumen output drastically decreased. I assumed it was exhausted batteries, and so I bought a new package of batteries. The Streamlight did not regain its 600 lumen output. It put out less than 200 lumen, in my estimations. At times the light did not turn on at all when the switch was pressed. I assumed that this was my fault, that maybe I didn't know how to use the Streamlight's "ten-tap" technology. After all, I couldn't find anything on the internet suggesting that anyone had ever had a problem with a Streamlight. I even bought another package of batteries, just to be sure that expired batteries weren't to blame. Sure enough, it was a problem with the flashlight. Bear in mind, I had not abused the light, submerged it, dropped it, exposed it to shock or high heat, and I would go as far as to say I babied it. It spent most of its time in the holster, on my belt.

Streamlight has a limited lifetime warranty on parts defects, and so I decided to send the flashlight to the Streamlight repair facility, after filling out an online repair form on Streamlight's website, accompanied by a detailed description of the problem. I asked them to call me with their findings. I paid for 2 day priority mail, it was shipped within 2 days to their facility, and by the morning of the 3rd day, it was marked as shipped back to customer. I called them and asked what the problem was with my light, and they said it was that I must be using bad or inferior batteries, because they couldn't find anything wrong with the light. I told them that there was indeed a problem with the light, and that I had used both Energiser and Duracell batteries with expiration dates of 2021, and they said that I must be mistaken, and that they strongly recommend more new batteries. Personally, I don't think they looked at it at all.

When the flashlight shipped back to me, I decided to inspect it myself. I figured I'd lose nothing since honoring the warranty was seemingly ignored by Streamlight, and as is, I had a useless paperweight of a flashlight. I started by cutting the rubber button on the tail-cap off, exposing the "guts" of the flash-light's switch, and immediately exposing the problem: corrosion in the tail-cap. An easy fix that I believe that Streamlight should have easily found and fixed. I ordered a new tail-cap on eBay for $16, and the light works like new.

In the end: Does the light work now? Yes, but because I fixed the problem.
Did it work in the beginning? No.
Did Streamlight honor the warranty? No. They insinuated that I was mistaken to weasel out of warranty work, and offered no solution to the problem.
Total cost of flash light after repairs, shipping, and batteries: Easily over $100
Would you recommend this product? No. The product is made in China, offers quality craftsmanship, but poor quality control, and customer service is marginal at best. For you to buy a flash light this expensive, you would have to need it for a tactical/emergency situation, and if it doesn't work in even simple situations, you have a serious problem.

I will probably get steam-rolled for this negative review, but I can only report my experience. I can't speak for the entire Streamlight brand, nor other model flashlights of this brand. I'm only speaking from my experience, and this being my first and only Streamlight, I can tell you that I'm not pleased.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
The purpose of this review is to describe additional subtle differences between genuine and fake flashlights.

The background story is that I bought this light because I had a handful of CR123 batteries that weren't good enough to drive a smoke detector but still registered reasonable life on a voltmeter -- so I wanted to use those up rather than dispose of good batteries, but I didn't want to be locked into a CR123-only light.

I initially bought a light from what looked like a reputable seller on eBay. The light arrived and as far as I could tell, both packaging and light looked genuine. Other reviewers have pointed out that fake lights:
1. don't include batteries
2. don't have a SL logo on the button
3. have a black-colored tailcap gasket (instead of orange)
4. does not have springs on both ends of the light to hold the battery

The light I received did not have any of these issues so I felt pretty good about having received a genuine light.
However, some reviews also point out that in addition to all of the above, counterfeit lights also cannot be programmed using SL's Ten-tap system, and this was true of my light. When I tried to program the light using Ten-tap, the light would stay on with the 10th click/hold, rather than extinguish like a real light. So, I started to wonder if this was actually a fake light.

I ordered another light directly from Amazon (Amazon was the vendor) which I received today and it appears that this new light is genuine. When I stare at the two lights and packaging side-by-side, the differences are EXTREMELY subtle, to the point that I had to wonder if the original light simply had a malfunctioning Ten-tap and that the differences I was seeing were simple manufacturing variance.

On the attached photos, the suspected counterfeit light is on the top, and the real light (shipped from Amazon proper) is on the bottom.

Here are the additional differences that I have found:
1. The ink used on the real light is a bit thicker than the counterfeit one - the fake one has ink that is slightly translucent and makes it look a bit like a factory second. This is really subtle and difficult to tell unless you have a real/fake side-by-side.
2. The word "TEN-TAP" on the flashlight is the same height and font size as the adjacent word "PROGRAMMABLE". On the fake one the "TEN-TAP" is just slightly more squished and lower height than the adjacent word, as if the aspect ratio were off.
3. The line spacing of the text above and below "Patented" is equal on the real light whereas on the counterfeit light
the S/N line is much closer to "Patented" than is the "TEN-TAP" line. Again unnoticeable unless you are aggressively comparing a real and counterfeit light side-by-side.
4. The machining of the knurling on the tailcap is different. On a legitimate light, there is a slight 3D depth to the texture -- the grooves are both wide AND deep enough to catch a fingernail. The fake light has a texture that is smoother and with grooves that are more shallow.
5. The lanyard hole on the real light was smaller than the one on the fake light I received (see pic #2)
6. The overall texture of the light on the fake light had a textured glossiness (but very smooth to the touch) vs. a more textured matte finish on the genuine light (pic #2)
7. On the pocket clip there are two cutout notches flanking the long part of the clip that are oriented parallel to the axis of the light -- they are slightly longer on the real light than the fake light (pic #3)
8. The button/switch action is much smoother and easier to depress with the genuine light
9. FInally, on the packaging, the fake light had a California Prop 65 cancer warning (the real one didn't, surprisingly.) On both packages (real and fake) the cardboard insert had a cutout that showed the flashlight -- the real packaging had a corresponding cutout on the plastic packaging while the fake one had plastic covering the cutout.

So, that's it. These are immensely subtle differences and without an actual side-by-side comparison, I think they would be quite difficult to identify in isolation. Good luck out there!
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Lasted a little over a year.
reviews:
I really loved this light until it stopped working. It's really bright, has a solid build and is very versatile with the different modes. I always used the 18650 rechargeable batteries and battery life was great. But just today, a year and three months after getting it, it started having problems. I'm assuming it's the switch, which apparently is a somewhat common problem with Streamlights. If it gets shaken moderately or bumped while on, it will shut off. Turning it off and back on sometimes works and sometimes doesn't. While it's in this condition, no modes beyond low power on/off are available. If you wait a few seconds before turning it back on, it seems to work normally until it gets shaken or bumped again. And I'm not talking severe shaking or bumping. Just the kind of movement you'd use to roll a pair of dice. This light has been in my pocket since I bought it and has seen only very limited use. It's a tactical light intended primarily to be used with my firearm. I use other larger lights for the day to day utility tasks. Now I'm certainly no stranger to having flashlights fail on me, nor is anyone else who's used them extensively, especially those of us in public service that regularly depend on them. But Streamlight is the quality light you spend much more money on so you won't have those kinds of problems. I didn't expect it to last forever, but I certainly thought it would last at lot longer than a year with only limited use. I saw an officer in one review state the axiom that two lights are one and one light is none, and there's very good reasons why we say that. Carrying an extra light in uniform isn't a huge deal, but it's another story when you're plainclothes. I'll probably end up with two lights since there don't seem to be any better choices, but I'm highly disappointed in a product this expensive that only lasted this long. The only reason I didn't give it one star was because it was a fantastic light when it worked.

EDIT 1/26/2020: It appears my problems may have been related to a bad battery. It's been working well for about a week now with a new battery. But since I can't see how a battery could affect switch functions or cause vibration issues, I'm only going to raise my rating to 3 stars for now. If it keeps working well for a few more weeks or so, I'll come back and adjust the rating accordingly.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Very nice flashlight, with a few quibbles
reviews:
I bought this as a lightweight option to mount on my home defense firearm. It's a lot smaller than I was expecting, and lighter, too. I will be buying another for dedicated EDC pocket carry. I'm taking a star off for a few quibbles that bug me.
First, the pros. This thing is a lot smaller than I anticipated. That was a majorly pleasant surprise. Being more compact, it's also a lot lighter. Given this is mounted on my firearm, I'm definitely a fan. There are times when I like my lights to have some heft, but firearm mount is not one of them. Another major (and obvious) pro is the option for two different kinds of batteries. I personally use the CR123 option for the firearm as it's brighter, but with pocket carry I'm more inclined to use an AA lithium battery for the longer life. It's nice to have that kind of flexibility either way. There are not a lot of flashlights out there that give you multiple options in terms of how you power it.
The cons (for me). The tail cap switch is mildly infuriating, in terms of trying to get the light turned on to the setting I want. The first day or two I kept doing full clicks trying to get to the low brightness setting, or even the strobe, but could not for the life of me do anything more than just turn it on or off. It wasn't until several days later and finally googling the flashlight to find out you do a rapid "half-click" either twice (for strobe) or three times (for low brightness), with the last half-click actually being a full click to set it. So, you'd do a single full click for full brightness, half-click full click for strobe, or half-click half-click full click for low brightness. You think that sounds complicated? Wait until you actually try to do it. Either I'm horribly uncoordinated or slightly on the low end of the IQ scale, because it was maddeningly infuriating to attempt my various combinations of half-clicks and full clicks before I'd finally end up on the setting I was going for. After all those attempts, I've decided I'm good with just a single full click to turn it on, on the HD gun. The second quibble is the price. I paid about forty bucks for the light, only a few dollars more than either the CR123-only version or the AA-only version. That in and of itself is not a terrible price to pay for a decently bright flashlight. My issue is, this is not the only flashlight I've ever bought in my life. And there are others out there that are the same quality, but with far more features, for only a few bucks more in price. Granted, they're also bigger and heavier with longer run times on their batteries, but I'm having a hard time reconciling the price/value balance of this light, when I try it out alongside those.
Again, those quibbles are just me, and my own subjective biased opinion. Your mileage may vary. At the end of the day, I like it enough that I'm buying another one, and I'd gladly recommend the light to friends and family.

reviews:
This is a really cool flashlight.
I am not much of a flashlight guy... I'm more a knife guy. (we all have our thing, ya know?).
So I did a bunch of research when I figured I wanted an LED flashlight.
I have always used MagLites for home/camping/backpacking/work/etc... so I figured that one would do. I love the brand and their quality is and has always been awesome.
But then I heard something in a random review about a flashlight that can use a couple of different batteries...? whaaaat?
After more research I settled on this one (for price point and functionality. I don't need more than 3 settings anyway.)
It came with 2 batteries - standard AA and the CR123... OH YEAH. (So, the CR123 is a better battery, more powerful, that's the one I put in there. Well, I hit the LOW beam for a split second the other night to find something on my side of the bed. My wife woke up from a dead sleep and exclaimed 'OW' because the room lit up like an invasion. Seriously, it took me by surprise too.
Haven't had a chance to check the durability factor yet. I will though when we go camping this summer.
Real easy to use, just be careful, IT IS BRIGHT.
The body has a nice feel, no sharp edges. It can stand up on end for 'candle mode' because of the recessed button.
Clip woks great.
All in all, this flashlight is constructed, and operates, very well.

review_title: 2 year review. Buy Surefire instead. (You get what you pay for)
reviews: I have purchased 2 of these and carried each as my EDC. The first one would work fine, but.... I would use it once per night to walk our dogs for less than 2 minutes. I would NOT use the light for 2 minutes, but just flash it once in a while to get my bearings, worked great. During the first month of use, I noticed that the light would be slightly dimmer each week, which was perfectly acceptable. BUT then all of a sudden one day it was just DEAD. No light at all. Like it would have 50% power on Tuesday and Wednesday it was DEAD. First couple of times this happened I assumed that the light was being turned on by mistake and that would drain the battery; I experimented and discovered that this was not user error and the light was faulty. Shortly after discovering this, I lost the light; so I purchased a second one hoping for better luck. I was wrong. After a few months of using it in the same manner listed above, it was noticed that the light would flicker from time to time (which is a bad sign for a light). In sort, BUY A SUREFIRE. Many of my acquaintances have all had Streamlights fail (all kinds of models) and have had MUCH better success with Surefire. The only reason I gave 2 stars is because of the ergonomic and versatile design; quality/durability sucks though.

review_title: Great flashlight, just make a slight mod to make the clip more secure
reviews:
I've purchased this flashlight three times now and I'll continue purchasing it if necessary. It's by far my favorite every day carry light. It's bright enough for anything you'd need it for and small enough to fit comfortably in your pocket. The batteries last long enough with sparing use, especially if you make use of the lower light option, which is sufficient for most any day-to-day task.

My biggest hint to maybe save you all from having to make multiple purchases due to lost light is to take some electrical tape and wrap it around the light near the clip and a bit around the end of the clip itself. Without this modification, the clip is not very secure in your pocket. I lost one flashlight at some point during a night out, never to be seen again. I lost another for a few days when it fell out of my pocket and into a chair. Since I've done this, I haven't had any issues with flashlight coming loose even during strenuous activity.

reviews:
Streamlight has gone downhill since moving manufacturing to China. This light is not at all as bright as my 6-year old Surefire P2X Fury that's rated at 500 lumens; yes, half that of this PROTAC HL. The Surefire has a smoother and more neutral white light (vs this bluish light), and has a far greater throw (tested both at night to light up treetops. The kicker is that this light is about an inch longer, and wider throughout, that the surefire.
It's incredible to me that Streamlight appears to be moving backwards while Surefire continually innovates (the newest Fury is rated up to 1,500 lumens with Intelibeam technology). It also doesn't help that this light is manufactured in China, while Surefire still makes them in good 'ol USA.
Perhaps it's the great tech Surefire has invested in their reflectors, or the efficiency of their LED's. Whatever it is, it's far better than this rubbish. At this price, you could get about 2-3 off-brand ones that are just as inadequate.
Oh, and their "Ten-Tap" is as awkward to use as the name implies...

Disclaimer: I DO NOT work for nor derive any financial benefit from ANY light manufacturers. These views are mine and mine alone.

reviews:
I was looking for a light for everyday pocket carry, and this is small enough that it is usually in my pocket. Though I like the battery flexibility of the 1L-1AA, the smaller size of this light was the deciding factor for me. The hi setting is amazingly bright for a light this small, and the low setting is a bit brighter than I'd like. The high-frequency strobe is definitely an attention-getter, and would likely be a distraction if it were shone into the eyes of an attacker. The beam pattern is exactly what I'd like: a strong center with moderate beam spread (enough to light the full width of a walking path when held at waist-height) and a very wide low intensity spill -- it's the perfect middle ground between flood and spot.
Compared to similar Surefire lights, I put them on even performance ground but at a lower price.

reviews:
Almost the perfect patrol light.

I'm using high quality 18650 olight batteries, not sure of the runtime but it is at least an hour on full. This thing is super bright and lights up everything with the perfect balance of throw and spill. High is brigher than the car spot-light, it blazes through tinted windows and gives a great view of the inside.

It is a great size and the grip is really fantastic in a gloved or bare hand. Makes a good club when needed. It fits in a duty belt ring with no problem and is easy to carry. I've dropped tested it onto pavement multiple times and it is surviving (so far).

It is almost the perfect flashlight, with two minor exceptions. It needs a programming mode high-med-low instead of low-med-high. The default of high-strobe-low is what I am using, meaning I have no medium . Low is fine for reading documents, walking a trail, or whatever, but I think it would be nice to use medium. I don't like low-med-high as I need high to come on right away, there is always time to cycle to low. Strobe is nearly useless since high is plenty for disorientation. Second is it would benefit from a side switch for different shooting platforms. I was worried about this but have quickly gotten used to it's size and weight as a tail clicky using the FBI flashlight technique. This is not a good light for the Harries technique, but i don't like that method anyway for personal reasons.

review_title: Beware of fakes. How to tell ProTac is not counterfeit
reviews:
I really like this light, so ordered my second one. It didn't have the normal signs of being a counterfeit, so I thought I had a real Streamlight. Ten Tap programming didn't work, so I compared it with my other ProTac 1L-1AA. The light was slightly dimmer, more yellow and the beam pattern was not as smooth as an authentic Streamlight, but these would not be apparent unless you are able to do a side by side comparison.

Ways to tell if you have a real ProTac:
1. Try Ten Tap programming. Rapidly click the switch 9 times and hold down on the 10th. The light should switch modes.
2. CR123A battery should have a 4 digit date code between the + and - markings.
3. Rubber tail switch should have the Streamlight logo, not a cross hatch pattern
4. The two battery springs inside the light should be gold, not silver
5. The clam shell packaging should include a Streamlight CR123A battery and an Energizer AA battery

Fakes used to fail all 5 tests. The one I got failed 1 and 2, but passed 3 through 5.

So why 4 stars? It's not Streamlight's fault others try to copy their success. I docked a star because the light cannot stand on end to light a room. Otherwise this is an excellent EDC light. It's priced lower than most other well made EDC lights, dual fuel capability is a bonus and it delivers great lumens for such a small package. I like the size and clip of the Zebralight SC52 better than the ProTac, but the tail switch of the ProTac makes this more useful as an EDC light. Also build quality of Streamlight is tough to beat.

This would be my #1 recommendation for someone wanting a small (i.e., not key chain) EDC light.

reviews:
My father lost his tactical light recently and so what better way to gift him for his birthday than to provide him with another tactical light. I did so much online research before I came to this conclusion. When you are looking for a tactical light, you want to keep these in mind; maximum lumen output, battery life, tactical uses, light modes (strobe and different lumen outputs). Otherwise you might as well just get a standard flashlight.

This one fills nearly all of those criteria. It has a quick and easy usb charger which is a plus because you won't have to keep buying batteries. There are the standard strike bezels in the front for use as a melee weapon. It's maximum lumen output is blinding (I'm not exaggerating). The strobe mode is a great tool for self defense as well. We tested it and I couldn't see anything but a white strobe. The battery life at the higgest lumen output is pretty good itself. Usually some other tac lights last only an hour or so at their maximum output, this one lasts way longer. You can increase this battery life by switching to a lower lumen output by quickly double tapping the power button. Triple tap it, if you want to activate the strobe feature.

It is to my understanding that this flashlight has two models. The one I gifted my dad has the High, Low and Strobe setting. And I believe the other model has High, Medium, Low and Strobe. Although I have not found the other one on the market at all yet.

There are definitely other Tactical Lights that are as great or greater than this one. But that doesn't mean this aggressive looking flashlight doesn't deserve it's 5 stars for exemplary performance. I wouldn't mind getting myself one as well, but I'll have to wait, as I'm only a student and this current Covid-19 situation has put me out of a job.

review_title: which are functioning just fine, and need to purchase the protected 18650 version
reviews:
This is for the ProTac 2L-X Ten Tap 500 Lumens.

First, let me say, it's very bright and very compact. I bought it to use for walking my dogs at night. I was previously using an UltraStinger LED, which I felt was to much flashlight for the job. In comparing the the two on high mode, the ProTac seems roughly half as bright. According to Streamlight specs for both, that would be about right. I used the ten tap programming to start it in low mode so I don't disturb the neighbors, and it's still giving me plenty of light, quite a bit more than my mini Maglite led. On this setting, the specs say it will run for 30 hours on the CR123A batteries, and it will probably run longer on the 18650 rechargeable. That's a lot of light for such a small package.

On Amazon the info says "Dual Fuel use 2x CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-iON Batteries." I checked the Streamlight website, they said "uses two CR123A lithium batteries (included) or one Streamlight rechargeable 18650 lithium ion battery." So I bought 6 18650 rechargeable UNPROTECTED Li-iON Batteries and a charger, to go with my new flashlight. When I rec'd the flashlight, it came with two CR123A batteries. Upon reading the operating instructions that came in the box, it states the light will also function if you install a Streamlight #22101 or commercially available "Li Ion18650 PROTECTED cylindrical 3.7V 2600mAh 'button top' rechargeable battery". So now I'm stuck with 6 unprotected 18650 batteries, which are functioning just fine, and need to purchase the protected 18650 version. Ok, not Streamlights fault. I should have done my homework. So in short, if you're buying the 18650 batteries, make sure you get the protected 'button type'.

Anyway, I like it a lot. I already dropped it on the sidewalk, oops! And it still works fine. This flashlight is no joke, and in my opinion, well worth the 50 bucks. I keep it in my backpack, and will be buying another one to keep in the car.

reviews:
Excellent little light ( ProTac HL-X ). The TapTen programming lets you enable and disable lighting modes you don't use. Very bright on high, blinding. I especially like the low and medium settings since low is still bright enough for a lot of general use and medium is bright enough to temporarily blind someone, but without the high power drain of the full 1000 lumens.

Battery life seems to be good, I haven't drained the ones that came with it. You can also use 18650 batteries if you want rechargeable "high capacity" batteries. The clip is good, can be used to hang in your pocket or off the brim of a hat for head mounting, but could have a stronger spring to it.

I love the tough construction, it feels very solid in the hand, and the angles on the head casing keep it from rolling around on a table.

The one downside is the beam is not adjustable. You can't get a really wide flood, but the fixed beam does have a nice spotlight in the middle with a good transition of illumination to the edges. No visible halo edges or dark spots.

review_title: Great flashlight, durable, tough, and bright!
reviews:
I'm a bit of a flashlight freak, I probably have $2000 in flashlights of various types, but most of them are higher-end tactical type flashlights.

People certainly use flashlights differently, they are not a one size fits all product, but with a couple of dozen mid to high-grade flashlights of various types and brands I have to say that for my daily work this flashlight has been my go-to over all of the rest, none of the others have the USB rechargeable feature with the lighting program I prefer.

I use my flashlights primarily for inspection work that I do and this flashlight has a program where it cycles from low power to high power with each momentary tail click and it returns to low power after turning the light off. I really like this program, I don't get blinded in really dark situations and I'm always just a click away from a little bit more power...all via the operation of the tail switch. My ProTac has been dropped, tossed, kicked, flipped...you name it, it looks terrible, but still works.

The only problem I've had is that occasionally the light doesn't start on the first click, it just flashes once, then I have to re-click the switch. It's pretty random when this happens, I keep it charged, so I don't think that it is the battery, but either the tail switch is getting worn or the bulb is. This particularly purchased was for a backup, I bought my first one in July of 2015, I've used it almost every day, and it is still in use currently

I was a Maglite guy for a long time, but I've found myself favoring my Streamlight flashlights since I've invested in a few. I've purchased some tactical Fenix lights recently, but still grab my ProTac. I own some older model Pelicans, I'll probably try a couple of the new rechargeable models of those next, but Streamlight has set the bar pretty high.

review_title: I want to like this light more
reviews:
***UPDATED REVIEW 12/30/2014***

Within the past 2 weeks, this light began turning itself on in my pocket with no input from me. It burns through batteries in a day, and eventually, I begin to feel the heat against my leg. (Too late.) This disappointing light has gone in the trash, and I replaced it with a competing product that works better and cost less. Steer clear of this one. Revised my rating to 1 star.

*********************************************************************************************************************************************************

I want to like this light more. Honestly, I really do. I've owned this light for 2 years, and it has been my EDC in my front left pocket every day since I bought it. Unfortunately, since day one, the light has been unreliable to turn on. I'll click the switch and nothing happens. I tap the light against something and it turns on. After that, it'll work fine until I leave it turned off for several hours, and the scenario above plays out again. The ProTac 2AAA is an awesome light otherwise, and I love the functions, size and weight. I love how it disappears in pocket and you practically forget it's there. What I don't love is the feeling of wondering if it will let you down when you need it the most. I'm planning on retiring it and getting either a Pro Stylus or a 4Se7ens Preon II.

review_title: Buy it you will like it.
reviews: I live in the interior of Alaska. My homestead is far off the beaten path, The only way in or out is by foot, quad or snow machine. The winter months bring with them, many hours of incredibly long dark nights. This is an area that will kill a person in the winter. Therefore I prefer high quality lights. This is my second Streamlight Pro Tac headlamp. I Prefer to have a backup on my gear. Spending the night in the woods with animals that eat people is not always a good thing. The Pro Tac projects a far reaching beam, therefore allowing me to see several hundred feet ahead. The quality is exceptional. Aluminum in construction is a major plus. Battery life is not all that great on high, however 4 additional batteries are not an issue to carry. Would I recommend this headlamp? Absolutely , YES. My reasoning is simple, if it works in the Alaska winters, it will do the same anywhere else on earth.

reviews:
We bought three for our family's camping bags; they all worked perfectly out of the box and feel solid and reliable. The grip is aggressive enough to provide solid control even if wet, and the gaskets were all in good working order. The straps work well, although I do not have a helmet to check the rubber helmet bands; they do feel high quality and provide good grip when wet.

The one issue I have is the multi-function selector switch: you only have one button to turn on the flashlight and control the brightness setting. To activate the different brightness setting, you have to quickly (.5 sec) press the button (light) on and off, which is difficult given how strong the button is. If you are intentionally trying to press the button as fast as possible, you MAY be able to get it to the correct brightness setting eventually, but it isn't something that will happen easily. There is a way to reprogram the light so that the default changes from high/low to low/high (and strobe is in there too I think), but is needlessly more difficult than cheaper lights that cycle brightness settings (low-high-off).

reviews: I use this product approximately four days a week, as I work night shift in law enforcement. I‚Äôve been pretty disappointed with the product the longer I‚Äôve had it (which has only been a little over 6 months). Here‚Äôs why: 1. The brightness fades as it loses its charge. I find myself having to charge it at least once a week. 2. It takes forever to charge. I leave it on the charger for over three days and it is still not fully charged by the time I need to use it again. 3. Once I take it off the charger, it‚Äôs hit or miss whether or not it will turn on. Today, my husband spent approximately 1.5 hours taking it a part and putting it back together to get it to work after it had spent three days on the charger. The good things about this light: it‚Äôs size and it‚Äôs light it gives off when charged. However, I wouldn‚Äôt say it‚Äôs too reliable and wouldn‚Äôt recommend it to another partner.

review_title: Rugged tactical flashlight with three programs
reviews:
Took a while to realize that the button press needed to do the ten-tap programming is a light button press. Once you have the feel of this down the whole thing makes sense. The light is based around light tap and release and full push only when you need to have the light stay on. I changed mine over to Low/Med/High program. The Low and medium should be fine for most day to day chores. The high would be great for use outside and in the great outdoors.
This is a rugged essentially tactical system designed for police and security personnel. Two of the programs have strobe.
Will get quite hot when on high.

reviews:
This is bigger than I had imagined, but it is super bright. We had some cloud covered days at hunting camp so the solar panels didn‚Äôt charge the batteries. I turned on the light, sat it on its base so that it beamed against the ceiling and it lit up the entire kitchen so we could eat.

I carry this in a pocket and it is a bit big, but now that I‚Äôve gotten used to carrying it, the size doesn‚Äôt seem that big a deal. Interestingly, I use the flashlight more than I do my pocket knife.

A quick double tap on the switch and it goes into a low setting. A triple tap and it goes into strobe.

The lugs on each side are good for standing it up. I imagine that those lugs could be handy, too, if one needs to use the flashlight as a defensive tool.

The case is tough. I had put this in my coat pocket while on a business trip to Chicago, but I found out my pocket had a hole and the flashlight dropped and hit the pavement. A couple of dings to the aluminum case, but it keeps going. When I got home, I filed down the nastiest scars so that it doesn‚Äôt snag.

The only downsides to this is battery life and the LED never goes to green when charged, but I just put it on the usb charger every evening while I sleep and I carry a pair of 18650 batteries and a charger while traveling. So long as I recharge it every couple of days it‚Äôs still operating.

A great add-on to this is a Streamlight 22100 battery charger. It comes with a pair of 18650 Li-Ion batteries. Each has a micro USB port so the battery connected to a USB transformer for recharging, or you can drop them into the charging station.

review_title: Great value, uses rechargeable batteries, easy to use
reviews:
Incredibly happy with this flashlight! I have the Protac 2LX. I‚Äôve carried Maglights and even had a nice little Fenix model I bought for $50 5-10 years ago...

This light blows it out of the water. I haven‚Äôt had much use in the rain, but I‚Äôve dropped it on a wood porch and it didn‚Äôt even flicker.

You can change order of the modes when you click, but honestly I‚Äôve been using it as is. The strobe is great. The bezel doesn‚Äôt look as aggressive as some, but will still do some damage. It doesn‚Äôt snag or rip pockets.

I bought this over the Olight Striker and honestly I don‚Äôt regret it. Saved money and still got a great light. The clip can be used either way vertically and the body is about the same width top to bottom which for me was a must.

It‚Äôs light, can use 18650 rechargeable batteries, comes with 2x CR whatever camera batteries which are lasting me well. I‚Äôll only be using 18650 when they die, though.

It comes with a thin nylon velcro holster that works on my Sam Brown or a Byron duty belt, but when it wears out I'll get a niteize holster for that.

It can probably be mounted on rails, but I haven't tried yet. Definitely a versatile and durable light.

reviews: I've been carrying this light at work as an industrial electrician every day for a year and a half and during that time it has proven to be very durable and reliable. I use it often to quickly light up dark corners of cabinets and read stamped labels, and will use it as a work light, leaving it running on what I'm working on for extended periods. I wish I could give it 4.5 stars because it's only real drawback as a basic work light is the battery life. It eats through batteries a lot and it's been inconvenient a couple of times. Overall I can't gripe much about it for as much as it gets used but I've got other lights that I like less for more important reasons that seem to go forever on batteries. The ten-tap programming works nicely and I've got mine programmed to come on low when the button is pressed once and high if you press it twice. I use the low setting most of the time. One nice thing about changing the batteries often is I lube the O-ring often when the light is apart. I've had to wash it a few times in the sink with soap and water and it's proven to be completely waterproof. If I were to lose it or break it, I'd most likely not hesitate to get the same light again.

Highly recommend

reviews:
So I bought this with the intention of keeping it in my car. My thinking was this: I wanted something battery operated so those batteries could be swapped out with other primaries if needed in a pinch. In fact, the option to run either CR123 or AA batteries on this light is it's selling point. No need for recharging features or anything in this case.
And this fit the bill perfectly. It's a forward-clicky style meaning: a soft depress will active the first mode (350 lumens) and can be clicked into place to keep it constant. Or a quick one-two half press will take the click into the 40 lumens mode) and click into place if you want that one. The light comes on instantly with no delay. Perfect for flashing someone in the eyes or just in need of a quick burst of light without having to toggle through various modes. There is also a strobe mode. The 10-Tap programming is easy as pie and you're sure to find a "program" that fits the bill.
The finish on this light is a better quality that on the normal Streamlight Microstreams. The black anodizing seems slicker and less prone to rub off over time.

reviews:
So I like the light a lot. It is too big for an EDC, but is perfect for any other use. It is well built and very bright.

Now for the frustrating part with Streamlight and their engineering. I called them this morning because after 16 hours of charging, the indicator light never turned green to tell me it was fully charged. I assumed it was defective. I spoke with Gary who informed me that unless you use their charging head or one piece charging cable, it will not fully charge to green. I used both an Apple head and a very nice Anker head, which he said will not work to bring it to a full charge.

This is nowhere in the instructions! He is shipping me their one piece charging cable for free, but it is beyond me why they wouldn‚Äôt just include it with the light then??? I would have gladly paid $10.00 more for it to avoid the hassle of having to figure it out.

As an FYI, you can buy their head or one piece charging cable here on Amazon for $10.00 + if you want to avoid calling and asking for a free one.

review_title: Great EDC item, but BE CAREFUL removing the pocket clip!
reviews: For starters the flashlight itself is superb, with the lithium battery it is very compact yet a good weight, feels good in the hand, very, very bright, the strobe light function is pretty cool and the function switching using only one button is simple to master. The carrying case is a decent size, too, and of very good quality, I like how you can slide the belt loop on or fasten it via velcro. Haven't tested out the waterproof capability but I would hope it would be decent for the price. However, if I'm totally being honest the attached pocket clip is an absolute NIGHTMARE to work with, the manufacturer should just leave it in the package unattached, you wouldn't want to carry around this premium flashlight exposed anyways and risk scratching up the lens... the manual says it's "removable" and other reviews say "it pops right off" but be careful in doing so, you can actually damage your fingers or the flashlight itself if you do not remove it correctly... the easiest, best way I've found to take off the pocket clip is to slide the flashlight, white lettering exposed (otherwise you WILL scratch the lettering off... trust me, I learned this the hard way) onto the flap of a cardboard box, say the box the item came in, and with one hand securing the flap, fingers grasping the cardboard positioned on both sides of the flashlight body, wiggle & pull the light out of the pocket clip with the other hand, firmly but at the same time carefully (you'll need to wiggle a bit instead of just pulling in order to stretch and deform the clip temporarily and free the light itself, also if you just pull the clip belt prong might just bend permanently and then would be both useless and stuck)... you will scratch off some of the black paint in doing so, it just cannot be helped... DO NOT wiggle a knife/screwdriver underneath the clamping struts unless you want to slip and stab your hand (or worse), and for goodness sakes do not use your fingernail either, the clip strut edge is pretty sharp and will cut under the nail before the clip fully releases its grip on the flashlight (again, I learned this the hard way). Besides that (and oh yeah, per the instructions do not leave this thing on or sitting in your car glovebox in the sun or it might explode!), I hope it will be a very capable tactical flashlight.
