review_title: The HL-X is maybe 50 lumens brighter than the standard HL but with an awful clip
reviews:
I've bought 4-5 of the 750 lumen Protac HL flashlights and given them away as gifts except one that my wife keeps. I needed to order a flashlight for myself and came across the HL-X w/ 1000 lumen. Ordered one to try then maybe a second to replace my wife's 750 lumen. I fired the flashlight up and was not impressed. The brightness is barely brighter than the 750 lumen HL. Side my side the new HL-X and the old HL are exactly the same brightness but the HL-X has a slightly more defined spill border (where the light ends and darkness meets is clear and not faded). That's it. The body of the flashlight is the same as an HL, the brightness is the same as an HL, but the clip is screwed onto the frame with the HL-X but the problem is, the clip is folded in a spot were it gets in the way of removing the tail cap. The clip is weak - it wiggles easily on your pockets. It is supposed to be a dual-sided clip, but to try to make the baseball cap clip-on users happy, they ruin it for everyone else. You can get the exact same out of buying the HL and get a tighter clip.
tl;dr - Protac HL 750 is practically the same as the HL-X 1000 but the HL 750 costs a little less, has a wider light spill, and a better clip. Its not 1000 lumen - more like 800.

UPDATE - Sent back for a replacement. Received the replacement - the new HL-X I received is maybe 50 lumens brighter. This is tested in pitch black outside a city in the country. I am very disappointed in the HL-X, and the clip is extremely weak and gets in the way of removing/replacing the endcap. It looks and feels like a Protac HL 750.

review_title: Quite possibly the perfect everyday flashlight
reviews:
I just lost my ProTac 1L after 4 years of daily carry and am purchasing another, after trying out 4 other flashlights as replacements. This just might be the perfect flashlight: tough and bright enough for tactical use (my previous one saw service overseas), bright enough to do work (e.g. feeding chickens and locking the coup on a pitch black night) without being overwhelmingly brigt some some of the newer tactical lights. Dual fuel, runs forever. A truly superb product.

PROs:
(+) Solid 350 lumens as advertised
(+) Small enough to EDC without looking like "Joe Tactical"
(+) Runs on RCR123, CR123 or any flavor of AA battery. You can find batteries anywhere (like the "no credit cards accepted gas station in northern NH") when your boujee rechargeable batteries run out.
(+) Excellent construction, fit and finish

CONs:
(-) Just a touch large for a single cell light...wish it was 1/3" shorter. It is just a touch harder to pocket than true EDc lights (which in fairness are generally 14500-based).

For the price, just buy this light on Amazon, along with a couple of high-quality RCR123 batteries and a small charger (combos available for under $15) and use it into perpetuity. One of my favorite pieces of outdoor gear ever.

review_title: Good Flashlight that looks like it will last! Update: it did NOT last!!!
reviews:
Update:
The flashlight did not last. After only a few months with minimal use (about once or twice a week) the flashlight is no longer working. The problem started with flickering and the light jumping between the beam strengths. It also has trouble keeping a charge. Now it is so flickery and unreliable that I can not use it. I am going to call the warranty (lets hope their policy is good and replaces/fixes my flashlight). Dont waste your time or money. There has to be more reliable flashlights out there. This is unexeptible, especialy when this brand is marketed for people in high risk profesions who need reliable light.
Original Review:
I bought the Streamlight 88052 ProTac HL USB 850 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight - 850 Lumens. Every flashlight I have owned was ruined by leaky batteries, but this Streamlight has a USB charger and a concealed port for charging. I no longer have to worry about AA or AAA batteries destroying expensive flashlights. It has ten tap programming, but to activate this feature you do not click the flashlight button ten times. Instead you are suppose to press it nine times without clicking and click and hold on the tenth time. For the price this flashlight is just what I needed. I have mine programmed on low-medium-high settings with the lowest and medium being useful for household tasks and the high works great for outside tasks.

review_title: One of the best wide beam output Flashlight thats not too big to carry on my belt.
reviews: As an Investigator, I've used many different brands of high-powered LED flashlights searching the darkest places you can imagine, what makes this one different is the wide area this flood light covers. Before I got this light I was concerned the flood lens would make the overall beam weak being spread so wide, I'm very pleased with the way this light makes daylight out of the area it covers, no pencil beam just brightness everywhere! It took me a little while learning how to change the output level but once I learned I have no trouble. The factory set-up is low-high-strobe, I set mine up to run low-medium-high. It always starts on low then I cycle up as needed. I run the rechargeable 18650 Lithium-Ion Batteries, they last a long time and quickly swap out with a spare pair I always carry with me.

reviews:
I've owned a few Streamlight lights over the past 40 years. And this light fit my needs almost perfectly.

Until it just up and died. I bought the light in November 2018. Today, May 27, only seven months later, it just stopped working. Now, if this got a tough beating on the road, like most of my lights when I was still touring, I'd chalk it up to the riggers of the road.

But in the seven months I've owned it, it probably doesn't have 10 hours on it. It sits on my fickin' nightstand, for Buddha sake. It's in my back pocket when I leave the house, which isn't that much. Bottom line: It gets very little use, and isn't abused. None-the-less, it just craps out on me.

A light needs to be dependable. And this Streamlight clearly isn't. Made in China junk. But then, what isn't now days?

review_title: Well made, a little heavy for carry though. To large to mount on shogun,. Excellent for back yard who's out there...
reviews: All my other flashlights are 150 lumens which work good during power outage at home. Recently purchased 320 lumen tactical to mount on shotgun. Smaller than this model and perfect for application. This is a large and heavy flashlight, much to heavy to mount on shotgun. Trade off is portable 1,1100 lumen hand held flashlight for emergencies. Have to remember only 1 1/2 hr run time. So I purchased a couple 12 packs of batteries for storage. Took this 1,100 and my 320 lum out in out yard after dark. Wow, this one is like daylight. Then I went out front and shined this one down our street. 5 houses away is the corner which has a stop sign, which lit up like a red xmas tree! And completely lit the front of the house at end of our street that faces us. This is in town, so this morning I took it with me during my morning dog walk before sunup. This is a serious light if you are looking to light up an area. Just know that it is far from a pocket carry flashlight. But at 1,100 lumens, it is still compact enough and extremely well built. Has a vicious center beam as well. Other bonus is it was pre-set for click on high only. Great as I am not interested in the high low flicker modes. Only thing is the price is a little high. I just ordered the Steamlight Scorpion 600 lumen Tactical on Amazon $62. Will be interesting to see difference in brightness and distance. Every flashlight that indicates meters does me no good on distance. I use an online meters to feet and this one was about 850 feet.

review_title: Compact powerhouse that won‚Äôt empty your wallet
reviews:
So, first off, let me just say that Streamlight sets the bar for ‚Äúreal‚Äù flashlights. These are the ones the professionals carry. Yes, you‚Äôll find less expensive choices out there, but they won‚Äôt hold up and perform like a Streamlight.

I own a bunch of Streamlight models and the majority are ProTac 1L-1AA‚Äôs. If you have to choose just one to flashlight to carry around, this is the one to get. It‚Äôs my favorite due to the perfect balance of size, cost and power ‚Äî this model is small enough to comfortably carry, fits any budget, and is amazingly bright.

My wife and I take our dog for walks along a long, straight road near our house. With the shorter days of Fall and Winter, it‚Äôs common for us to leave at dusk and return after dark. I normally use the strobe feature of the ProTac 1L-1AA to make vehicles aware of us. The powerful beam lights up the reflective surfaces of road signs a half mile away, and oncoming traffic responds accordingly. There are definitely brighter lights in the Streamlight catalog, but they are significantly larger and require more batteries.

Speaking of batteries, I also like the ‚Äúdual fuel‚Äù choice ‚Äî a single CR123A or AA battery. Of course, I prefer the CR123A lithium ion cells but these are not as easy to find as the alkaline variety. In an emergency, it‚Äôs nice to have a choice.

If there is a drawback to this light, it‚Äôs the lack of support for a USB-rechargeable battery. An upgraded rechargeable model would be the perfect EDC flashlight. However, under normal use battery life is excellent, and the dual fuel capability offsets the concern.

review_title: Slightly disapoointed but I think it will be OK
reviews:
I bought this as a less-expensive alternative addition to my Fenix PD22, which I really like for a compact light but which has been discontinued in favour of a newer, more powerful - and of course more expensive - model. Fenix seem to introduce a new model every few weeks and their prices are climbing- but they do make very good lights. So these comments should be taken in context , the Streamlight being quite a bit less expensive than a comparable Fenix.

As I only recently got it I can't speak to durability but I have no reason to doubt that if it is not abused it should be pretty reliable. The body is (I think) spun aluminum, as opposed to the heavier machined tube of the Fenix lights, and this makes it feel flimsy to me. Also, there is no knurling aside from on the tailcap (to aid unscrewing for battery replacement) and this gives it a slightly slippery feel- at least to my hands. Being "a bit older", perhaps I have drier skin but I would have liked some knurling on the body. Two or three strips of clear or black non-slip tape may recify this but shouldn't really be necessary, IMHO.

The light temperature is good- neutral white, without the bluish cast that some lights used to have. It is worth reminding potential purchasers that it only achieves 350 L when powered by a CR123 battery, which provides 3V. With a nominal 1.5V AA, it is rated at 150L. CR123s have very long shef lives though and so are worth the extra cost. It's not a bad thing that it can take an AA in a pinch, evem if the output is reduced. And I was pleased that the included AA is an Eveready, rather than some miscellaneous brand of possibly dubious quallity.

The multiple-tap sequence to access strobe or reduced output seemed a bit fussy at first but works fine when you get used to it. Depressing the tailcap button results in full output; a short press + hold gives strobe @ full output, and two short presses + hold results in reduced output. (The printed instructions are slightly different but this is what works on my light!) However the "tap 9 times at less than 0.4 sec. intervals" to program a couple of alternatives seems to me to not be worth the bother.

All inall, I think it will be a good light but I must admit to being a bit disappointed with the build quality even at this price. Streamlight has a good reputation and the vast majority of the reviews here are positive, so as usual, "YMMV".

reviews: I bought this to replace one just like it (never leave one around little kids; it will get lost) that I got for work & general use. As stated in the description, this model uses CR123A batteries which seem to last forever, especially if the light is used primarily on the low setting; while I was working (now retired) half my shifts were at night and all of my shifts involved poorly lit areas inside, and I usually only had to change batteries twice a year. As for lighting, the low setting is sufficient for ordinary use (90% of my time; on par with a Mini Mag Light), and the high setting is blindingly bright, focused and will light up the other end of a city block or make animals (cattle, coyotes, downed deer, etc.) easy to find in fields & woods. The short/small size fits easily inside the front pocket of my jeans and allows plenty of freedom of movement, and the clip makes sure it stays there until needed. Finally; this is the most durable and easy to use light I've ever owned, and is a great addition to any pocket, pack or purse. 'Nuf said...

review_title: Great pocket light for self defense, especially if you're also carrying a gun. The button set up on this light make it perfect.
reviews: I have several different pocket flashlights in this style but this is the light that I carry everyday. The primary reason I carry this light over others is the function of the tail switch. This light comes on at full brightness when you push the button, every time. It doesn't have memory like other lights I have tried where it cycles through 2 or 3 modes with each full press and you have to go through all the modes to get back to the beginning. This light does have 3 modes but to get to them you simply depress the button halfway and then sort of tap your way through the modes until you get the one you want, after which you fully depress the button. This is important to me because I carry this light as a companion to my handgun and if I ever need to use it I want it to come on at full brightness, not soft and definitely not strobe, as could easily happen with other lights that you have to cycle through. It is very bright for it's size and the battery life is good. I use it on a daily basis, almost always for short duration, and I probably replace the batteries every other month. The light is still working acceptably when I replace them but I like to have it at full brightness and like all led lights this will keep working for a long time at a diminished brightness level.

reviews:
I bought the non rechargeable model. This is VERY bright and can cause eye damage if pointed directly into someone's eyes. I saw stars for approximately 15 seconds when I caught the reflection off a wall from 10 feet away. That could be advantageous if you shine the light directly into an intruders eyes as a defense but if you catch a reflection of the light it will most likely have the same effect on you.
Myself and someone else were unable to program the light and since I mainly use the low setting it's annoying having to go through the first two modes to reach the low setting every time turning the light on.
VERY Bright wide field on high and dimmer yet still bright wide field on low. High setting throws off a lot of heat making me wonder the longevity of the LED.
The clip could be better sized and then sturdier for a 1 1/2 " belt. The sheath belt opening is velcro and adjustable and of adequate construction.
The construction of the flashlight seems to be well made.
As with any product I will have to see how it stands with the test of time.

reviews:
For a while I knew I needed a good reliable light that was waterproof, drop resistant, and most of all bright. This flashlight hit the mark for me. It features a high strobe and low setting. At first I was hesitant because I favored the mid setting of most flashlights, but then I figured the lows setting is plenty for basically any activity close range. The high setting is intense, awesome really. The beam reaches distances that will honestly compete with 1000 lumen flashlights...I often think Streamlight underestimated the high settings capability, because its darn bright. The strobe I find handy for diorienting house intruders, or just simply getting somones attention.
If you are curious about the reliablilty of its water resistance, you can rest any concern over it; I played with this thing in a 7' deep pool for about an hour and a half on vacation, stayed dry as a bone on the inside, still works perfectly!
You can tail stand this flashlight, however my only problem is that after a while the light, when on high, heats the light itself, expanding the rubber tail switch which pushes the light off of its tail end, making it incapable of tail standing unless you keep the light cool by some external effect. However on low or strobe it will be fine for as long as you need it. Not a big deal though. The light will heat up when used big high for a period of time (what light wouldn't?). At least you can keep your hands warm in the winter. The heat won't harm the light.
Ive dropped this light mulitple times and its gotten a bit tattered, which makes it look cool in my opinion, but the light has never decreased its value in anyway.
I've heard a lot of complaints about the pocket clip. But when I first recieved it, i had no clue what the complainers were talking about, as it tales a considerable amount of force to rip that thing off; its a VERY sturdy clip. if it is loose, just bend the two clamps in and snap it on...it wont fall off.
It has flat edges to prevent rolling...but they really do no good when the light gets bumped, but the clip will keep it from rolling.
This light is a magnificant EDC light. I carry it every day, and would highly recommend it to anyone who wants a great light for whatever reason. Ultra bright, ultra reliable, ultra water-resistant; awesome. The beam is beautiful, very defined. Get it.

I give my flashlights to my coworkers sometimes and I don't have to explain to them how to operate it like my other flashlights. The battery last pretty good on it (about 2 weeks for my use ). I don't usually use the cr123 battery with it. I just keep some for emergency use if i run out of aa batteries. I do have other flashlights from other manufacturers that take both AA and cr123 batteries but i can clearly say that this one is the winner because I don't have to remove any parts from the flashlight when i want to use a different battery. By the way, I paid $38 when i bought it and not $43.80 as I'm looking at it right now but don't let that stop you from buying it. I'm actually looking to sell my other ones and buy the same one again.

review_title: Streamlight quality, USB charging, BUT NOT 1" diameter
reviews:
Typical very high Streamlight quality. Decent charging accessories. Pretty large and hefty for a 1000 lumen light compared to some recent entries from OLight.
My one major bone to pick, which is why 3 stars instead of 5, is that the specs for this light are NOT CORRECT. They show a 1" body diameter, which will fit in most common flashlight mounts, but the body is NOT 1" where it is knurled. Since the knurling takes up the majority of the body, the actual effective diameter of the body is 1.1", meaning this light can't be used in any of the light mounts that I've found yet. Very annoying that I checked this spec before buying and Streamlight's specification sheet is INCORRECT.

reviews: This a really nice small tactical light. Streamlight has come a long way and now challenges the big boys like Surefire. This one has a neat clip that will clip both ways. Clip it to your pocket then mount it on your cap. The beam pattern is a good all around balance for distance and peripheral views. No focus, don't need it and one less thing to mess up in a critical situation. Best of all it will run on an AA OR a 123A battery. The AA feature looses about 1/2 the output power, but gives the light a universal power source for backup. Construction seems fine. The programming works, just tap quickly. I like the low/high program. Thought I wouldn't like low before high but on high flashing the light in a close area zaps my night vision. Low is about what you'd expect for a close quarters tactical. The bright setting is more a mini spot light. Good for SAR work out to 50 yds or so. Plenty good for signaling and useful for spotting maybe to a hundred yards in good conditions. All this in a light I can cover with my small fist. And it's such a deal!

review_title: Lots of light in a small package
reviews: Super bright, but can be adjusted to a lower light level for close-up work. The clip is effective at preventing the light from rolling far on a flat surface; it can also be clipped in a pocket or on the bill of a cap, and the clip will keep the light secure, so you don't have to worry about losing it. I like (very much) that you can use either a CR123 Lithium battery or a AA battery. You can find the AA battery almost anywhere in the world, so you do not have to worry about carrying a pile of batteries when traveling, and you can go extra bright with the 123 battery, which has a very long shelf life for a light you may leave in a purse, briefcase, or backpack for extended periods and still find useful when called upon. It comes with a nice holster that will fit a wide array of belt sizes, or you can easily carry it in a pocket without the sheath. It's not a lot bigger than a AA battery, so it is not a big inconvenience to carry it loose in a pocket.

I like flashlights and have owned or do own many Fenix as well as BLF and various off-brand lights and this Streamlight seems to be the most difficult of all in changing modes. reviews:
This is an awesome light. Being in the public safety field, I've learned not to judge lights based on lumens alone. This light throws a long, tight beam. Perfect for when you are on an accident scene at night, searching houses and property for missing or injured persons, looking for evidence, etc. Yes, I carry a larger light in my command vehicle, but this is always in my pocket and always with me. A big plus to this light is that it uses either a AA battery or a lithium CR123A. It's brighter than any flashlight its size with the lithium battery and more than adequate with the AA battery. This came in handy during Hurricane Harvey because CR123A batteries were not easy to come by but I could find AA batteries everywhere. This flashlight served me well through hell and high water. I'll never use another brand other than Streamlight.
Do yourself a favor and BUY ONE.

review_title: Built Like A Tank, Feels Like A Beretta
reviews: I love this beautiful beast of a flashlight! So solid, so frickin' bright, and the battery lasts for ages. I keep it on me at all times and probably will ten, twenty years from now. Feels right in your hand; right weight, balanced, nothing rattling, etc. The protection/charging circuit in this keeps it from flickering/shutting itself off and on when the battery voltage discharges to 3.7v like most led flashlights can these days. The micro usb input protected beneath a sliding collar that forms a waterproof seal when closed (as long as you keep the o-ring clean), well that's a feature I wish every rechargable device had. It might be more expensive than most flashlights, but it's worth it.

review_title: This is the perfect sized tactical light for me!
reviews: This ProTac 1L (88061) has many of the features I wanted for everyday use. It fits in my fist with about ¬Ω-inch sticking out of the bottom of my hand. I like the "Dual Fuel" feature, and can use either a single CR123A or AA battery depending upon availability. The CR123A battery is quite a bit brighter, so I use that one primarily. I really like the belt case; good rugged material and the velcro closure seems to be holding up quite well so far. I was concerned about how rugged the pocket clip would be, but it is stronger than it appears in the pictures and after using it with my jeans and cargo pants pockets, I'm satisfied it will last a long time. There was a little learning curve to access the 3 lighting styles, but now I'm pretty fluent in getting to the one I want quickly. I've gotten a few, "Hey! That's a nice light, where did you get that?" comments from people already. Good price at thirty bucks and a few cents.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: High output, very rugged and small enough to carry withyou
reviews:
This flashlight is exactly what I wanted - I durable, high output light that fits in my pocket. Most other lights with this much output have a much larger bezel, which makes them too fat to carry. This light is the same diameter end-to-end. The button is programmable, so you can make it momentary high beam and push through to keep it on. I really like to be able to press and hold, or press harder and turn it on. The on/off does click, so if you want it to be silent you just hold. The button is recessed so it won't accidentally turn on. The switch seems well made with no "mush".

Battery life seems ok. If you leave the light on for a few minutes it does get warm around the LED. I'm still on original battery set (it takes 2) but it is rated for 3.5hrs and I haven't used it that long yet. Even after being on for 2 mins, the light level did not drop or fade.

Wipes clean from dust, dirty and grime. The lens is recessed and protected.

The clip is pressed tin. It clamps very tight and is hard to slip over my jeans pocket. If I changed one thing it would be the clip, but it's not a big deal.

Very happy with this purchase and I'll probably get 1 or 2 more.

reviews:
This is a decent light. It is bright, and i like the s-clip which lets me clip it on my hat, even tho its a little heavy for that.

Comparing this to my streamlight stinger that i bought a few years ago, and the streamlight strion that i use at work, this light is a little disappointing. its heavy for its size, and its got a warm white led, compared to my streamlight, olight, maglight and fenix flashlights which all have a cool white led. Also, the "Ten Tap Programming" is not nearly as easy to use as the system on the stinger and strion lights. I'm not sure i will buy anymore of streamlight's lower end lights as its just not the same build quality as the higher end stinger and strion lights.

Over all, im disappointed in this light. One good thing about it was i could buy the light only (since i already had some 18650 lithium cells), which cost half as much as getting the light + battery. For the price, its a nice light and very bright, though when compared to more expensive lights it cant hold a candle to them

reviews:
Awesome flashlight. I have quite a few ultrafire, sure fire, lingsfire you name it lights. I use them for hunting, fishing, camping and any other general use for a flashlight. For Bowfishint there is no comparison. It pierces through the muddy Ohio River like nothing ! I wish I took pictures! I have a lingsfire 350L green huntjng light that reaches about 350 yards. This ProTac HL3 blows it out of the water. Its many times brighter then that light. Seems to be every bit of 1100 lumen. All my other lights can't compare. It gets warm with prolonged use. It is waterproof because I dropped it in the river on the shoreline and it still functions. The whole design and quality is way higher then the other lights I have. The caps thread on nice and smooth the button functions very well. I didn't exactly time it but the Duracell 123 batteries it came with lasted the entire weekend camping and I used it a lot. Half of the time was just playing with it because it's so amazingly bright. I used my range finder to prove the distance it went, it may go father but that was just the distance across the river. The strobe setting would disorient your local thief very well.
Worth the money highly recommended.

Andrew H

review_title: Nice light, some goofy design limitations. Your mileage will vary with those. But otherwise a stout and intentional piece.
reviews:
Finish is nice but not terribly strong. If you have other things in your pocket that are metal it will come off. My black bullet pen is 2 years old no scuffs this got beat up by my closed smooth pen on day one.

The pen has a lot of strengths but some are also weaknesses.

More than bright enough for its size, navigating its 3 modes with the depressible button is super easy.

Principle issue I have is you need to hold down the button. There is no switch as it were, you hold the button to get light. Given how the modes cycle this can mean if you are shifting grip and trying to use the low light triple clicking allot.

Given that issue this could kill the light for a lot of people. I do however find it to be nice that its impossible for this thing to get switched on in your pocket and drain its own battery.

With that Caveat I'm keeping rather than returning the light though it may be left in a glove compartment soon as I pick up a EDC with a switch option.

review_title: The only EDC light you'll ever need.
reviews:
I got this primarily as a replacement for the original ProTac I've been carrying around for years. I got tired of replacing the CR123 batteries every so often, so I went with this, which takes rechargeable 18650 batteries. Feels weird not having to buy batteries every month.

Not gonna go into too much detail, but this thing puts out a serious amount of light which is primarily suitable for long-range illumination. reviews: This is a great flashlight, it fits nicely in my pocket, it‚Äôs really bright and I‚Äôve only had to charge it once in the year that I‚Äôve owned it. I was invited to a 4th of July fireworks display, largest private display I‚Äôve ever seen. They played the National Anthem beforehand, but it was dark and you couldn‚Äôt see the flag. I pulled this little wonder out of my pocket and without much expectation, shined it towards the flag. Well, it was like somebody turned on a spotlight. From 50 yards away, it brightly and effectively lit the flag. There were lots of surprised comments around me about the brightness of the light. It left me with a good feeling to have been able to add to the evenings experience. What a great light!

review_title: Durability and dependability at its finest!

review_title: Pick your battles: Cree (price) vs. Streamlight (purpose)
reviews:
"Apples to Apples"

I figured many people looking at this product have or are also considering the very inexpensive Cree 7W 300LM Mini LED Flashlight (which I've also purchased and reviewed), so here's my comparison of both and also why I chose the 88031 model with 2 CR123A's over the models that use a single CR123A, AA, or AAA batteries...

Cree 7W 300LM Mini LED Flashlight:
---First glance...You notice the low price (I'll get to in a minute) and secondly you see around 1000 reviews with 90% of people giving either 5 stars or 1 star with very few in the middle.
---Reviews -whether good or bad, are all seemingly based on 2 things. 5 stars= they received an ACTUAL Cree, not a knock-off, and came from a distributor in the USA. I ordered 2 which I manually selected (for an extra .40 cents) to come from a US distributor called "Welltop". So they arrived in 3 days and were marked with the legit "Cree" as it should be on the side. 1 star= either received knock-off P.O.S's or ordered from a Hong Kong distributor taking 3-4 weeks, either way a hassle and waste of money.
---Quality (if made by Cree) well... the price should say a lot. Provided you dish out the extra $ for the UltraFire 14500 1200mah 3.6V Rechargeable Li-Ion Battery (Pair) + Charger Combo -also from Welltop- then they work well and are insanely bright. That's about where it ends... They are not shock or water resistant, so don't mount one on a firearm, and will tend to get very hot as you drain the battery which lasts about 90 minutes on "high". This like the Streamlight also has High, Low, and Strobe -a very slow strobe, so carry the back up battery or after that initial power burst it settles at the same brightness a cheap incondescent bulb has.
---Overall: A good price and purchase idea using them for similar things as I now do (i.e. letting the dog out, one by the night stand, if the kids need one to play with, etc...). Simply put, NOT a reliable emergency, hard worker's, LEO or tactical flashlight.
*************************
Streamlight 88031 Protac Tactical Flashlight 2L with White LED Includes 2 CR123A Lithium Batteries:
---First glance ...Okay, a bit pricey, but over 1000 reviews with 95% being 5 stars. Which do I choose and what's the catch?
---Reviews Just like Streamlight's reputation and other products, consistantly excellent and very accurate. There are bound to be some shipping mistakes or minor defects when tens of thousands are sold, but there's a reason people choose to "exchange" for anothr and not "return" for a refund. Read other reviews, just as they say -if I could give more than 5 stars, I would. Some have a problem with the "High, Strobe, Low" order, but it's logical with you want the strobe to use the brightest light setting which precedes it. And this is a REAL strobe... as in give the bad guy a seizure strobe.
---Quality -where your price difference is. Streamlight (unlike some other makers "cough...Surefire...cough"), does not tack on any extra zeroes for a brand name. This price is all product, and coming from a guy who first bought the Cree, can honestly say this flashlight is worth double what Streamlight is charging. Here's why I bought 2 more after my first. This has been submeged in mud puddles, mounted and fired on both my 12ga shotgun & AR15 (5.56 NATO), chewed on by my dog, left in freezing cars and on burning hot barrels, dropped about 389 ti... 390 times, and right now is in my pocket working perfectly -aside from some cosmetic damage, but this ain't a beauty contest (though new out of the box would win). The other 2 I bought are mounted on those firearms, which being so nice and slim only required wrapping electrical tape around it to the point of needed thickness (also needed with the Cree if you put it on, ummm an airsoft gun).
---Overall this little guy is a beast worth more than you'll pay. I use this on weapons, keep one on me, and will be buying at least 2 more for emergencies (one for the car & one by the fire extinguisher in the kitchen). It not only handles everything the Cree does, but also I would recommend for workers, LEO/tactical and emergency uses... or simply to have 1 "trusted" flashlight in your home.

The winner (in all categories): Streamlight

The model? I chose the 88031 2L model based on simple industry logic... Companies are producing fewer AA & AAA batteries due to their short life-span, thus raising the price. CR123A's are the new go-to battery and are dropping in price daily. They hold their charge for a decade and a single CR123A puts out the same power of 2 AA's and but lasts twice as long, so you do the math. FYI, this comes with 2 brand new Duracell CR123A's that won't "dim" out like regular alkaline, both you and the flashlight will know when it needs new batteries. And just like AA & AAA you can get rechargable (not recommended). Size-wise, the larger 2L (instead of the much shorter 1L) IMO is more easily handled for "regular to large" hands or mounting on weapons.

review_title: Streamlight, best top quality 350 lumen tac light for $40
reviews:
Wow, what High Quality impeccably made light. Just read the stats, they're all true.
This sucker throws a lot of light and doesn't get as hot as some of my other lights that only put out 200 lumen on cr123 batteries.
This has 3 pre-programmed modes; high, 350L Strobe, 350L very disorienting and Low, 15L? not sure.
You cycle modes by half clicks, within 0.4 seconds of each other and then press on at the setting you want.
You can also customize your stock settings to either Strobe-High or Low-High. I chose the latter.
To customize you need to, from off, press quickly in succession (within 0.4 sec of each click) press 9 times fast and stop on the 10th time until the light goes out and in the action click the trail cap button. Note: this is explained in detail in the enclosed material.
Anyway, this light's well worth the money. It's light weight, slim, fits naturally in your hand and built tough! Water submersible (limits in literature) real glass cover over led housing, top grade aluminum construction - it's a Streamlight!

reviews:
I just got it, and sitting here playing with it, I'm impressed! It's a nice looking tactical light, but it doesn't look that tactical. This will be my replacement for that light.

The pros (so far):
- small enough to hold in my (meaty) hands.
- non-tactical looking, no sharp edges.
- fits well in average pants pockets, sturdy pocket clip. Can be carried lens up or down.
- very bright with AA battery.
- OW MY EYES!!! bright with the CR123a battery. Ha!
- LOVE the ability to use expensive CR123 or easy to find AA batteries!
- comes with a belt pouch too.
- comes with an AA and a CR123A battery.

Only cons so far:
- momentary tail clicks have to be FAST to change modes. Not a big deal, really, just different from many other lights I've used.
- it will get warm. Even just after switching on, I can feel increasing heat in front of lens.

review_title: This light is exactly what you seek.
reviews:
I love this light. It is everything I want in a flashlight.

At the outset, I wasn't sure about Streamlight, I thought they were an LE/GOV designer product. I bought a Surefire second hand to see what that was all about. I used it til the batteries died. Then, harshly out of character for me, I bought a TLR1 HL. The heavens opened up, and i saw a blinding light- over 600 lumens emerged from a flashlight smaller than a pack of cigarettes. At that point I was Team Streamlight. I told all my friends, tried it on two handguns, it was just what i was looking for.

After the anticlimactic Nitecore I purchased, I was wary. I made sure to read all the details, especially about batteries. This HL3 had a wider focal plane, slightly more length, and an extra 100 lumens over the other one. Those 1100 lumens blaze too. I drove my Jeep with 8k lamps into a field and shined them onto a barn a ways off, and i could see the outline of the barn against the night sky. I lit that barn up with this Wonder Wand, and i could almost see the spirits of dead farmers rising up from the ground.

The description of this product says three 123 batteries are included, and by golly, they are. Also included is a belt clip, velcro holster, and instructions on how to change lighting settings, (high, low, strobe). IF I needed another flashlight down the road, I would buy this one again, no question. However, they got it right with this one the first time, so I don't think I'll need another flashlight for a long time.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

review_title: Works with EITHER a CR123 battery OR AA battery, how cool is that?!? All flashlights should do that!
reviews: Streamlight flashlights are great and this is my 3rd one. I got it because it can use 2 different types of batteries which is a huge benefit if you're out of CR123 batteries, but everyone has AA batteries laying around so this can use 1 of those as well! The CR123 battery is obviously brighter than a AA battery since it's power outbut is greater. My rough estimation would be about 33% brighter, but a AA battery is still plenty bright enough for me. I haven't tested it's runtime capabilities with both types of batteries yet, but being able to use a AA battery as a backup when the CR123 battery dies is a life-saver. I think all flashlight manufacturers should have this simple tech to be able to use different sizes of batteries and I can't believe it took any of them this long to implement it.

reviews:
Short version: great flashlight; would recommend it and would buy again for non-emergency situations. Also, the description is wrong in that you do not need two CR123 batteries to operate. You only need one

The difference in lumens between the AA and CR123 is noticeable, but that's what you get when you go from 1.5V (AA) to 3.0V (CR123).

Where it lost a star was in the performance one night when I needed it for extended use. I was in a raining environment and had the flashlight going for a little over an hour on "low" mode, and when I had power cycled the light it was having difficulties coming back on again. After about 10 seconds or so and a couple of tries, the light came back on. I was running off of a AA battery at the time. I'm not sure if it was an overheating problem or a moisture problem. Either way, there is that small chance that it might not work depending on the environmental conditions, and because of that, I would not rely on this in emergency situations. There are far more expensive flashlights that will fit that bill. But for the price, it's a FANTASTIC day-to-day torch

reviews:
Let me start off by saying I was skeptical on paying this much for a flash light that had lots of mixed reviews and some about fakes. I decided to take the "risk" and go for it and boy am I glad I did. I received a legit one with fast shipping and it exceeds my initial expectations. The lights programing is great and easy to use. The actual light modes are perfect! Only thing left to say is time will tell. I will update this review if anything changes but if not, buy this light! 10-16-18

Update: 11-8-18: Still kicking ass. Great battery life, I've only charged it once so far. Bare in mind I mostly use the low power mode and Medium when needed. Seems very water resistant, I leave it sticking in ice while working on a soda bargun.

review_title: A nice small light that is worth the cost
reviews:
I have had a couple of $20 flashlights and the on off button wouldn't always turn the light on and finally died completely. You basically could not count on it working when you needed it.

I decided to spend a little more and hopefully get a better quality flashlight and I believe I have. I really think the push button is going to last on this one. It just feels more positive. Light press for momentary and firm press to turn it on,

I never cared for the strobe and this light lets you select a program that is either just on high or on low and press again for high. I chose the second one and could not be happier. It took me awhile to actually get the program to change because I was trying to push the button to on instead of just momentary.

I also wanted to be able to use just regular AA batteries. I think the included CR battery is a little brighter but the AA is fine for me. The light is small. It comes with a velcro belt holster and the clip which probably can be taken off would work on a belt and will also keep it from rolling if you put it down.

There is a small hole on the base and I used the lanyard from one of my failed lights so I am set. It is a fixed beam so no focus which is fine for me. For the most part the low setting works for me and the high is plenty bright for probably 50ft or so.

review_title: First responder, military and hunter approved
reviews: . I have the opportunity to buy these types of products heavily discounted as a firefighter and military, but I've bought all 3 of my streamlight flash lights off amazon to get them quicker... completely worth the money. If anything this particular flash light may be too much for run of the mill use. I've used this flash light for search and rescue and it's by far superior to any flash light we carry on our truck or engine; except maybe the truck of engine flood lights. I managed the find the victim in minutes from a far when the rest of my crew was off with their lights straining to see 5 feet in front off them. The down side is it'll reflect heavily off glass and up close it's too bright. On that note, I could see how it could be good for clearing rooms or attaching to a weapon- haven't tried though. However, I wouldn't use it with a red light cover/film becuase i would assume it would be too intense to use at close range. For a duck hunt it's unmatched, I carry two and I've had the thing completely submerged. Now that I've said all these great things watch them all fail on me haha. No I doubt it, great product(s)!

review_title: Better power regulation than the Stylus Pro, lame beam
reviews:
At first glance, the numbers are unimpressive. Somewhat brighter, but a fraction of the running time. The reason is that this flashlight actually has some voltage regulation and maintains most of its brightness for a while, whereas the Stylus Pro has no power regulation and begins losing brightness immediately, trailing off at less than half output for most of the claimed running time. Streamlight has charts on the back of the packages and online.

The beam has rings. Both the distracting peripheral rings outside the flood area, and also something resembling the old "cree ring" just around the spot beam. I can't figure out what is causing it, but there it is. Stuff like this seems to happen a lot when an existing model gets a newer LED which is a slightly different size and shape, but the reflector is not changed at all.

review_title: (Not as) Disappointed after spending so much... (See edit)
reviews:
~~~Edit... Adding this statement and now increasing to four stars. I will leave my critical review below however, just FYI.
For whatever reason, it finally let me reprogram it and it works fine again.
For those of you poor saps that might have lost your instructions, to reset or reprogram the light you need to press the button 9 times in a row (fairly quickly and not pushing it in all the way / not 'clicking' it) and then on the tenth, fully depress or click and hold it in. It will give you a quick visual indicator if you did it right.
For whatever reason, mine was frozen on "high beam only" mode but it finally let me reprogram it. Read on for original review but my issue has finally been resolved.~~~

This is for the 88040 ProTac 750 lumens model (and I'll keep it short).
I am a fire marshal and code inspector so I have a great need for a good flashlight. Well, after only using this puppy for two months, it quit functioning as it was meant to. It now no longer has low beam mode or the strobe mode... Only high (or bright) beam all the time. When the batteries are nearing the end it appears to be in low mode for the last half hour or so of battery life but it's not like I can choose it. -- If I could, I would select 'low' mode more often to save batteries because with it stuck on high it obviously drains power rapidly. It also gets pretty hot if you have on for a minute straight or longer.
I wonder if that's how I fried it. ?? I was doing a walkthrough of a huge new building (doing an 'above ceiling' inspection) and of course, I was the only guy smart enough to bring a flashlight.
Anyway, I'm giving it two stars since it still works. It's just a battery drainer that will burn your ass if you leave it on too long.

In case you are wondering... I bought this in 12-2015 and it is now 6-2016 and I am on the verge of ordering another batch (dozen?) of Streamlight flashlight batteries. You might stretch them longer as a daily flashlight user if your 'low mode' doesn't break. -- Along with more batteries, I will be ordering another flashlight. Sorry to say I will be trying a different brand.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
---INITIAL IMPRESSIONS---
So far I'm very impressed with this flashlight. It feels very solid (all metal construction). Having the ability to recharge this flashlight through the built-in micro-USB port is really nice. There is no worrying about burning through batteries. The included cigarette lighter USB adapter is a nice bonus as well.

---USB Charging---
The USB charging port is exposed by sliding down the part of the flashlight below the lens (but above the belt clip). When the USB port is covered back up, this sliding piece slides over a gasket to keep water out. When it's closed it feels very solid and secure. Inside the 74175 rechargeable battery appears to be replaceable with an 18650 battery - so it should work fine if you had to use it with CR123A batteries (though I haven't tried this). There is an indicator light that's red while it's charging and turns green when it's charged. Mine came with the battery completely dead - it took several hours of charging before I could use it. For some reason when I was trying to first charge it the red light didn't want to come on and the flashlight wouldn't turn on even after being plugged in for several minutes (I thought it was broken) - after being plugged in for about 15 minutes however the red light turned on and it continued to charge. Maybe the battery was just really dead. Also I've noticed that when the battery gets too low the flashlight seems to just shut off rather than getting dimmer over time.

---OPERATION---
I also like how the flashlight operates. Unlike other tactical flashlights I've had that cycle through the modes with each press of the button, this flashlight always cycles between on (full power) and off with each full button press. To activate the strobe feature, you quickly half press the button before fully clicking it. To activate the low power mode, half press the button twice before fully clicking it. While this procedure took a little bit of time to get the hang of, it becomes second nature pretty quickly. I rarely find myself accidently turning it on to the wrong mode. The operation I described above is the flashlight's default programming - but apparently the flashlight can be set so that one press is low power mode, half a press then a full press is medium power, and two half-presses then a full press is full power mode. Also the flashlight can be programmed so that only full power mode can be activated to avoid accidently activating other modes I assume.

---PERFORMANCE---
The high lumen output is the main reason why I wanted this flashlight. At first when I turned it on indoors it was bright, but it wasn't until I used it outdoors that this flashlight was really impressive. It's really great for lighting up large areas outside. I was impressed at how well it lit up everything while shining it across a parking lot. Though it isn't adjustable, I liked the focus of the beam. It wasn't too spread out and diffused but it wasn't too narrow either. I'd say the light itself is more yellow (warmer) than other flashlights I've used - but not as warm in color as an older style of flashlight with a filament bulb. The low-power mode is pretty dim and not something I will likely use much, but it's nice to have the option to conserve power just in case. I haven't really used the flashlight in medium power mode. Finally the strobe feature works very well. Comparing it to other strobe LED flashlights, this flashlight's strobe seems to be faster and more disorienting.

I paid about half-retail, and if realistically advertised as a 125 lumen light and shipped with a lithium AA, this would be a 4-star product: compact, durable, good AA throw. It can pinch-hit above that, but falls well-short of the bold ‚Äú350‚Äù marketing.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Cheap but Effective, Could Be Improved
reviews:
I actually expected this to be more of an 85/100 (4 stars going on 5) when in fact I'm going to call it a 70/100.

My point of reference for this light is the Inova T1, which is similar in many ways with a slightly different intended user in mind. Compared to the T1, I like that the Streamlight 2L is slimmer and lighter. I also like that is has a clip. My use for this light is for general purpose but also as a fighting light to go with my carry gun (which I don't carry with a mounted light). The clip makes this light much faster to deploy, since the T1 used to sit in my pocket with a number of other items. It's also small and light enough that it is basically unnoticeable when clipped in your pocket.

Brightness is definitely good (maybe even a little more than you want on a light like this) and I like that you get 3 hours of life from a set of batteries. The hue of the beam is a little blue, which is frankly a little weak since these days a good LED flashlight can be made to have a very neutral white beam. Not blue enough to be an issue, but I'd prefer if it was whiter.

The click button is perfectly adequate and I like that you have to press relatively deep to actually click it on. This makes it easy to use as a temporary-on light. Strobe mode is also easy to activate without being cumbersome. Strobe mode is a double click and low mode is a triple click. Low mode is a pain to get into but that's fine because it's really only for if you plan to have the light on for an extended period and don't want to deplete the batteries.

What I don't like...

It's cheap. Nothing here really feels highly robust or durable. It doesn't feel like it will fall apart, but if I didn't work a white collar job and do car camping as my most intense outdoor activity, I wouldn't trust it. For my purposes I'm sure it will be fine. In general I trust Streamlight and have two of their TLR-1 weapon light (which I love and it is very robust). That said if I worked a blue collar job or needed this for duty purposes or intense outdoor activity, I'd say to look at Surefire. My Inova T1 is definitely much more of a quality item, but it is also larger and probably twice as heavy, and definitely not as tactical in design.

The finish on the light is pretty smooth, aside from the features on it, so wet grip will probably score a C-.

The spill of the light isn't as wide as I'd like in a tactical light, but it's not bad. The spill area is good as far as brightness, just not width.

Finally the clip design is poor. Stiffness is great but the way it's set up, your pants fabric will catch before getting up into the top of the clip unless you really work at it. Not conducive to putting the light back in your pocket and clipping it one-handed. I removed the clip and bent it with pliers to make it so it stopped snagging and still has proper tension. Not the end of the world, but I prefer when I don't have to modify a product to make it optimal.

I have no qualms about using this as my EDC light, but if I had $200+ to spend on an EDC light I'd probably get a Surefire... but I don't so this will work well.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: The Streamlight ProTac 2L-X: Simple, Practical, Excellent
reviews:
The ProTac 2L-X has quickly become my favorite flashlight. The machining quality, anodization, and general fit and finish are all excellent. You can tell that it's quality as soon as you pick it up. The tail switch has longer travel than other lights, and this makes it much easier to use the momentary function to cycle through modes without accidentally clicking it on at a brightness level you don't want. Programming is relatively easy with clear instructions, and once you have it on the configuration that you want, it's a breeze to operate. I have mine on Low-High for simplicity and EDC usage. The light tailstands easily, and the clip is excellent. This is the first 18650-sized light that I can comfortably carry in my pocket because of how deep the clip is. You can actually put it on a baseball cap too, although it looks pretty ridiculous because of the size. I find the light output to be adequate and the runtimes to be excellent. No, it does not put out as many lumens as comparably-sized lights, but it delivers almost as much but with much longer runtimes*. I personally find this to be much more useful. Some 1000 lumen lights will throw light farther than I can clearly see, and they burn through batteries like crazy. This light shines plenty far but is much more efficient with its runtimes. My only real complaint is the color of the light. It's not cool white like most LEDs, but it's not really neutral white either - it's more of a yellowish tint. This is a really minor complaint as I can still see everything just fine, it just distorts certain colors a little bit. Overall, the ProTac 2L-X is excellent, and if you are considering a purchase then you won't be disappointed.

*500 lumens vs 1000 lumens seems like a giant difference, but the human eye perceives light logorithmically, not linearly. In layman's terms, this means that even though on paper it's a big difference, visually it is much, much smaller.

review_title: Seems like a true American spec 1100 lumen Compared with Surefire ...
reviews:

If you frustrated with all the chinese spec 1000lumen and don't want to spend an arm and leg, this is your best choice.
Is a very nice product with reasonable price.

reviews: Not bad. Not great. From a technical view on this little bad boy, it has everything. In functionality, holding and using it, it falls short. The tail button is not engineered well. It feels loose and just overall, not great quality. You have to press it all the way down like to the body of the flashlight, which feels like about a 1/4 inch before it clicks. And the actual mechanism that ‚Äúclicks‚Äù under the rubber is just a very small pin-point you can feel under the actual button. Using a CR123 battery, the light does produce decent light. However, it seams all over the place. It doesn‚Äôt have great throw and the spill is broken and un-even. Using a single AA battery, this flashlight doesn‚Äôt stand out of the crowd. It‚Äôs ok at best. Size is awesome however and the rest of the flashlight seams like it‚Äôs built very well. Great clip. You would do much better with the Fenix LD12 G2.

review_title: HEADS UP IF YOU CARRY IN YOUR POCKET.
reviews: I've carried one of the pro-tac models by streamlight every day for 5-6 years or more. I recently switched from the protac HL(1000lm) to the protac HL-X(1000lm). I will say I do like the more focused beam at longer distances but I do not like it enough to warrant the size difference. I carry my lights clipped inside my back pocket. My protac HL fits nicely clipped in the corner of my pocket while the HL-X is so big the light hits my pocket bottom before the clip is even touching. Long story short if you want a truck light this is for you. If you want a carry light... there's plenty of 1000lm options, this isn't one.

review_title: Overall fantastic, only a couple things I would change
reviews:
I just received my light, so this is really just a preliminary review.

First thing I noticed, how compact it is! This is probably the only 2x CR123 light that I would EDC (everyday carry). Most other flashlights have a large head that make it cumbersome to carry. This one fits nicely in my left back pocket, almost unnoticeable if you are used to carrying flashlights or knives.

The beam is great. High mode is very bright. I'm used to carrying a Surefire E1B backup, which cost me $140. This light seems brighter. I can't do a side-by-side comparison because I lost the Surefire, hence why I bought this. Granted, the Surefire was a single cell, and this is a 2 cell, but it's worth noting.

The programming modes are awesome! I really, REALLY hate flashlights that have a million different modes. I only want two modes, low and high. I don't need strobe, SOS, or any other fancy modes. This flashlight allows me to program it how I want it. I was worried about this at first, because I thought it would be confusing to operate, or that I would accidentally switch between modes. It turns out that it's very simple to switch between the 3 modes, and nearly impossible to accidentally switch between them. One small gripe, is there is no mode for High-low. However, I can live with the Low-high mode.

Another small complaint I have is, the pocket clip hangs up on my jeans. I can easily slide the clip half way onto my jeans pocket, but then it hangs up. I have to pull outward on the clip to get it to "seat" all the way. I ended up slightly prying to clip outward to make it a little easier, however it still binds up a little because of the design, and it seems like it will chew up my jeans over time. It's the part that clips onto the flashlight that binds on the pocket, because it has a sharp 90 degree edge. Chamfering that edge with a file will probably remedy that problem.

The sheath is nice, nothing fancy. I would call it average quality. Not extremely well made, but not junk either. Middle of the road. I don't plan to use the sheath anyway.

I would give it 4.5 stars if I could. It's a very, very nice light, especially for the money. But for me to give something five stars, it really has to be perfect.

review_title: This flashlight may be TOO bright for some applications! ...
reviews: This flashlight may be TOO bright for some applications! If you want something that will light up what's in front of you, and can be seen from space, this is the one for you. If you want something to, say, read network jack numbers under desks, it's WAY to bright. It does have a low setting, but you have to "thumb" the on/off switch through high and strobe to get to it. It should be high, low, and then strobe. It's clumsy. Also; the beam can't be tightened. It only has one setting. This thing will eat batteries for breakfast. On the high setting with rechargeables, the thing only goes about twenty minutes, and then starts flashing on and off, indicating that the battery is dying. Get a set of rechargeables and a charger.

review_title: It's alright, but evaluate your needs first.
reviews: I bought this light for personal use, but took it with me as a duty light when I joined my local Sheriff's Department as a jailer. This light is OK. It is my second of this type, and this one seems to be dimmer than my original light. Here's what you need to know. I do not doubt it is the full 850 lumens, it's bright at very close range. However, the beam pattern is very wide and the brightness of the light is lost at any distance. For my use, it is adequate, but I wish the beam was more narrow so as not to shine it into the eyes of inmates when doing nightly checks. Personal issue. The rechargeable battery is nice, saving money and heartache hunting down CR123 batteries for a reasonable price. It is also nice that it takes a very common charger. BUT, it takes FOREVER to charge. Charging overnight is the only feasible option. Once it is charged, it lasts a very short time on the high setting in my opinion. The versatility is nice though. I occasionally have problems with the light not working, I will have it on and it will momentarily go out as if the end cap is loose, even if it is not. It is not common enough to be an issue for me, but it is a data point. I get a lot of compliments on this light, and am often asked how much I paid for it. I am happy with this light, but would not buy it again, as I think the light is a compromise in size, convenience, and versatility. I encourage you to evaluate your needs before buying. I wish I had.

review_title: This is a fantastic light. It feels nice and balanced when held
reviews: This is a fantastic light. It feels nice and balanced when held. The multi-touch button takes some getting used to, but i can now quickly cycle through the modes in no more than a second to get what i need. I use this light daily, 1-3 times for 5-10 minutes at a time and the batteries will last about 2 weeks or more on a single charge (never used the disposable ones it came with). The recommended streamlight batteries and charger are great, but i recommend  18650 Battery 3500mAh, EASTSHINE E35 10A Button Top 12.9Wh 3.7V Protected Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries 2Packs for High Drain Devices  as the rechargeable battery to go with. They last longer and the light doesnt seem to get as warm during prolonged uses. As for the brightness, watching coworkers point it towards their face and turn it on never got old. This light is BRIGHT. I use it in dim areas and it will turn night into day on the normal bright mode when you need it, and provide a comfortable light for reading or close up work when on low mode.

I bought this for him as a stocking stuffer -- and later borrowed it one day when he was out of town. I love this flashlight! The Streamlight 88030 (180 Lumens) (Tip, don't aim this at your friends or you WILL give them retinal burn-in). After reclaiming his Christmas gift, I had my husband order two more of these babies -- and took ownership of both. Also note, the flashlight has 3 settings. High, Low and Strobe (not sure what purpose there is for a strobe feature on a flashlight except for maybe at an impromptu Rage party?) If you're looking for a powerful, yet compact, flashlight, I highly recommend this one.

review_title: The Streamlight 88034 Pro Tac is a very good small light that is featured with two brightness levels
reviews: The Streamlight 88034 Pro Tac is a very good small light that is featured with two brightness levels. Care must be given to this light though. The thread for the top where the led is housed is not that strong. If this thread is weakened the light will not function properly that is to say the on feature will not engage. For that reason use of the included black metal holding clip is not advised. If you use this clip it will cause the undue pressure on the light head which will cause stress to the threads. Aluminum is not a hard metal so once the threads are broken the on switch will not engage properly. I have had to replace this light for a new one for this same reason. But knowing how this happened and not repeating it makes this still a very good light.

review_title: Excellent Tactical and everyday carry light, if you carry on your belt and not in jeans pocket.
reviews:
Very nice flashlight. I own a number of lights, in fact I an somewhat obsessed with finding the prefect everyday carry and otherwise flashlight and have tried and own many major brand tactical and everyday carry lights (almost all led).

I like Streamlight products and have had very good results with all so far. This is a very bright light and has the ability to do high, low and strobe with a slight push of the tail button and then a full push once you select the appropriate setting you would like. It is very sturdy as i have dropped it a couple of times on cement and asphalt with no issues whatsoever. Still on the batteries that shipped with it and have used it for about 15-20 minutes on high and 20-30 or so on low and strobe. Batteries still test out full charge with my battery tester that puts a load on the battery to do a full test on them.

The size is very compact for a 600+ lumen light with the head being the only large part of the light, it is slight wider than the body of the light, but very good size.

I would recommend this to anyone wanting a very bright light that is very sturdy and has a tactical strobe as well. Too large to pocket carry in jeans, I carry mine clipped onto by spare mag case that rides horizontally on my belt and it is very comfortable and easy to access quickly.

reviews:
We bought three for our family's camping bags; they all worked perfectly out of the box and feel solid and reliable. The grip is aggressive enough to provide solid control even if wet, and the gaskets were all in good working order.

The one issue I have is the multi-function selector switch: you only have one button to turn on the flashlight and control the brightness setting. To activate the different brightness setting, you have to quickly (<.5 sec) press the button (light) on and off, which is difficult given how strong the button is. If you are intentionally trying to press the button as fast as possible, you MAY be able to get it to the correct brightness setting eventually, but it isn't something that will happen easily. There is a way to reprogram the light so that the default changes from high/low to low/high, but is needlessly more difficult than cheaper lights that cycle brightness settings (low-high-off).

reviews:
Okay, I'm impressed with this little wonder light. I bought it six months ago and have been carrying it with me ever since. It's only about 3 5/16 inches long and 13/16 inch in diameter (at the bezel), and throws out a tight, bright, blinding white beam. It is high quality all the way, both in material & manufacture. Like any good daily carry item, it's not cumbersome and most of the time I'm not even aware that it's there; but when I do need it, it's available and ready to do its job. This will never replace my primary tactical flashlight--and if I was allowed to carry a firearm in my oppressive state of residence I'd surely be carrying something other than the Protac--but it's a great little gadget for an everyday carry item or backup. I was carrying a Surefire Executive Defender (E2D) until I bought this. Don't get me wrong, I didn't buy this with the specific intention of replacing my E2D (actually, I'm not sure why I bought it). I was and am still perfectly satisfied with the E2D; but the Protac is just so much easier to carry around (especially with its included nylon belt holster), has almost twice the output of the E2D (110 lumens vs 60) with a cleaner & whiter LED light versus the E2D's yellowish Xenon lamp, has a longer battery life (even on "high"), and is more versatile with its additional "low" setting that I figured it was a much better choice for me (YMMV). And I gotta admit, even though I'm a big fan of the crenelated bezel on the E2D, the fact is, the crenelated bezel has put holes in my pants, something I'll never have to worry about with the Protac. [Yes, the Protac has a somewhat crenelated bezel, too, but not as aggressive and obviously a lot smaller.] I think there are better choices for a flashlight to keep stowed in the car, but this could certainly fill that role, too. All in all, an impressive little tool.

Edited To Add (Part 2) 12/10/13
-------------------------------
The above review is for the Protac 1L. This year (yesterday in fact) Amazon had a Lightning Deal on the 2L, so being as impressed as I was with the 1L, it was a no-brainer that I would purchase its big brother during the sale also. Unfortunately, Amazon won't let me make a second separate review for the 2L, so I have to piggy back my review of it onto this one (which probably means nobody will ever see it, considering the sheer number of reviews on this product).

First of all, kudos to Amazon... overnight shipping (w/o paying for it) during the Christmas rush? Wow! This is the second product in two days in which that happened. Impressive.

As for the Protac 2L, it's a solid 4-star product. I have to be more critical with the 2L because it really is more of a tactical flashlight than the 1L. Some people (not me) will not like the fact that it doesn't come with a lanyard, nor does it have a loop to attach one (though you might be able to attach one to the included clip). I also think the head is too long in relation to the body; if you use the clip to carry the light bezel up, there's too much protruding out of your pocket, so you're pretty much limited to bezel-down carry with the clip. My biggest complaint, however, is the recessed tailcap switch. A recessed switch precludes one from using the Surefire-Rogers low-light technique (i.e. the "cigar method"), or at least from performing it correctly. This is where SureFire flashlights will never be beaten; their tailcap design (on the 6P, G2, etc) is perfect for tactical use. No "tactical" light should ever have a recessed tailcap switch. So again, like the 1L, the 2L will never replace my primary tactical light. It is, however, my new EDC light, replacing the 1L.

Aside from the above criticisms this is a solid, high-quality light. It's plenty bright on 'high', and 'low' is still bright enough for you to navigate around in darkness or to read things w/o burning up your batteries. The 2L has a REALLY NEAT feature that the 1L doesn't; it gives the user a choice of three preset programs. The factory default is high-strobe-low. Also available are high-only and low-high. I use the low-high mode; I'm not a fan of strobes, and even if I was I think it's pretty ridiculous to think that in a life-or-death situation, with an adrenaline dump in your body and loss of fine motor skills, that one can seamlessly perform a double-tap to activate strobe mode when a bad guy has a gun pointing down his/her throat! If I was a LEO, I think I'd keep it set on high-only while on duty; switch to low-high if there's a legitimate need for a 'low' beam. Frankly, I think Streamlight mucked that one up, too. It makes MUCH more sense to have a high-low program on a "tactical" light instead of a low-high program, but that option isn't available. Pretty dumb (IMO).

Everything else is as you would expect. High quality materials/workmanship, waterproof to 1m, crenelated bezel (albeit more subtle), a nice pure white light, nice throw, good beam form, etc. It's "maybe" kind of narrow if you have big hands, but the clip certainly aids in gripping (if you choose to keep it on). It also comes with a ballistic nylon holster, if (like me) you prefer belt carry over pocket carry. Two Duracell Ultra 123 batteries are included. Like I said, a solid 4-star product.

reviews:
This little torch is AMAZING. I primarily wanted something to sweep the house with in the middle of the night when "the wife hears a noise". --UPDATE--

So, my favorite little light decided to up and die on me while looking under the hood of my car. I've literally used this thing 3 times. While using it the last time, it was used no longer than 10 minutes. The light got hot and I turned it off. It never turned back on. Very disappointed to say the least. Not sure if I got a bad unit or what but I liked it so much I'm willing to give it another shot and return this for another. Will update once I get a thorough test on the second unit. And I will test it till the battery runs out.

--UPDATE 2--

First off, Kudos to Amazon. They shipped me a new light Monday and I received it Tuesday. I immediately put the thing to test. This particular light behaved much different than the first. I left it on for over 30 minutes at one point and while it got warm, it never got as hot to the touch as the first one did. Anyway, the second light works great and I still love it. I still recommend it. Thanks

reviews:
I bought this guy to replace a Polytac that I somehow managed to lose and that I was, in turn, lost without. My main light is a Streamlight Stinger but I need a small backup light that I can always carry since the Stinger is too large to wear comfortably all the time.

This light is great. Typical Streamlight quality without the ultra-premium price tag. It is VERY bright at max, the strobe is nice and disorienting, it's sturdy and feels good in your hand, and the tailcap switch feels solid.

Only a couple minor negatives:

a. It is very lightweight. Along with the light weight (I had to double check to make sure it wasn't a polymer flashlight when I first took it out of its package), it's fairly skinny...not much bigger around than the included lithium batteries. It's also a shorter light (which I wanted), and if you take it all together and it's just not a very substantial tool. Not a big deal, but I wouldn't have minded something a bit more solid.

b. The switching system. This is what I knocked a star off for. I can understand why Streamlight did what it did here, but the pattern doesn't work best for me. Click once and it comes on in high mode. Click again, and it strobes. Click a third time and it goes to low. I would have MUCH preferred it started low, then high, then strobe. It's not a deal breaker and I'll get used to it, but I really don't like it much. Also, like I mentioned above, the switch feels positive and sturdy, but it's a long-throw and clicking through that long throw 5 times to get to low-mode is mildly irritating.

c: The included pouch is pretty cheap and I'll be trying to find a molded nylon pouch to replace it. I honestly worry about the security of this light while hanging on my belt, but I've had no problems with it (other than mental ones, that is).

All that aside, it really is a great light and I'd buy it again if I had to do it over again.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster
