#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
If any of you watch YouTube...look up Nutnfancy's review of this light. He says it all...
Originally, I was looking at either the Preon-1 or 2, or the Pro Stylus, and ended up seeing this one on the page for the Stylus here on Amazon... so I clicked on it and opened it up. And I am glad I did! I was looking for an EDC flashlight that was light enough to carry in my pocket every day, but wasn't going to break the bank in terms of cost, and this fits that role perfectly. I didn't want to spend more than $30 on this light because I already have an Olight M20 Warrior, and an Olight T25 which I LOVE both...but even the T25 is a little too big for EDC (at least for me). The Preon 1 is a twist top (to turn on/off) and I wanted a tailcap pushbutton, and that's why the Pro Stylus was my original choice. (I STILL may buy the Preon-1, because for only $32 bucks that thing looks like a powerhouse of a mini flashlight!) However, I ended up going with this one instead of the Pro Stylus due to the higher lumens and it has a high/low/strobe function, which the Pro Stylus does not. And in comparison to the Preon-1, this was a little bigger, and I didn't want to lose the small Preon.

And wow...this thing is awesome for such a little pkg.

Pro's (for me):
Good amount of light: 80 lumens on high, 10 on low.
Lightweight. I barely notice it's there.
O-rings for water resistance. (I think it says it's waterproof down to 3-5 meters or something like that, but I don't intend on diving with it, so that's fine.)
Good quality build.
Good price: $29 bucks on Amazon, but I've seen it for less elsewhere.
I like that it uses AAA batteries, which are readily available anywhere. (There is a AA version of this light as well, if you want a little bigger version!)

Con's:
I wish the clip was a little higher, so it rides deeper in my pocket. So I don't lose it.
The tailcap button is hard to press. But I'm finding I might like that so it doesn't accidently get turned on in my pocket or bag.
I wish it came in other colors: metallic orange, blue, green, etc. Then it's easer to find in a dark bag at night.
I wish the high/low beams were right next to each other, instead of it being: Hight (single click), Strobe (double click), and Low (triple click). Put the low before strobe! I'm sure there is some reason for that. But it's not a deal breaker by any means.

It fits in my pocket right next to my Spydeco Tenacious just fine. It's about the size of a fat sharpie pen and I barely notice it's there. In fact since I started carrying it, I have to reach down once in a while to feel if it's still there!

So here's what I did at home when I first got it. I pulled out my large Maglite, my Olight T25, and a no name Asian brand LED light I bought here on Amazon for 4 bucks (I didn't bother bringing out the M20 because that thing is a beast. I turned all the lights out in my living room and tested them by shining them on the ceiling one at a time. The Maglite and T25 have fairly new batteries, and the little LED has never been used. So the T25 was brightest, the no-name LED was dead last...and this little Streamlight beat that huge Maglite! In terms of brightness, wide beam...it killed my big maglite! I took my new ProTAC outside and shined it out to where my dogs are (about 20m) and it lit up the whole area. I don't think it throws 80m as advertised...but it sure does put out a lot of light.

If you're looking for a good quality, high lumen EDC light that won't break the bank...this IS IT. Buy it. Carry it. Love it. You'll be glad you did.

UPDATE:
Last night after a gig (I moonlight as a musician) I was walking out along the back of the hotel I was at, back to the parking lot and remembered I had my ProTAC in my pocket, so I pulled it out to test it. It was really dark, almost pitch black, and I must say, this light really lit up the entire area. So I'll take back what I said above...this light lit up a couple trash cans and boxes that were out at least 60m from where I was! I shined it down this really long maintenance pathway, and it lit the whole area. I am impressed more than I was before. If you're looking at the Pro Stylus, take a look at this light as well. It's a little bigger diameter-wise...but well worth it in my opinion. 10 out of 5 stars!

reviews:
Initial impressions (the first few days) of the ProTac HL 600 lumen

I bought this for my every day carry. Some people might say its too heavy or large for EDC but I think it will work well. You can see the specs online. It is slightly heaver and thicker but not as long as the LED MagLite I used to carry. If you're concerned about size then you either have to spend more money or go for less lumens. You could consider a polymer but I like the feel of metal.

It has a low lumen for regular close up work but still lights up a room very well. 600 lumen for the blinding down range sort of work. Be advised that it appears that the 600 lumens does not last 1.5 hours as suggested - the output significantly tapers down after the first few minutes.

Tail switch is way too touchy. Takes very little pressure to activate the light. This is bad for carrying in a sheath. I use a Maxpedition flashlight sheath and the light can be easily activated during every day carry or when sitting should anything press against the sheath. I easily circumvented this by putting a large bottle cap in the bottom of the sheath. The tail switch sits in the cap and cannot be activated by pressure from outside the sheath.

Speaking of sheathes, the one that came with the light is a joke. Flimsy nylon as expected but the fact that the sheath is too small for the light surprises me. The velcro hardly overlaps. No doubt the light will fall out under hard carry. Same problem with the switch as noted above would also apply. Glad I already had a sheath I trusted.

Fits well in hand. (I probably have medium sized hands, wear 7.5 sterile gloves if that helps). Seems stable even when wet. Works well with heavy extraction gloves. Pocket clip is sturdy but light will stick out of your pocket about an inch or more and you probably risk hitting the switch. Clip also has a lanyard hole. Seems too small for 550 cord but you could probably get the paracord sheath through the hole.

Its a bit awkward to switch between the settings at first (lightly press, not click, the switch for less than half a second and then press and hold on your desired setting). I feel this will take some getting used to but hasn't been a problem yet. Kind of wish it had an intermediate (perhaps even an extra low) setting.

First light I own with the TEN TAP - very cool concept but would like to see more options. Instead of the 3 it comes with: high/strobe/low, high only, low/high. Other combinations could be added: low only, strobe only, high/low; because you can change to any of these in less than a minute, more combinations would give the user more options. Adding an intermediate (maybe 200 lumens) and even an extra low setting (maybe 10 lumens) would make this light extremely versatile.

I use the low/high setting but I‚Äôve noticed a problem. Sometimes the light starts on high instead of low. If you're not cautious you will be running on high and kill your batteries.

Overall, the last few days haven't required much use of the light but of course I‚Äôve been manipulating and learning it. Hope to add to the review in a few months after some hard use.

Update August 2017 (purchased sept 2015)
Tail switch remains touchy. Sometimes the light flickers. Not sure why. I elongate the spring and that seems to temporarily solve the problem.

Over the months I've used it many times and still wish for an extra low setting. The low setting is near blinding for close up work and will run down the battery faster than say 10 lumens for example.

Small amount of cosmetic damage after a few drops. No big deal.

This is my EDC light but I don't use it everyday. Have only changed the batteries twice.

Overall still happy with it but given the flickering issue would have trouble trusting my life to it.

review_title: Great Light - Reasonable Upgrade from Stylus Pro
reviews:
About the light:

I have carried the Streamlight Stylus Pro for about a year (see review) and have been extremely pleased with it. What made me change/upgrade? Several things: First, I wanted a little more power, without more size. This light meets both of those. This light may not appear to be any brighter in a room than the Stylus Pro, however at night outside, I did the tree test about 25 yards. It was noticeably brighter. Second, Nutnfancy (see Nutnfancy youtube channel) gave a wonderful review of this light in comparison to the Stylus Pro. I heavily consider his input, as he is a great gear tester/reviewer. This light also comes with a low mode and strobe, both of which I plan to use, especially the low mode. The only downside of this light compared to the Stylus Pro is battery life, the SP has 6.25hrs run time, while this ProTac AAA has 1.5hrs on high and 30hrs on low. There is give and take. The SP has great battery life, but only one mode, and isn't as bright. The PT AAA has more modes, but less battery life. I still plan to use both, and would have both.

About the tailcap switch:

Some complain about it being stiff or hard to press. I have not had that issue. It does take effort, but that is by design, so that it doesn't activate in the pocket. This is a tactical light, hence the ProTac, so it is meant to be carried, and not easily activated. That being said, unless you have arthritis you will have no problem activating this light. I'm 6'2 180, average build, don't have the strongest hands, and I have no issues at all turning this light on and off. I also find it easy to switch between the 3 modes. I do recommend putting a drop of oil, gun oil, etc. on the tail cap threads as it helps the removal a lot. Otherwise they are dry and its a metal to metal feel.

Note on batteries (from my Stylus Pro review):

I am using the Lithium batteries with the ProTac AAA also because of the following experience with alkaline in the Stylus Pro.

I recently did change from the typical Energizer alkaline batteries, to the Energizer Ultimate Lithium batteries for several reasons. First, I learned that lithium batteries perform better in extreme temperatures, especially in cold weather. Cold weather drains alkaline batteries. Lithium batteries are superior in every way, except in price, but they are worth it. I had a Stylus Pro several years ago, that I left in a drawer for months. I went to get it one day, and it still worked, however when I opened it up the batteries had leaked and were stuck. I tried everything to get them out, but was only able to remove one. I had to throw the light away. Alkaline batteries can and often do leak, and when they do in a tiny light like this, it ruins the light. So my suggestion is to use lithium batteries. WM and Lowes sell them, Energizer Ultimate Lithium, 4 for about $9-10.

review_title: Good price, very bright, you will like this light
reviews:
I am a flashlight guy. I have dozens of them, and I use them professionally as well as around the house. I have a lot to compare this light to, including several high quality lights from Maglight, Surefire, Streamlight, Coast, Dorcy and several cheapo brands that I have tried through the years. This light is as good as any I have had.

The ProTac HL is extremely bright, and it feels as strong and sturdy as you would expect from Streamlight. The tail switch functions smoothly and feels durable with no "misses".

After research, I purchased this light to be installed on a tactical rifle. It is just right for my application, because I prefer a light that can cast a wide beam far down range. This light does that. it will light up the world between you and your target, including every inch of the ground between you and your target. This relaxes your peripheral vision and allows you to be sure of what is around your target. Some like a tightly focused beam, and if that is your thing, this light may not be for you. But I can tell you that this light will give you good downrange illumination almost as good as the tightest of beams. Streamlight did not make any shortcuts here that I can see.

The price for this light seems low to me. It is an outstanding value when you compare it to other lights in its class. A 600 lumen light that is made by one of the best in the industry and has quality components for far less than you would pay for most similar lights. Amazon's price for this light is incredible.

Another positive for this light is the programmable tail switch. For a rifle application I prefer a on/off clicky cap, and this light can do that. If you prefer a series of high/low/strobe, it can do that, too. You choose the setting you want. It programs reliably and once you set it it will stay on your setting until you change it - at least mine has.

If there is any con to this light I guess you could say it is the relatively short battery life. This is probably true of most high lumen tactical flashlights, so the ProTac is not unique here. The simple truth is that you cannot get high lumens and a powerful beam without burning energy. There are some rechargeable lights out there, but you will pay handsomely for them, and I think they are over-rated based on past experiences with them.

In my opinion, you cannot go wrong for the ProTac HL, especially for the price Amazon is selling it for.

*****UPDATE 06/21/13

I should add that this light fits perfectly into the Elzetta ZFH1500 tactical flashlight mount with no modifications necessary to the mount - for those that are interested in that fact. I also recommend that mount for those looking for a tactically sound way to install a light on their AR-15. Good luck.

UPDATE:
This review unfortunately just lost two stars due to bad customer support. I cracked the lens on the light and had hopes and expectations that the lens would be able to be easily and quickly replaced without a lot of hassle. I emailed support thinking it would be as simple as asking them to send me a replacement lens cap since the part just threads onto the light. See the email thread below (start from the bottom), I've blocked out only personal information. I will update again when I finish the process with the authorized repair center.

I am now going through an authorized service center to handle this, but would like to inform you that you are making the warranty process a huge pain. If you would simply look at the image I emailed you twice (three times now), you would see that no retaining ring came loose. The cap that the lens presses into is a removable part of the light. It threads onto the light and is sealed by an o-ring. That is the part that I would have liked for you to send me. Your lack of competence on your own product and what parts are serviceable is very concerning and makes me question if your product was the right one to spend my money on. When I spoke to the service center, they immediately knew what I was talking about. Pick your head up from your script and go look at the product before you reply to service inquiries.

Kyle Jurick

reviews:
This review applies to the 2L version of the flashlight. I've been carrying this one for about a year. It is by far the brightest flashlight I can tolerate for EDC. I have brighter flashlights, but they just don't fit in my pockets comfortably. So they stay at home and are rarely at hand when I need them.

This one is pretty bright--it certainly straddles the threshold as a 'tactical' light. But to be totally honest, I haven't yet had to blind any gunmen or bash in any terrorist brains with this light. I can't guarantee it's up to that task. But what amazed me when I started carrying this thing was the tremendous non-tactical utility of carrying a bright flashlight all the time: Tracing cables. Finding that screw I dropped. Changing a tire at night. Flagging folks down. Tripping that occupancy sensor. Pointing things out to a contractor. Startling whatever's rummaging through the trash at night... the list goes on.

I do hope someday to find a brighter and/or smaller flashlight to replace this one before it wears out. But for now, this one has proven entirely suitable for EDC, and I'll never find my cellphone's flashlight-mode adequate again. The clip is just right for in-pocket carry (tailbutton up). Mine works perfectly after a year's use, although it looks quite beat up. My only complaint: I wish the tailbutton were more difficult to press, or further recessed. On several occasions I've accidentally clicked the light on in my pocket, and not noticed until it's scalding hot (and depleted the batteries). The batteries are not cheap; for me they last at most a month (and that's without draining them in my pocket), but their cost is entirely justified by the performance of the light.

rank:
#9,282 in Tools & Home Improvement (See Top 100 in Tools & Home Improvement)
#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
The Streamlight ProTac 2L is a great flashlight for just about every purpose. I like it's size, 4.75" long and 13/16" in diameter. The power is very adequate at 260 Lumens (full charge) and up to 200 L for 2.5 hrs. according to Streamlight's Product Fact Sheet. The tail cap switch is recommended for use with a firearm as is the momentary function provided when the switch is lightly depressed. This light offers several different combinations of functions which can be set by following instructions and using the switch. The basic functions are high beam, low beam and strobe. It takes some practice to make the use second nature, but the three functions make this light very useful in a variety of conditions some of which could be life threatening. It comes with a pocket clip with strong tension which can secure the light in pockets or on a strap or belt up to 1.5" wide. It also comes with a sturdy belt pouch.

The only downside to this light is that there is no texture to the outer finish. It is very smooth. This means when pressing the switch with the thumb with dry or wet hands, the light is prone to sliding forward in the hand rather than actually operating the light. Not a good thing if your safety or that of others depends on it. I otherwise like the light well enough to keep it, but will definitely have to use something to give the exterior a no-slip texture. I'll start with a paracord lanyard secured to the pocket clip. With a light this small and with a black exterior, it would be pretty hard to find it in the dark if it were dropped. It would be helpful if Streamlight would include a lanyard ring or hole in the light where a lanyard could be attached.

Otherwise, this is a great light. I would buy it again and recommend it to others. I also recommend going to Streamlight's website to get all the information you can on this or their many other products. It is an excellent website, easy to use and very thorough. Also, don't forget to keep your purchase receipt in a place you can find it in the unlikely event the light fails.

reviews: The Pro Tac 1L is a good light except sometimes it doesn't come on unless I wiggle the tail cap slightly. I solved the issue by scraping away some of the paint on the threads and using a small aluminum foil shim laid across a small area of the body threads, but I shouldn't have to do this if it were designed right. The paint acts as an electrical insulator between two surfaces (body and cap) that require conduction to complete the circuit, and if Streamlight stopped putting paint/anodizing on the body and tail cap threads then the reliability of electrical contact would go way up. Other than that, it's bright, lightweight, and compact. For those wondering, the tail cap has a spring, but the positive terminal does not.

review_title: Best flashlight I've owned in 30 years
reviews:
Having been through many flashlights (fl) over the years of all battery sizes and bulb types this is hands down the best utility fl I've ever owned. The small size makes it convenient for daily carry and the clip is useful for keeping it close to hand. This is certainly the brightest fl I've ever owned, more powerful than my old 3 D Cell Krypton Mag Lite and definitely more versatile than my old Mini-Mag 2AA fl. Comes with a nylon cloth holster with velcro for the closure and belt loop, I'm not a fan of this kind of holster and don't use it.

Pros:
The strong beam setting is blinding and is the first selection when clicking, it could be used in a defensive or tactical situation for surprise, the low setting is good for working on items or using for situations where a bright light is not desirable, low is 3rd click..
The strobe is outstanding and blinding, it's the 2nd click; it's an excellent non-lethal defensive tool and desirable in a rescue situation.
Excellent battery life and solid construction.
Comes with two Duracell Ultra batteries.
Small, compact makes it easy to carry or conceal; great for a vehicle or bug-out bag.
Small enough to be used as a kubotan if necessary.
Can hold in mouth when you need both hands.
Rear activated rubber click-pad is easy to use.

Utility:
I carry a short length of white 12" long nylon tubing in my gear that slides over the light and is secured by the clip, when lit the light resembles a mini light-saber; good for a tent lantern or illuminating a wider area while walking. The tube also makes you very visible, great for Halloween or other times where you may be out walking at night, can also be clipped to a pack or vest for hands free. The tube is also excellent for the strobe and makes an excellent signalling device. A couple of pieces of spotlight gels can also be used over the lens to change the color to red for night-time vision, such as hands free map reading.
The tubing is available here on Amazon: search for "White Translucent Nylon 101 Round Tubing, 5/8" OD, 9/16" ID, 12" Length" if interested.

I've carried this for a while now, plenty of drops and no damage, actually got to use it on my first outing with it when my wife lost an earring in a haunted house, found it VERY quickly. The only way I could see this failing right now is from the rear click-pad switch as it may wear out over time, but that's not really avoidable.

Cons:
The flats don't really keep the fl from rolling, the pen clip does the best job here.
Batteries are expensive, roughly 1/3 of the cost of the fl but should last a long time.
Does not have a lanyard hole (could use loop in pen clip)
The pen clip occasionally pops off when inserting or removing from secured location.
Gets VERY hot on high (not complaining, just a fact but could be useful in a defensive situation).

Again, an excellent FL that I can see using for a lifetime, plan on getting several more the vehicles, wife and bug-out bags.

reviews:
I bought this gift for my stepfather. He loves tools, guns, wrenches, gadgets, you name it. This is a retired Marine, homeowner, and handyman. For him? Being useful and always having the right tool is a crucial matter of life.

He loved it. This is a man whose holy pantheon included Chevy, Craftsman, Black and Decker, Colt firearms, and Dr. Pepper. Now Streamlight is up there.

He loved it. He was shining it at the cats and deer all night with glee, and loved the USB charge port. He's going to use it for everyday carry. I'm so happy I made a real American hero happy on Christmas with this gift. He was showing it to his neighbors and the local police force too. lol. A real winner of a product!

product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster
rank:
#9,282 in Tools & Home Improvement (See Top 100 in Tools & Home Improvement)
#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
I bought this flashlight to carry with me at work on the ambulance. Since I work the EMS peak hour shift the last 5 hours of my shift are at night and I needed a good, small, bright, dependable flashlight to carry.

I found it with this one.

PRO's

3 Modes
Bright: is perfect for lighting up a small area outdoors and will easily light up small rooms by its self w/o a problem
Strobe: (Thankfully) I have only had to use this once. this works great for disorienting & blinding people that might be trying to attack you. I have also flagged down other ambulances and stopped cars with it.
Low power: Is just what it says, A lower power less bright option. Handy indoors or in a crowd when you dont want to blind someone. It may be a little bright to check pupils with but it sill works.

Solid Construction
This flashlight is built solid, you can feel it the moment you pick it up. You dont really fret when you drop it. It sealed at both ends makeing it mater resistant. Lets just say this isnt something you are going to worry about breaking anytime soon.

CON'S

Batteries:
It uses 2 "123" batteries which if store bought are expensive. If you buy in bulk they are not so bad. They came out with rechargeable 123 batteries a few years back but I have yet to try them
The battery life is decent, with regular use (several times a day 5 days a week) the batteries are lasting me 1 to 2 months.

Watch out for the Heat:
The front end of the flashlight can really heat up when left on for any significant amount of time. It is not as bad in low power mode but anything more than 4 or 5 minuites on high power or strobe you will notice some heat to it.

Crappy case:
The case that they included with this flashlight was obviously made in china somewhere. When you get this flashlight chuck that case and get another one. The velcro started comming off after 2 weeks and it started to fall apart after about a month. Plus the inside of the case has velcro on the belt loop that can come loose when riding in cars.

All in All this is a GREAT flashlight. It has a few drawbacks but I am very happy with it and I will continue to use it for several years (unless I loose it or someone steals in before then)

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: A great light in a small package.
reviews:
I just got my PT 2L about two hours ago, and I must say, this light is AWESOME.

This is my first experience with a tactical light, but I did do my research, so I knew what I wanted: something small and lightweight but bright, preferably with a strobe setting. And this little guy delivers on all counts.

The switch is quick and intuitive: one click for bright, steady on; two clicks for strobe; three for dim, steady on. You can lock any of these settings on by pressing through until the button clicks.

The light is also waterproof to one meter submerged, and they are serialized just in case. Combined with a lifetime warranty (barring batteries and abuse, of course), this is a great package for not a lot of cash.

I'm sure there are better lights out there, but be prepared to pay for them. If you're on a budget, or need a solid day-to-day light, this is definitely your winner.

EDIT 11/19/2012: I've been using this light for over a year now with absolutely no problems. My only complaint is that it tends to get hot if run on the full bright setting for very long. This is a small complaint, however, as the dim setting is still far brighter than a normal flashlight, even with the batteries low. Speaking of which, battery life is excellent under normal use. If you're using the bright setting a lot, you'll probably be replacing the batteries more often than I do, but a set of batteries usually lasts me several months.

A year later, I'm still giving this little beast 5 stars. I've dropped it, kicked it, soaked it, and generally abused it, but it's still going strong and doesn't have a mark on it. The best light you're likely to find without spending a couple hundred bucks.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
This is a great, small, bright light (88031 Protac 2L Tactical), especially for the money. It's lightweight and the battery life seems very good, which I want as I intend to use it backpacking. I also have a Surefire P2X Fury which is larger and heavier (and twice as bright on the high setting). The Streamlight Protac works very well and is easy enough to re-program to the low/high switching combination I prefer. The option of having a strobe is a nice feature.

Comparing this Streamlight and the Surefire (which I know is not exactly apples-to-apples--the Streamlight 88040 would be a more equal comparison to the P2X) in terms of quality, it's evident that the Surefire is more solid--I feel like I could drive a nail with it--and the switch has a more robust feel, maybe partly because it requires a bit more force to click. The main body on the Surefire is larger in diameter (thicker tube) than the Streamlight. Just screwing the tailcap in you notice the difference in build quality. But at a much higher cost I expect a higher quality product. That's not to say the Streamlight feels cheap, it doesn't to me and if it continues to reliably shine light then it's doing all I need it to do.

I do prefer the whiter light of the Streamlight--the Surefire's light has a more yellow/warmer color cast to it.

All-in-all I'm very happy with my Streamlight 88031 Protac 2L Tactical, it seems robust and bright enough for my needs and so far it's been working perfectly. It's very compact and lightweight, and quite bright on high. I'll update this review if something changes in the future, but so far, so good.

review_title: Best flashlight I've owned so far
reviews:
The unit the seller sent was defective. It would come on, but wouldn't take the "Ten-Tap" programming and the strobe mode had an irregular pattern. I called Streamlight's support number to see if I was doing something wrong and a real person answered. He walked me through a couple quick things and then agreed with me that the light was defective. I sent it in and very quickly got a replacement back (the round trip took less than a week). The replacement has been working flawlessly for quite a few months. I've accidentally dropped it onto concrete floors a few times with no apparent ill effect. I wouldn't advise being intentionally careless with the light, but don't worry if you happen to drop it.

I like the fact that it has strike bezels on both the front and back. The back bezel provides a recess for the switch that does a good job of keeping it from activating while in my pocket. Battery life seems to be pretty reasonable. The light output is a nice white color and not too blue like a lot of "white" LEDs are. And let me tell you, for such a small flashlight, it puts out a L-O-T of light on the high setting.

UPDATE 2/1/2019: Four years later and the flashlight is still going strong. I use it all the time (several times a day, 7 days a week) and I rarely have to change the batteries. I should note that I set it to come on to the low setting by default. I find that I use the high setting only about 5% of the time. The low setting is plenty bright enough for most daily tasks. I wouldn‚Äôt hesitate to recommend this light to anyone looking for an EDC flashlight.

review_title: Excellent light and just what I was looking for
reviews:
Excellent light and just what I was looking for. I use it professionally. The ability to use AA or CR123A battery is a huge advantage. I really like this light! Highly recommended.

NOTE: The original (sold by Amazon) order arrived with a light that was without AA and CR123A battery, and the package had been opened then resealed (the two heat welds on each side holding the middle of the package closed had been cut through). Shipping box didn't look like it had been tampered with. Light was intermittent and did not work as it should - 10 click programming did not work at all, light didn't always come on when button was pushed. Light sequence for the ProTac 1L-1AA should be High-Strobe-Low but light was High-Low-Strobe. This first light shouldn't have slipped past Amazon's shipping Quality Control. Good news is the replacement light arrived promptly in an unopened package and with batteries and light worked exactly as it should.

review_title: Bright yes, but not in the way you probably think. Sure not what I need or expected. Read more...
reviews: I'm a total Streamlight junkie and I have or have tried most of their tactical flashlights. When I saw the power output of the HL4, I was really excited. What I didn't know was that it's quite different than all the others in terms of the spot it makes. It has four LEDs and a frosted lens to diffuse the light everywhere. This is more like a wide "flood light". It really has no spot at all. Maybe there is an application for this, like illuminating a large room, but my needs require a higher intensity focused spot for greater distance. 2200lm is a lot of light for sure, but when you distribute that light over a huge area, it's not as bright as you'd expect it to be. It's not nearly as bight as the HL-3 for example at any distance. Combine that with it being really big and heavy as a rock and you have limited utility in most applications. I'm sticking with the HL-3's, which are just awesome. The HL-4 just missed the mark as far as I'm concerned.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Perfect for night walks and for disaster situation
reviews:
For me, this is the perfect flashlight.
* Almost all the time, I will use it for night time walks. The "Low" setting of 13 lumens and 50 hours battery life is perfect for that. I changed the default program mode to "Low-High". I really wish it had a "Low-High-Strobe" mode, but it doesn't. The other modes are "High" only and "High-Strobe-Low".
* For emergency use, I really like the Strobe mode and its 6-hour battery life (on fresh batteries). It may make a difference in being rescued if I were to fall down a crack while hiking. I don't think the Strobe mode will make a difference in personal combat. It is blinding only if the attacker continuously stares directly at the light.
* During search and rescue, the 260 lumens for 3 hours will be a Godsend for spotting lost person or equipment. (It's bright, but looks more like 130 lumens to me.) I am thinking of also buying the 600 lumens tactical light for search and rescue use.
* Size is small enough to carry everyday. Fits in the palm of my small hand with 1 inch sticking out. Weigh only 3 oz without cover and 3.5 oz with cover (but feels comfortably hefty). Cover fits snugly and has straps to attach to loops or belts. I will probably carry it without the cover inside a small purse, or attached to the front of a shoulder-strap on my backpack. Body feels solid and well made. Probably will survive harsh conditions for several months outdoors in the event of a natural disaster. Also purchased bulk supply of CR123A batteries from Amazon. The 600 lumen ProTAC HL also uses the same battery, so they can share. The less types of batteries used for primary gear the better.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

review_title: Great little light. Out shines most others
reviews:
I've had this for probably 2 years or more now and just have to give this little light plenty of credit. First off I'll mention the few things I dislike about it. The pocket clip. While its handy and I love it, at the same time its a love hate relationship. There has been probably a dozen or so times I went to clip this back into my pocket and the clip pops off the light. Annoying. It pops back on with relative ease, but still if you're not paying attention you can completely lose the clip, which I have done once but thankfully a co-worker found it a few days later laying somewhere near. Thats pretty much it!

Now what I like. The three click system takes a little to get used to but is simple enough, I love that it has the high, low and flash settings. Each has come in handy. I use the low setting frequently at home when looking for things and I don't need to be blinded. The flashing setting is great for getting peoples attention. I use it often at work. Usually people will stop and pay attention when they notice this thing flickering. And of course the bright mode is great at well, being bright as all heck. Its funny when I'm around other people in my line of work who also carry similar lights, Surefires and so on. So far I've beat them all out in brightness. The only thing that I've come across brighter is the new LED spot lights affixed to patrol cars.

I noticed one reviewer claimed he had an issue with 'battery rattle' I'd just like to note that I have not once been subjected to this in any form with this light in some two years and counting of heavy use. I've dropped it plenty of times on concrete, asphalt, steel, etc and theres only a few scratches on it and a few light dings. Seems pretty durable to me, heck the only place I've noticed much wear is on the very tip from being drawn out of and returned to my pocket so many times.

Oh and I nearly forgot the best part of this thing is the price here on Amazon. Since I've had mine I've noticed a pretty steady price point of $40.00 which you can't beat for a light of this quality. Probably one of the best purchases on Amazon I've made was taking a chance on this light.

review_title: Good quality, maybe too bright for its own good.
reviews: Very very bright. Coming from a stream light stinger HL which is bigger, didn't expect this proac to be so bright. It's just as bright, not noticeably brighter then the HL though. I really like the 10 click modes to choose your style. Very simple and effective. Quality is great as expected though a little rough and sharp, which means it scratches other surfaces very easy (automotive industry). I feel as though this light is maybe too bright for its own good. Because it is so bright, even light usage at high power mode gets the whole assembly hot and you end up feeling the heat in your pocket for minutes and minutes after just maybe 30 seconds of usage. It doesn't really burn you or anything but it's definitely noticeable. Also because it is so bright, the battery doesn't last very long. It's USB charged so you always have a chance to charge it. But it does take a while for a full charge. Great light, very bright, good build, just needs either to be dimmed down a bit, or a medium power mode, where low power isn't bright enough, and the full power seems to drain battery and heat up the light.

rank:

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Outstanding flashlight, incredibly bright and very compact.
reviews:
Best flashlight I've ever owned. Brighter than any Mag Light I've used and this thing fits in the palm of your hand. It's really amazingly bright, and the battery, though an odd size, does seem to last for quite a long time. I've got a "super spotlight" that isn't as bright as this little guy, and that spotlight runs out of battery power after literally 5 minutes or less.

Bonus: It's waterproof so when you drop it in a stream it's not dead.

Minus one star because it's pretty annoying that you can't program it to only do low and high beam, excluding the ridiculous "flashing" setting. Also you can't program it to start on low beam and then move up to high beam, it only starts on high and moves down. Most of the time low beam would be fine, and keep high beam in reserve for when you want that much power (and it is a significant difference). You can program it to be: High, Low, Flashing or High only, Low only. I set mine for high only. Sure, if you're an army ranger or in an actual survival situation the flashing thing might be handy but seriously... I bet 99% of these get used at home or in an office, flashy setting is not only unnecessary, it's flat out annoying.

But other than that minor (and it is minor) annoyance, this is a fantastic flashlight, especially at the price. I'll be replacing most/all my flashlights with these as the others die off, this thing is top quality, incredibly bright and you can drop it in your pocket or purse without even knowing it's there.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
This light is amazing to say the least. For it's size ad the amount of
light that it produces it is just a phenomenal flashlight. I own 4 other
streamlights and this one is the biggest that I have. It's still compact
enough to be able to pocket. but big enough that you know exactly
what it is.

The light functions are excellent on it's brightest setting the light does
have very good range and an exceptionally wide range. The only
problem with that is if you were in a combat setting or if you were in a
defensive situation if you shine the light onto a bright wall or setting
expect to to have the flashlight blind you in return. I also like the strobe
setting as well. It is a great disorienting pulse of light. If someone were
to have adjusted to their night vision if they were to be hit with the pulses
it would vastly blind them. With the most bright setting and the pulse
this flashlight can become a very good defensive tool. The lowest setting
is for normal illumination.

The body is well constructed and the design is excellent. It's angled in
certain spots so it cannot roll when staged on a flat surface. The tip of
the light is recessed to become an excellent impact weapon. The rear
button is easily accessible and has a very positive button. The ten-tap
feature is very good at adjusting the programs on the flashlight.

Great light overall, would recommend to anyone. I've had fenix, surefires
and I think this is the best balanced as far as cost, reliability, and performance.

review_title: Great Profile for EDC - Flexible Power Options
reviews:
So far I'm loving this light! I am evaluating this as a possible every day carry light. I like that I can use CR-123, Alkaline AA, Rechargeable AA, and Rechargeable 3.7V AA. The beam pattern is perfect for my use: It throws a tight enough beam to illuminate beyond 100M, but does not blind you when using it up close. I really appreciate the on/off tail cap button. I get annoyed with other manufacturer's lights that force you to click through all the optional settings to turn their lights off.

When I first received the unit, it would not power on using CR-123. I tried multiple batteries, and was about to return it, but a day later it started working. I cannot explain this anomaly and will keep testing to see if the issue pops up again. Otherwise I would have given 5 stars.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Very Nice Tactical Light With a Couple Gotchas
reviews:
This is a very well made tac light, very bright and compact. It uses a lithium battery which means it can sit around for years and still be ready when you need it. I like it, but there are a couple things to be aware of, especially for a tactical light, which means something that has to be 100% reliable and ready when you need it.

1) Hitting the mode you want is very tricky. You have to hit the switch just the right number of times (of course) and most tricky at just the right interval. The timing is VERY fast and it is different if you are going to use a particular mode temporarily (light press and hold button) or switching to that mode (press firmly and release staying on that mode). It takes practice, lots of it to hit the mode you want reliably.

2) When the battery runs out, there is absolutely NO WARNING. Either you will click it on and nothing happens or (most of the time) you will click it on and in a few seconds it goes dead. NOT a good situation for a tactical light. The only way this light can be absolutely ready for a critical situation is to put a new fresh $4 battery in it. Battery life isn't great, but that's the price for such a bright light running on a single CR123 battery. Just hope it is ready when you need it. A low battery indicator would be nice.

Still I gave it a soft 4 stars, maybe 3.5 would be more precise. It is a good light if you use it often enough to be good at hitting the right mode and if you have a fresh battery in it.

review_title: Like a lighthouse that fits in your pocket :)
reviews:
As I write this, I've only had my flashlight for two days but I want to give you my initial thoughts, in case they help. Then if something changes quality or usability wise, I will come back and provide an update.

So far, I think this light is the greatest bargain ever. It is replacing 6 not-cheap lights from Sam's that look GREAT but don't work due to broken switches. I suppose one could conclude that I am hard on flashlights, but I'm really not ... and I don't use them that often. So the not-cheap lights are very disappointing.

I spent more money on this Streamlight 88031 in hopes that it is the answer to my flashlight needs. If so, I'll be back to buy a few more -- I like to have multiple flashlights around my world.

Side note: I'll be judging this Streamlight 88031 against it's seemingly-indestructible little brother -- the Streamlight 73001 Nano Light Miniature Keychain light. That little light lives on my keychain so it gets a lot of abuse. And it still works 2 years later. So, this Streamlight 88031 has a big challenge to live up to the expectations its little brother has created for me about Streamlight quality.

Anyway, some quick notes about this Streamlight 88031:
1) The light is smaller that I expected. Apparently I lost track of size after looking at (what feels like) 5,000 different flashlights. So be sure to check the measurements before you order. For reference, this light is about the size of a dry erase marker. So, if you like a flashlight that is big enough that you could plunk a bad guy over the head ... this is NOT the light for you.
2) In retrospect, the size is perfect because it easily fits in my pocket. It would also be GREAT in a purse, briefcase, car, etc.
3) It's lightweight. It's heavier than a dry erase marker but not by much. I love that it's light enough to be in my nylon running pants without me hardly noticing. That certainly wasn't the case with my old crappy lights.
4) It's very bright! It's like having a lighthouse-bright light in my pocket. Sweet :)
5) The clip is fine. Works great if you like clips, and it's removable if you don't.
6) There is no lanyard clip. Not a big deal but I could see wearing this around my neck sometimes. I suppose I could tie a piece of paracord to the clip if I really wanted to (though I worry it might pop the clip off).

Bottom line: This Streamlight 88031 seems like a GREAT light. I'm very pleased so far. I will be back with an update if this doesn't last forever (unless it's my fault, of course :)

p.s. Update after 10 days ... As I said, this light is small but I love the fact that it fits in my pocket. It's a double-edged sword though because I have big hands which makes operating this light challenging at times since the light gets lost in my hand (my thumb slips off the back, etc.) I can completely conceal this light in my hand which means it isn't practical if I had to use it with a firearm. So, while I'm thrilled to have this light for pocket carry, for some things I need a flashlight that doesn't get lost in my hand. Just sharing the observation!

p.p.s. Update after 2 months ... I still really like this light. It's in my pocket nearly every night. I never want to be in the dark (or looking for things in dark places) without it. Also, this is a perfect sized light for your car or for a woman's purse (if you want to upgrade from the nano-sized keychain lights). Again, just sharing the observation.

review_title: Excellent value for a tactical light.
reviews: After using and owning many tactical lights (cheap and expensive), I have been very impressed with the value of all the streamlights I have purchased. The 88031 Protac is no exception. I have several lights that are programmable (allow varying changes in intensity and/or strobe features), but it got to the point where I was forgetting how to program the different lights. This light, on the other hand, allows me to toggle through three modes (High intensity, strobe, and low intensity) quickly by repeatedly pressing the tail switch. This feature has made this light my favorite EDC, especially when traveling because it is quickly versatile and I don't have to remember how to program it. This is the same reason why I really like the 1AA protac that I use around the house (cheaper to feed it batteries). It is not, however, my night stand light. I still use a 4sevens Quark123(2) that is programmable (I leave the settings on high output and with a quick twist of the head of the light it goes into strobe mode). The Quark would be better in an emergency home defense situation because of that feature. The Quark was also almost twice the cost when I bought it though. Bringing me back to this light, I am extremely pleased with how good/bright the beam is. It is not quite as bright as a Surefire E2D, but it costs about a third as much and has a strobe function. Also, this light is incredibly lightweight with a smaller head than most lights that have less features. For the money, I couldn't be happier. Not to mention, I won't cry as much if I lose/break it compared to a $100 plus tactical light.

reviews: Wow, what a quality product. I bought this to replace an Extreme Beam that just didn't live up to it's hyped expectations. I love this light. The only CON I can think of is it's inability to adjust the beam, so if thats a critical function look elsewhere. Otherwise, this should satisfy most users.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Perfect quality for the price - outstanding value & product
reviews:
I'd been looking to get a new flashlight for awhile and had heard a few recommendations for Streamlight but hadn't tried them personally. I'm a Surefire brand-stickler but am always willing to try something similar for less. While at a friend's house working on his car, he had a Streamlight, The Stinger, and I had a chance to use it for a few hours. I really liked the construction, light output and price. I was sold on owning one myself.

I spent a few days looking for the exact Streamlight I wanted, there are several models to choose from. I wanted something small, only a few inches in length, definitely hand-held rather than the almost full-size flashlight like my friend had. I wanted water resistance, and I wanted it to operate on CR123's, so I decided on this one.

When it arrives you get a belt clip which can be detached from the light, a "pouch" which holds the light and uses a velcro strap to attach to your belt. You also get basic instructions and a battery to start you off with. I'm still on the original battery and it's been a few months of every other day use. So far so good.

*** PERFECT FOR THE OUTDOORSMEN / ROUGH-USE / CAR-WORK / EVERY-DAY STUFF / SURVIVAL BAG

It comes ready to use once you get it, and for all of the reasons listed below it's truly a solid light to have. It's tough, shockproof, waterproof and easily carried. The diameter of the light allows you to easily attach it to firearms using the appropriate universal light mounts which you can obtain inexpensively.

*** GREAT BATTERY LIFE

Over 2.5 hours of solid use on High and more than 50 hours when set on low. This is really good, and the batteries which run the light are fairly inexpensive, especially if you purchase in bulk. Amazon has many solid deals for these batteries in bulk. Be aware that the light will warm up a little near the output end because of the LED. This is normal. It won't get hot it just gets warm, so don't fear that when it happens, especially after 30+ minutes. For the record, I'm still using the battery which came with the light and I've put at least 2 hours of High use on it and maybe half an hour of Low, and it's still working.

*** IT'S BRIGHT

The light output is outstanding, with brighter output than my Surefire x200 gunlight. This model states a light output of 180 lumens on high, which far exceeds my x200's rating of 110. You have two modes of brightness, high and low, and I find that for most jobs the low works great. Low isn't as bright as a cheap/average battery flaslight, but it's not dull, you can easily light up an entire room softly.

I've used the high mode to entirely light up small rooms in which the room lights were non functional. The rooms were all white on the walls and ceiling. I simply placed the light on a table facing the ceiling and turned it on high. The rooms, about 150sq/ft, lit up as if there was a 40watt bulb in the ceiling. I use a combination of both modes for various tasks including car work, house work, walking around the woods, etc.

It has a strobe mode which works on the High brightness level.

*** NO MAJOR BLIND SPOT

This light is neither a projecting light (fine focus for long distance lighting) nor a flood light, it's in between. Some lights which project long distances will give you a white blind spot if used in close quarters or on something near you. This won't do that, though if you use it close to something reflective such as a white wall, a good portion of the wall will be intensely lit-up. Outside at night you can see where you're going, but the bulk of the light won't be thrown for more than 50'.

This isn't a bad thing, most flashlights won't. It has enough flood to let you see where you're going, and enough throw to see far ahead of your footsteps. Other models of Streamlight will throw for long distances, if you're interested.

*** WATERPROOF

I needed something at least water resistant--I always buy things to last, and I'm going to use stuff in the rain it's simply inevitable. I also wanted to make sure that, like all flashlights I've owned before, I could drop this in water for awhile and not have an issue. It's rated for 30 minutes of submerged exposure at up to 1 meter (3.3'). I haven't tried it at that depth or for that long myself, though I've seen them underwater for longer at gun shows. I have used this light inside of a few aquariums up to a foot deep, and it performed perfectly.

*** SHOCKPROOF

Another thing on my must-have list. I've already dropped it several times from about 4', right onto concrete, and it continues to function flawlessly. There's a bit of a ding in the aluminum of course, to be expected.

*** 3-WAY SWITCH MIGHT TAKE A MINUTE TO GET USED TO

Once you realize how it works, it's super-easy. The switch allows you to use momentary force to turn the light on only as long as you hold the switch, and also allows you to switch the light "on" by pushing it all the way in like a normal light. Here's the easiest way to describe it:

1. Hold the light as you would, and begin slowly pushing the switch in until the light comes on. This is the momentary-on point. If you release, the light goes off.

2. If you continue to push until it clicks, it stays on. Click it off to turn the light off.

3. To switch between modes, try this: Push the button until you get the light to come on (not all the way until it clicks). Now quickly release enough pressure until it turns off, and then push it back on just until the light comes on. This should be your strobe mode. If you do this again you'll reach the 3rd mode which is Low.

To get any of these modes (High / Strobe / Low) to "stick", you just push all the way until it clicks on. Once you've practied a few times I guarantee you'll get the hang of it.

*** CLOSING THOUGHTS

The only thing which bugs me is knowing what the lense is made of. I can't tell if its glass or a high impact acrylic. My Surefire lights use glass, which won't scratch, and are unlikely to be broken. A high impact acrylic would be near impossible to break but could scratch. Again, I have no idea which this light uses. Either way this is still a solid light. For the price, especially if you're an Amazon Prime member, you get this thing in a day and it's ready to go out of the box. I used two of these recently during a hurricane and they were superb.

YOU WON'T BE DISAPPOINTED!

review_title: Should of bought this one in the first place.
reviews: First off I've noticed these reviews are for multiple different flashlights. I bought the 600 lumen ProTac HL. Great flashlight for its build quality and the programmable tailswitch. Nice to be able to turn in on first in the low setting then to the high setting if needed. This comes in handy when you need the light for a low light situation and you won't be temporarily blinded by the 600 lumen blast. A note on lumen counts. Lumens are NOT a measure of light intensity. Its a measure of total light thrown by a light. Example a lowly little 14 Watt CFL light bulb that I have as my nightstand light produces according to the label 1,250 lumens. Obviously if I shine this light on it on its high 600 lumen setting, the flashlight is staggeringly brighter. Other companies overinflate the lumen counts by adding a shallow reflector spreading the light out wider. The Candela (cd) rating is the closest to the light intensity rating you can get. At 16,000 cd this light is one of the brightest on the market. (There is a 15,000 "older" version of this light, but I got the new 16,000 version so you should get it too). Don't be afraid of the "special" CR123 batteries. True, they can be found at $20 a two pack in some major drugstores. But online they can be bought in bulk for less that $2 a battery. The big box retailer W Mart sells the other major "S" brand flashlight maker double packs for $4.97 too. You get what you pay for in the high power LED flashlight market. I bought a $50 800 lumen knockoff light from another website and was totally unimpressed by the quality and the complete ghetto way of loosening up the head of the flashlight to access the low power modes. You can find cheaper higher lumen lights, but they are crapola.

review_title: This light is nothing short of amazing. I purchased it because we were going out ...
reviews: This light is nothing short of amazing. I purchased it because we were going out of the country to a destination where crime had been on the rise and I wanted something that would be legal to travel with on the plane as well as the destination. I also wanted something that would deter/prevent an encounter rather than defend - and boy this was it. Long story short, we stayed in a rather large villa on a cliff overlooking the ocean. The nearest place to us was about 300 yards away up a hill. On the last day we started noticing that items were going missing and that night we came back to find a window opened that we knew we had secured. Thankfully there were many of us to go in two groups to search the villa to be sure no one was hiding. After we were sure there were no uninvited guests we began to unwind and, about two hours later, a person in our group went to their room upstairs to get something and when they came back down they happened upon two men with shirts wrapped around their heads going through a purse that was left out. That person screamed for help and the men ran out the door. We all ran upstairs and called the police. In two hours the police arrived (was pretty lax kind of place) and they looked around the house. I followed the one cop outside and he pulled out a flashlight to see if anyone was hiding in the shrubs/thick that surrounded the villa. It was a substandard light. As he was squinting to see only 50 ft away I pulled out my light and lit the entire area like a ballpark. Stunned, he turned around, looked at me then my light and, with an approving nod said, "nice light". We scanned the rest of the property and concluded the burglars were hiding on the one hillside and waited until we were all on the lower level before sneaking in. I don't know about anyone else, but I wasn't going to bed and three of us stayed up and talked until sunrise - and we scanned the property from a high vantage point in the villa every 10 minutes or so. Whoever was out there, wasn't about to come back and we felt much better with this kind of ability to light up the area at hand. I would strongly recommend this product to anyone who may be subjected to this scenario. On top of that it's just a great tool to have and the fun hasn't stopped there although this event was the time it was needed the most - and hopefully the last! Only problem I have had was when something in my backpack compressed the top of the holster where the actuating button was and kept it on in my bag. The heat from the light burned a home through the bottom of the holster, but caused no other damage - so be careful when storing - not because of the damaged holster, but because I would not have had a charge to use the light when needed had I not discovered the battery was fully discharged. GREAT PRODUCT!

reviews:
If you need a light for you cargo pocket, EMT kit, go-bag, lanyard, etc...then friend this is the light for you!

I got one, wasn't a fan of the cost given it was just a simple small flashlight, but boy was a pleased how well it worked! Enough so i've gotten 2 more since for dropping into my go-bag for deployments. And where I go there are always mountains of AA batteries, so this light is perfect for me, because i can always get my hands on AA with no issue, and with little/no cost.

I love the 3 "setting" of brightness, which are just a matter of bumping the button once, twice, or three times for low, med, high. But what i love is that 90% of the time i never need more than the low lumen setting to see in the dark, and keeping it mostly on low, I've been able to go months with heavy use on a single battery. But there have been times i needed the full lumen that this lil puppy packs and even then still gotten all the use I needed, i just changed the batteries (better safe than sorry) since they were abundant and free, but I've never had it die on me.

The lil pouch is nice, esp if you need to wear it on your EMT belt, i chose to dump it and use the clip and keep in in my cargo pocket like a knife. On water rescue missions i throw it on a lanyard on my PFD as a backup for spotting the shoreline.

bottom line: its pricey but i love it!

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
If you had to own one flashlight, this might be the one.

It isn't tiny, but it's very small. It comes with a clip so you could clip it to your pocket and although at first I thought this was a bit of a joke (I think it's way too big for anyone's pocket), it occurred to me that it might be handy to be able to clip it to the outside of your pocket for easy access. Admittedly it's more prone to getting knocked off this way, but it's just something to keep in mind. (It also comes with a belt holster if that's your thing.) If you WERE to knock it off, I suspect it would take the impact very well. It feels very solid in your hand and is made entirely of metal.

Of course the principal feature of the light is, well, the light. It's incredibly bright. It's no 2200-lumen Olight SR-90, but for its size, it's nearly impossible to beat. Its 640 lumens are more than enough for anything around the house, and still plenty adequate for most outdoor applications. True, if you're trying to locate someone lost in the ocean from a helicopter in the middle of the night, you might want something with a little more kick, but for 95+% of all tasks, I suspect this light will more than fit the bill.

My chief complaint might be unique to my particular unit, but to me, the clicking mechanism feels a bit cheap - certainly worse than Streamlight's smaller cousin, the ProTAC 2L. Perhaps it's just because the device is larger, but the this light requires a much deeper push on the tail switch to turn the light on. It's a little harder on the thumb and just makes the whole thing feel a little cheaper. In the grand scheme, not that big of a deal, but it's what keeps me from giving this light the five stars that so many others have.

Overall a terrific product. Streamlight is a trusted name in lighting and here they do not disappoint.

review_title: Mounted On My Mossy 590 A1 Blackwater
reviews:
Tried a cheaper light on my full-size Mossy(590A1 Blackwater) tactical shotgun. It didn't last the first trip to the range. Bought this as a replacement and fired 200 rds 00buck(2 3/2 & 3"), slug, a few breach rounds, with this light mounted...no problems. It took the recoil and barrel heat without any issues. Granted, it's a little long for a mounted firearm light. But on a full-sized weapon, the extra 2" or so matters little.
The strength and focus of the beam is fantastic, the strobe-mode easy to access with a quick dbl tap. Despite the length(approx. 7"), it's slim and worked just fine in my existing rail mount. Could have bought something smaller but firearms lights can get very pricey, on a full-sized shotgun a super-small light is irrelevant.
Good balance of price and durability, reliability (key in ANY situation where tools MUST work EVERY time)considering my own application.
The reliability of Streamlight, the durability, and the warranty that comes with, and the strength of this lights beam and distance are well worth the pricing. A bargain as far as I'm concerned

reviews:
this is my trusted sidekick at work. runs on cr123z and it makes them last. has three settings, cycled by multiple pushes of the switch. starts on bright, then strobe (only good for irritating ppl), then lower up close light. it does get a bit hot, but that is expected since it pushes 180 lumens. my only suggestion for improvement would be some sort of replaceable rubber sleeve for the inevitable tooth hold. but this would only put this light up to 6 stars. if you are hemming and hawing over this or a surefire, save your child's college fund and get this one.

update: i have since replaced this on my belt with its big brother, the protac HL. meaner and just as leaner, but with a larger head. the lowly 2L was relagated to the door pocket of the truck, where it has performed flawlessly on more occasions than i will admit. i just threw it in there without so much as a second thought and have had to use it for things such as spare tire changes, and checking the campsite for the truck keys so we could go home at the end of the camping trip. battery conservation is good too, all things considered. still a great light for the money, and unless you own any of the other higher output lights, this will make you happier than a puppy with two peters.

update 4/18/14: this has since made its way into my hunting pack. outside opinion would call that a downgrade. quite the contrary. i trust this light to come on after rain, snow, hail, dusty atv rides, 10 mile hikes, etc. it has not yet failed me. i carry 4sevens lights on my belt now, but this will always have a place somewhere in my flashlight stable. its only fault, as i mentioned above, is that there are brighter lights out there. if you are not a flashlight-o-phile then this light will do everything you need a flashlight to do.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: 260 lumens is easily enough for most applications you'd expect out of an ...
reviews:
No, it's not the brightest 2-cr123a flashlight on the market. No, it doesn't have some bizarre 36 mode UI that requires you to carry a cheat sheet to navigate. What the Protac 2L does, it does very well. 260 lumens is easily enough for most applications you'd expect out of an easily pocketable torch. The UI is simple with a handful of modes in each UI version that suit most styles of use. The controls are dead simple. The construction robust enough. The size is perfect for my hands and pocket. It is about the largest light I can comfortably carry inside my rear pants pocket clipped to the outside corner of said pocket. It's perfect size for Harri Technique for me as well.

But the biggest factor for me, personally, is that I've lost three of them so far. My job requires me to be outside in the field, climbing on equipment, getting down on the ground, going underneath equipment and structures, etc. This is not a friendly environment in the slightest if you're actively attached to your gear. I fell on one, catching the clip against a skid loader and rocketing the light and my wallet out of the pocket. Obviously I went for my wallet first. The light got eaten by the loader. The second was left underneath a car (I guess, because I don't remember), and the third got eaten by mud in a landfill when I dropped it. Wasn't going swimming to get it. Why is this mentioned as a feature? Because at under $40 I don't mind losing it. If I lost three Surefire E2E's, man, I would be PISSED. Heck, I probably would've at least driven my hand into that landfill mud to get a Surefire or some other spendier light back.

Yet even at the price point, the more expensive lights don't perform so vastly much better that I feel short-shifted because I can't feasibly carry the spendy light.

So if you want a torch you can brag about to your buddies, go down to the candlepower forum and geek out. They have all the goods on some really awesome stuff. But if you want a torch you can carry in the field, use the crap out of it, and not cry if you lose it, grab one of these. After trying out more torches than I can count, the ProTac 2L is the far-and-away class leader on value.

Oh, and having described my work environ just a bit, I've lost three of these but never broken one, nor had one fail on me. And that is after using these exclusively for about 4 years now (bought one when they first came out)
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
i have the streamlight protac 2L and i love it. i saw this one and i knew i had to have it to stun friends and amaze co-workers. it does both. waaaaaaaay bright without being waaaaay expensive. it's not fenix cheap, but it is reasonable for what you get. it is roughly the same diameter as the 2L except for the bezel, which is larger. takes two cr123's and the runtime is considerable, considering the light output. it has three modes that you can run thru...high, strobe, low...and they are just another push of the switch away. i like the simplicity, no moonlight mode, starlight mode or ultra-moon starlight mode. still not sure what the real purpose of the strobe is. if you really want to stop an attacker, why just give him a siezure? melt him with the high beam. my light would have been 5 stars, but it has an odd hiccup every so often. it switches modes on its own. both times it happened in extreme cold weather after it had been on for over 5 minutes. i will investigate further since i really do like this light and it beats 47 and surefire in the lumen/price column.

update: i have not had this light repeat the weird mode switch. possibly it was doing this due to low batteries? anyways, among my belt carry edc lights, this one is king. so i thought i'd better come back and give it its star back. foursevens quarks are pretty slick, but this one will hold its own.

update 1/12/2015: after a lot of use i think i have figured out the "problem" with the switch. the switch end will turn itself out ever-so-slightly...i mean, just enough to lose contact momentarily with the battery, which is what was switching modes or turning off, or sometimes not turning on. if it acts weird i just make sure the tail cap is twisted on firmly and away we go again.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Why didn't I buy this flashlight sooner?
reviews:
Some years back I asked my father for a Surefire rechargeable incandescent tactical light for Christmas that cost a few hundred dollars and I've regretted it ever since. The rechargeable battery wouldn't hold a charge long enough to be trusted in an emergency and the burn time was so short that it was useless as a utility light.

Finally I got up the emotional courage to buy a replacement light and the Streamlight ProTac HL is such an amazing light it makes me feel even WORSE about the Surefire. This light is everything a tactical flashlight should be: small enough and light enough to easily carry and use with one hand, blisteringly bright, and durable enough to get kicked around on the ground without any problems. For a flashlight that is only slightly longer than a man's fist is wide, I don't think there is a brighter commercially available product at this time. I also love the fact that it has various brightness levels so that you can also use the flashlight to navigate a dark room or read a map in the car without burning out your retinas. My only complaint is seemingly common to all LED lights with variable brightness. All brightness levels lower than full blast HIGH, are achieved by strobing the LED light "quickly" to reduce it's overall light output. While the light flashes faster than the "strobe" feature that is designed specifically to be dizzying, the flicker of the low level light is still quite annoying. I'm sure there must be some technical reason that the light manufacturers can't make the LED flash any faster because this seems to be a wide spread complaint. It really is quite annoying and I can appreciate the safety concerns voiced about using such a light to inspect moving equipment such as fans, belts, pulleys, etc as the strobing effect can make moving equipment appear to be stationary to be moving much slower than they are in reality.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
This is the best of the tactical flashlights that I have. Though small, it has a really powerful high beam light. That seems to be the default level of illumination. I use that beam often when I take my dog out for a pre-bedtime bio break in a large meadow beside our house. Sometimes after she relieves herself she decides to sniff all the exciting scents on the furthest side of the meadow (she's a Lab...all nose and mouth). Notwithstanding, I can easily follow her with the bright light, until she satisfies herself that she knows who and what has been there and joins me to go back into the house.

The only reason I did not give it five stars is that it's hard to activate the other levels of the light. There is also a low beam, and a strobe level. The lower level light extends the battery life by scores of hours and usually is just fine for walking, etc. But it's hard to activate. You have to lightly push the switch on the end of the flashlight partway down three times then hold it and push the button down until it clicks on. Similarly, to activate the strobe you push the button down lightly two times then hold and push it until it clicks on. It's not quite as easy as it sounds, but if you do it enough, you get the hang of its operation. The instructions were unclear (to me) and I felt pretty frustrated when I could not get it to operate properly.

I thought something was wrong with the light and called the company. They referred me immediately to a very cooperative technician who gave me much better instructions but said if I couldn't get it to work, send it back and they'd send me another one. They were very nice at all levels. So now that I've figured it out, I'm thrilled and considering buying another (a $40 flashlight is still pricey in my world) to keep with my outdoor gear.

review_title: This will be my favorite light for many years to come.
reviews:
I've had this light for a little over 2 years now and I haven't been gentle on it. Its been dropped, and smashed and it shows little to no wear at all. While the battery isn't so common to find, I have to replace the batteries maybe twice a year (I use the light mainly on low.) The high is definitely effective when you need light fast and bright and low is more than enough (but not too much) for everyday use. The strobe is quick and very bright and the half push switching system makes finding the mode you want very quick. This will be my favorite light for a long, long time, I've tried to find a light the same size that could beat it but I simply can't. I usually carry this using the pocket clip (which is better even some of the pocket clips on the much more expensive lights) and it never slips off, even while running or moving up stairs. For me, this light is the perfect size and thickness for nearly every task, and it goes everywhere with me. Its lasted a long time through hard use and there's no sign of it breaking anytime soon.

Edit: It's now 2016 and this light is still my go to light. I've smashed it, submerged it and treated it harshly in every manor possible, it's been with me in 30 degree whether as well as 110 degree whether, even after as much abuse as it has been through, still not a single issue with it. The light has never failed me no matter what conditions I'm in, it's survived many hard drops and still almost no damage to the light. The paint is in fair condition, it's high quality to go through all that and still have only minor scratches. Pocket clip retention is still as good as it was the first year I got it (pocket clip tends to wedge itself up against the ridge above where it sits, really helps to get even more retention.) Clicky button on the back is still good, hasn't even begun to wear out. One of the best purchases I've ever made, this light will probably last me a lifetime.

review_title: I like it, overall, but two small complaints...
reviews: Very nice....very bright...very handy...and pretty darned sturdy. However, the push-button light switch on the end of the light is not recessed enough, so when you're wearing the light in its nylon case on your belt, the button can accidentally get pushed and the light turned on. This happened to me last week, and because I was unaware the light was on, the metal casing actually heated up so much that it actually burned my skin through my pant waistband. The metal casing was extremely hot -- so much so it was hard to grab and take out of its nylon case so I could turn it off and set it on top of a cabinet to cool off. That's only happened once. And to be perfectly honest I do still carry the light every day as part of my every day carry. But the manufacturer really needs to look into the excessive heat this thing generates if you accidentally leave it on. And also the push button on the end of the light should be better recessed, so it can't as easily be accidentally turned on while you're wearing it. For the price, I shouldn't have to be checking it for or five times a day to make sure the light's not on.

reviews: My husband is a Police Officer and bought this flashlight for work. It is VERY bright and can be charged using USB. His partner at work owns this and he really liked it so we went to the Police Uniform Gear store to buy it but while in the store my husband decided to go onto Amazon to see if he could find it a little cheaper.
