reviews:
This review should really be for "4.5 stars" but that option was not available. I knew of the single shortcoming of this product before buying it, because I had read other Amazon reviews and seen this item in a walk-in (police equipment) store.

First of all, it's a little powerhouse (600 lumens: WOW!) And, it's manufactured by Streamlight, a Pennsylvania outfit with lots of "cred."

Also, the Amazon price was exceptional: I got it for fifteen bucks less than the price in that store -- sufficient difference for me to not patronize a local businessman. (I had resolved in my mind only to buy it here only if the price difference were $10.00 or greater.)

Finally, the down-side: as another Amazon reviewer mentioned, the bulbous head prevents easily slipping this in or out of a pocket with the reflector and lens pointed down, and the clip is pointing in the wrong direction if you want to hang the light facing upwards to compensate. (He was incorrect in his suggestion that the pocket clip should be turned around and attached at the opposite end -- there is not enough room on the barrel of the flashlight near the head to accommodate this adjustment.)

So all in all, a solid bargain and an impressive little piece of technology -- but the Streamlight folks need to widen the flat spot on the barrel near the head so the clip can be flipped.

reviews: I was recently outside with the family grilling hotdogs in the fire pit. I snatched out my Streamlight Protac 1L to inspect my daughters hot dog and it slipped from my hand flying into the fire pit. Oh no! I could see the flashlight laying in the red hot coals and knew it would be shot, but frantically tried to recover it with the hot dog forks. After what seemed like forever, I recovered the light from the pit and quickly poured a beer on it. It sizzled and cooled enough for me to grab it. I pressed the intact rubber button cover on the back that I expected would be melted. It was not and the flashlight lit up bright as it always does! What? It really worked! How crazy? It has since lost the ability to stay on, but the light still works when the button is held. I had expected a total loss, so I was more than amazed with the results. Attached are the pics after the fire. I washed it off and it still looks like new! Amazing quaity!

reviews:
[Update 2016] I lost my old flashlight, but liked it so much that I bought another. The new light is brighter and the beam is not as concentrated. This turns out to be better for use within your house or a building. Everything else is just as good as my original flashlight.

A week or so after I received the new flashlight I found my old one in the yard. It had spent a month in a Wisconsin winter that saw 40 degree temperature swings, snow, rain, and sun. It worked perfectly and there was no damage anywhere - inside or out. Just reaffirmed to me how good these things are!

[Original Review 2014] I've had this flashlight for a year now, carry it with me daily, and use it on a regular basis. The Streamlight Protac 2L is bright, durable, and set-up right.

The button on the end cap can be used for momentary on, or pressed harder for continuous on. It starts out bright, then strobe, and then low - which is perfect for more tactical use. The batteries are long lasting (I've only changed my once in this past year) - which is something I really like about this CR123A version of the Protac.

I'm sure that this flashlight will last many more years, and I'm completely happy that I chose it.

review_title: With great brightness comes great responsibility though
reviews: This is one bright flashlight, in fact it is actually too bright for what I needed it for the most. If you want a compact light that can put out a reasonable distance of light then this is the light for you. Just to show it off to my friends I had them turn out the lights in their living room and I shined the light on the ceiling... it illuminated the whole room clearly enough you didn't need another light source. With great brightness comes great responsibility though... If you are wanting to read with this light, even the low power setting is really hard to look at a white piece of paper with. So much light reflects back it was actually hurting my eyes. Also, the only other notable problem I had with mine is that after awhile of use it does get pretty hot... which isn't surprising considering the lumens it puts out. The clip has failed me a few times, but I don't knock the flashlight for that, it's just something to watch out for and not really count on if you are putting it outside a pocket.

Please believe me, the high end Flashlight/Lighting Products world has truly come far in technical advancements over the past decade, and there are "many" players out there stating "they are the best and have the best pricing", etc.

reviews: OK I admit it. I am a flashlight nut, always looking for the optimum lighting solution. When I labeled all my boxes and put them in alphabetical order I discovered I have 3 boxes of flashlights. If you think you might need a club, carry a D cell mag light. For hands free, my Streamlight Septor with 3 AAA's is my go to head lamp. I have been looking for the optimal "carry" light for any pocket, or for my cool 5.11 tactical pants. Lithium batteries provide energy density that alkaline batteries can't match which means more lumens that last longer so I wanted a twin that was small in diameter and short enough to fit anywhere. Next the ten tap programming is the icing on the cake that completes this package. I have three different models of this "ten tap" light. One is too big. One is to small (1 battery). I have them all programmed the same. The third program setting is #1) one click for "on-low" which is usually enough and good for 50 hours. Next #2) two quick clicks for "on-high" which is easy to function if I need it, which I rarely do. For my applications it is not a battery hog. All around, this combination of size, performance, simple multiple functions means buy this light first, then everything else would be "why?"

review_title: Could be the perfect flashlight of its kind???
reviews: I am very happy with the Protac 2L and will cover my pros and cons of this light herein however I should begin this review by saying that I am flashlight brand agnostic and own many lights including Surefires, Petzl's, Pelican's, Streamlights and Underwater Kinetics. Each of these lights have their own purpose. It is obviously not useful to compare a dive light to a headlight meant for camping. A reasonable point of comparison emerges between the surefire and streamlights especially the "tactical" lights. What I express here is only my opinion but I have to say that while I own 5 or so Surefire's they tend to be overly heavy and two of them have had failures shortly after purchasing them. My executive light's tailcap switch failed and my AR weapon light's momentary contact switch also failed. These lights are premium priced and for that premium I would expect outstanding quality. But of course this is a review of the streamlight Protac 2L and in contrast I have experienced no failures with this light. It's three modes work incredibly intuitively. The bright setting maximizes the output of the C4 LED. Strobe mode is easy to activate and it is very disorienting as it is intended to be. My favorite mode though is the low mode. It is great to have a light that can put out such a blinding beam also produce a low mode that is useful and yet greatly extends battery life. The crenelated ends are sharp but non-intrusive. In a tactical situation they would come in handy. My only complaint is that the body is very smooth and sometimes when you try to lock the tailcap switch the smooth aluminum slides through your fingers. I also like how light, thin and short this flashlight is. It carries in one's pocket very easily without a lot of added weight or bulk. The holster that comes with the light is actually is serviceable. I think it would work for daily carry. Overall, I can't recommend this light highly enough. I just ordered two more and look forward to traveling with them and putting them into service on a daily basis. The only person I can imagine not rating this light number one is someone going into actual combat who might want something that was heavier but given my poor experiences with Surefires, I am not sure what I would recommend. If you buy this light I would be very surprised if you have anything but a great experience.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

reviews:
I don't usually add my $.02 to a product when many others have already spoken so overwhelmingly in favor of it. But in this case, the item I received deserves a special mention because Streamlight has improved the product, although it now costs a few dollars more.

Many, many reviewers cite their biggest (often only) issue being an inability to modify the program of selections that are available by tapping the button. With the current product release Streamlight has addressed this issue by adding their "Ten-Tap" programming to this flashlight.

The unit ships with the high-strobe-low program set as the default. This used to be the only program the unit had. Now it can also be programmed to have high-beam only or low-high selectable in addition to the standard program. For my use the low-high program is perfect and made this flashlight a slam-dunk for my daily carry.

An additional change is that the high beam is now 180 lumens rather than 110. Low beam is still 12 lumens, which I believe is unchanged. Battery life is 2 hours on high and 24 hours on low but I do not know if these values are different from earlier versions of this flashlight.

Recommended!

review_title: This is the best light I have ever owned by far.
reviews:
When I was in law enforcement, I carried various brands of lights and always found Streamlight to be the most durable and well designed lights on the market. The PT2L is no exception. This is by far the best flashlight I have ever owned. I purchased this light several months ago when my Surefire G2 turned out to be a piece of junk (and Surefire's customer service declined to respond to my repeated attempts to contact customer service). The Streamlight PT2L turned out to be a great surprise.

First, this light is very compact and well-built. The light will easily fit in your pocket and is lightweight. The clip is sturdy as well. For added versatility, I added a neck lanyard that I attached to the clip. Second, this light is BRIGHT! Compare it to lights that are much larger and more expensive, and you'll find that the PT2L is brighter than most. It blows my Streamlight Stinger out of the water in the amount of light it puts out. The light is a clean white light as well. Third, it has a low power setting when you don't need as much light or need to extend the life of the batteries as long as possible. It also has the strobe feature, which is nice to have, but not something most people will ever actually need. Fourth, the light comes with a set of CR123A lithium batteries that are reasonably priced, easy to find, and have a very long 10 year shelf life.

The only down side to this light is that it does get pretty darn warm if you need to run it for a long time, but that is the payoff for getting the bright light since I understand that the aluminum body is used to draw heat from the lamp to allow for the brighter light capability.

In short, for the money you simply can't get a better light.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

review_title: Streamlight 88031 Protac Tactical Flashlight 2L with White LED I
reviews:
I'm not "flashlight manic" or an expert so I can only say that this "tactical" flashlight appears to do what it's supposed to do in "tactical" situations. It projects a strong beam of light - it's shape & size makes it easy to carry and use to blind/ ward off aggressors (at least long enough to take further defensive action - the whole point of such flashlights).

Compared to one larger multi-LED flashlight, this flashlight produces MUCH more light and even reflecting the beam in a mirror can "blind" at short ranges.
Not sure what the battery life will be - have to wait and see (and not keep "trying it out" as I was at first). It's the only device I have which uses CR123 batteries, so I'll have to look around for local battery sources before passing judgement on that part.

Got my first one a couple weeks ago - then got 2 more from Amazon for Xmas gifts (daughter & her husband). One of those two wouldn't work no matter what I tried. It'll be going back to Amazon pronto - customer service says they're shipping a replacement right away.
Thanks for that - I gave my own to daughter so she'd have one to take back home (and to work- she's a grade school teacher).

Worth the cost? WEll - if it can save a life, it's worth it. I've seen other places advertize the exact same flashlight for $75 - so it wins price comparison-wise.
Yes - I'd recommend this light to others.

review_title: great tac light... not so great clip
reviews:
I would have given this a 5 star except for the fact the clip is poorly designed and breaks away much too easily.
if the lip of your pocket is a bit thick (think Kuhl heavy duty pants) it is impossible to clip the light without the clip popping off. Eventually I noticed that the clip was gone but thankfully the light was still in my pocket.

As for the light... top notch light. Seems to hold up very well in my pocket next to a Krenshaw knife. The black coating does scratch off a bit on the easy side but I don't care about looks... i want the light to work every time I need it. I don't leave home without it. Battery life seems decent. I don't usually use the highest setting as it tends to be too bright (but it does come in handy when I need a lot of light.) I have had mine for a while and haven't changed the batteries yet.

Just a note, on the brightest setting, the body will warm up over time. I accidentally switched on the light while it was rolling around in my pocket (since I lost the clip) and it got pretty hot... not burning hot but hot enough to make you notice.

Bottom line, if you need a high lumen tac light that is inexpensive compared to a surelight, etc, this is a great buy.

reviews:
I purchased this to install inside of a Elzetta Tactical Shotgun Flashlight Mount for use on my Winchester 1300 Defender, which it fits great inside of. I haven't had the light on for very long, so I'm not sure if the bulb gets darker after it's been on for a long time. However, at least right now the light is crazy-stupid bright. I have never purchased a flashlight this expensive before and have never had a true tactical light, but it seems like for the price it is well worth the money.

I didn't quite understand how to change into different modes at first. The way you switch modes is by lightly depressing the cap switch "on" button 2x or 3x depending on which mode you want. So you don't click it all the way down so it locks on, but just barely depress it until the light switches on, then quickly release the pressure and push down lightly again. This puts it into a strobe-light mode. I'm assuming that mode is to disorient the assailant, but frankly it was disorienting to me as well. I don't know. Kind of cool. Never seen that feature before but I guess it makes sense.

Long story short: this light is great. Well worth it. I've never owned a Surefire so I don't know how it would stack up. But it's definitely way better than your average flashlight. The only downside is that it uses those CR123 batteries which aren't always readily available. I would prefer something that uses AA's and that I always have on-hand.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
This is a great light. It is competitively priced and is a nice size for pocket carry in men's jeans. I wear a slimmer cut pants (not skinny jeans lol) and there is no noticeable bulge in my pocket. The unboxing experience was plesant. Packaging was about standard, and was well put together. The light came with 1 CR123A (more about this later), 1 AA, the light (duh?), a pouch, and a wrist strap. I pocket carry this light only so I haven't used the pouch yet but it could be useful for storing things in and seems to be of good quality.

Pros:
Quite bright, with a nice balance between distance and width. The light can easily reach 200 ft or so while having a wide enough beam to provide good peripheral visibility.
Durable (so far). I have already dropped it several times on concrete and other than a few scratches it works like a champ, although I expected this.
The hat clip feature is useful. It is worth noting that the part of the clip contacting the bill of the hat is rounded over so it won't damage the front edge of the hat. Nice touch!
The pocket clip is nice and sturdy, and I haven't had any issues with it sliding around or falling out throughout the day.
The feature to be able to use AA batteries is awesome. I prefer to use a CR123A in order to achieve the full brightness, however it is very nice to have the option should I not have any CR123As on hand or if I don't feel like wasting the more expensive battery on a less demanding task. I imagine this feature would be very nice while camping or doing other things as AAs are far more prevalent and cheaper than CR123As.
The tail switch is extremely easy to actuate while not turning on in my pocket easily. Strobe is also very easy to actuate (double tap).
The end of the flashlight, near the bezel, is flattened on several sides so the light won't easily roll around. This is a nice detail.
The lens and the glass (I believe it is acrylic of some sort) is recessed which is nice as it won't scratch or become damaged as easily.

Cons:
I would have liked for the pocket clip to carry a little further down in my pockets, as almost the entire screw on tail-cap portion sticks out. Although as long as you don't care about it being super concealed (it is just a flashlight after all) I can usually just tuck my shirt over it and it isn't much of an issue.
I wish there was a way to possibly program the light to go High > Low > Strobe by single, double, and triple tapping. Currently, it is setup as High > Strobe > Low, and I find that I have to press it up against my clothing while actuating because the strobe function will turn on momentarily while switching to low which is quite blinding, especially when you need a lower amount of lumens to begin with.
Not really a con, but the battery that came with the flashlight died very quickly, within the span of 1 week with not much use. However, I ordered a pack of 2 CR123As with the flashlight and the battery life of those are much improved. I have had the same battery in for about a month now with with moderate use and have had almost no visible reduction in lumens.

Both of these cons are more nitpicks than anything. I very much enjoy this light, and can't wait to see how it holds up over time.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
I do not believe in writing a review until a few months after using the product. With that said, I have now used it for awhile, and I am in love with it. At the time I bought this unit, I was debating on buying this Streamlight PT2L or a SureFire E2D LED (March 2010). I love SureFire as much as the next guy, but at the end of the day, it came down 'more' to the overall function of what I needed in a light and not the price that drove me to buy the PT2L over the E2D LED.

The E2D LED offers 200 lumens and a strike head bezel. Th 200 lumens is actually an upgrade from the prior E2D LED which was only 120 lumens. I am sure at some point, SureFire will upgrade the lumens even further. The strike head bezel on the E2D LED is the best one on the market. SureFire really made it so that it can be used for tactical purpose. Other manufactures offer "copy-cat" designs, but their bezels are made of a pathetic plastic that is more for "show" and not built to go. The E2D LED has two outputs: high and low. The material used in the E2D LED like all other SureFire product is exceptional and will withstand abuse. So why did I go with the Streamlight?

The Streamlight PT2L offers 180 lumens (20 less than the SureFire E2D LED). However, the PT2L offers 3 outputs: high, strobe, and low (in that order). The stike head bezel is nice on the E2D LED and it's great for tactical purpose, but it's hard and sharp, so it can scratch other things you might have in your pocket. Also, since I almost, always have my trustworthy Spyderco Stretch with the ZDP189 steel, there's no need for a strike head bezel. The PT2L is also noticeably more compact and lighter. Both the PT2L and E2D LED are waterproof.

Finally as far as cost, which was not the issue for me. I always believe in paying more if I am going to really get more for my money. I purchased the PT2L from Amazon for $42.90. At the time, the SureFire E2D LED was selling for $140 (normally $165). For the price of the E2D LED, I could have bought 3 (or 4) of the PT2L and put one in my car, backpack, and offer the other one to my significant other or family member. I am sure if SureFire bulked up the lumens to 220+ and offers an additional strobe output, I will be the first one all over it. But until then, my PT2L is great.

Also, I forgot to mention, prior to 'needing' to buy a flashlight, I purchased the Streamlight TLR-1s weapon light. Since I cannot carry a weapon light around as an everyday-carry flashlight, I wanted something similar to the quality of my TLR-1s, which I really love. The PT2L was the purfect compliment. Both have similar outputs and lumens: the PT2L has 20 more lumens than the TLR-1s, but the TLR-1s has a stronger center of focus (or so it appears). I hope this helps.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
This ProTac is not the smallest, or most feature-filled, or most efficient on the market today. That being said, it has performed reliably for me for almost 2 years now and my mother liked it so much that I ended up getting her one as well recently.

This flashlight is durable, powerful, feels great in the hand, and is a great balance between size and power. The throw from the light is a very bright white (no one would describe it as "warm") and its reach is exceptional. I often have to go onto unknown properties at night and this has never let me down.

After almost 2 years of use mine has shown minimal wear, just some marks on the outer case. I have dropped it and gotten it wet and this has not affected its functionality.

The only things I am not in love with are the sheath (I had a leather one made; the nylon one is usable but not my cup of tea) and the fact that it ONLY take CR123A batteries; you cannot put an 18650 in this flashlight like you can on many that have been made since this time. The run-time on a set of batteries is acceptable, but really enhanced by the low feature which is useful in most applications.

I would recommend this to anyone looking for an every-day-carry flashlight that takes non-standard batteries and has normal requirements.

reviews:
-1 star for significant heat production
-1 star for questionable LED protector (front)
-1 star for strobe being second click instead of third

One thing that surprised me was how small this light is. You don't get a fair sense of its size from the stock photos. But it's the perfect size for me so no complaints there.
This light has a powerful beam and great throw. It is so bright on high that I suspect the battery life on that setting would not be good at all.

24 MAR 2013 UPDATE:
After further testing, I have decided that I cannot keep this light. On the high setting, it produces excessive amounts of heat, even a couple inches away from the LED area. The amount of heat is inordinate, and bordering on dangerous. I can see someone getting skin burns from it if used on high for any more than 5 minutes. It doesn't have to be on for long at all before it becomes very hot. Seeing as how I intended to use this light on high for more than a few minutes at a time, it has become a non-option. Too bad, because in the rest of its form and function I am rather pleased with it.

reviews:
This is our second Streamlight 2L. Obviously that's an indication of how much I like this flashlight. I carry one and keep the other one bedside. We have critters in our backyard and this flashlight allows me to "shine" them. If I want to scare them away, I just double push and activate the strobe option. It startles them and then sends them on their way. The lower lumen feature makes this flashlight a great light for almost anything without using up the batteries.

I've had my first 2L for six months and the batteries are as fresh as when I bought it. Good long life - and I use the light daily.

The triple push button makes this flashlight a bit tricky to get used to. I still don't always get it right the first time. 1 click - brightest. 2 light clicks and push - strobe. 3 light clicks and push - low light (average flashlight).

The 180 lumens (as advertised) is plenty bright for me, and the low lumen is perfect for long-term flashlight needs.

I have purchased countless little flashlights - espec. the little 9 LED, 3 AAA battery ones - and kept them around the house. My 2L replaces them all. The 2L is reliable, easily useable and easy to carry wherever and whenever.

Buy this, and it's all that you'll need. OR - buy two right away. This is one of the best priced flashlights in this catagory of LED lights. My son's in-laws have a $125 flashlight that is no better than this one. I tried 5 other flashlights at a local sports store and ended up buying this one - twice.

reviews:
Prior to writing this review, I was contemplating whether it deserved a 4-star or a 5-star report. The reason for my dilemma was the switch on it keeps getting bumped on during the regular hustle and bustle of my duties. I finally determined that this problem was due more to my poor choice of a location for mounting it than a defect or design flaw. Therefore it would be wholly unfair to bestow a 4-star review on such a little "firecracker" of a flashlight. Be very careful as to the location you chose to mount it, if you mount it on your person, the flashlight gets very hot if the switch is inadvertently bumped on. How they manage to squeeze so much power out of a single CR123A battery is still a mystery to me. I didn't like the fact that it isn't a pinpoint spotlight, but after I had gotten used to its intensity over the larger area, I stopped caring completely. Having 3 different modes on one flashlight has proven very useful as the strobe mode is great for catching the attention of people in an area; the low-intensity mode is good for tactical/administrative; the high intensity, no surprises. I like my larger flashlights for most situations, but I don't always like to carry it around so this is definitely my favorite substitute or backup. It appears to be very well built - feels very solid. It is very small in relative comparison to all my previous portable flashlights - you could just easily loose it somewhere in your TDUs/BDUs. I intentionally lost the holster that was included - a holster for a flashlight that is this small, seriously? If you really wanted to, you could just toss it in your front pocket like a pocket knife. Unless you are prone to easily losing things, I would recommend it to anyone looking for a much smaller flashlight.

Update: 4 years later, a lot of scars from heavy use and it still works like a champ. I'm rarily found without it.

THE CR123A will give the light its max lumens, though the light from the AA is plenty bright. What the manufacturer doesn't tell you is that you can also use a AAA battery in it. It is good to have that flexibility when you need it in an emergency as it ups your chances at finding a battery to keep using it. The only things I don't care for are: the light starts in high mode, the tailcap switch is a bit stiff (though not terribly), and switching it between modes can take getting used to.

reviews: I owned my first Streamlight PT 2L for about 18 months and was quite happy with it. I primarily keep it in my house though occasionally wore it on my belt. It is quite bright. Switch can be a bit awkward at times to figure out...once for brightest light; twice for flashing; 3 times for dim light. After 18 months, I bought a second one to carry with me and put my Streamlight in my car. After nearly 1 year, my new light quit working. I swapped out the batteries with no change. I then swapped out the switch with my old light and WAS able to get the new light working. I wonder if the extreme humidity in a recent Houston trip caused the problem. After waiting a day in lower humidity (St. Louis), playing around with new batteries, and swapping switched (end caps), I was finally able to get the old light to work with its original batteries and switch. So...all is well again but my confidence in the light working on demand is greatly diminished. If this was an anomaly, I will remain quite happy with this light. If this ever happens again, I will try another vendor since I want reliability.

review_title: Super bright if you keep the batteries fresh
reviews:
Firstly I bought this light because I saw a Navy Seal recommend a tactical flashlight for personal defense. This light is bright enough to blind someone temporarily (well, technically it could blind someone permanently if left shining in their eyes long enough) and it fits in your pocket, although it's a good size. If someone attacks you, you can strike someone with either edge of this solid flashlight and do some major damage (it has metal ridges on either end and I wouldn't want to be on the receiving end of a blow to the head with one of these).

In my opinion this is a better choice than another top brand because this has 100 extra lumens (total 600), it is actually programmable (for example if you want strobe to come up first), and it's even cheaper.

Minus one star because I don't feel it stayed at 600 lumens for long enough (however, I may have received poor batteries with it). I have replaced the batteries with fresh ones (and BAM it's back to lethal-seeming brightness) and I will update the review after using the light if my opinion changes on this point.

At the end of the day, this light will illuminate an entire street (we're talking all the way down a long street) or nearly blow some burglar away with light. I already bought another one for a gift.

reviews:
I have had this flashlight for a few weeks and have loved it. It is very bright, even at considerable distances. I have been able to light up the structure of a bridge (I use it for construction inspection) from a good 30 yards away at night. I don't use the strobe function but it's fun to play with sometimes. With this light in a confined space, the high setting can be too bright so the low setting is very nice to have. Cycling through the modes was fairly intuitive and I was pretty proficient with it after about 5 minutes. It is light, so far has been durable (my 3 y/o nephew wasn't able to damage it even when throwing it around) and a good size to keep in my pocket or on my belt.

The only reason I gave it 4 stars is because, as others have said, it does get warm after a minute or two on the high setting. So far I've only had to use it for that long on the high setting once, and even then it wasn't uncomfortable to hold. I really like this flashlight and am considering buying another as a backup (that doesn't mean I don't have faith in this one but... two is one, one is none).

Update 6 Dec 2012:
After a few days of not being able to find this light, I thought I had lost it and immediately ordered another. The next day I found it. I'm not at all disappointed though because this is a great deal on a great light. Now I have a backup in case I really do lose this one.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
When it comes to tactical technology, you can pretty much produce anything and tack the word "tactical" to it and most people will buy it. It's a given that the quality tactical items usually come with a hefty price tag. Tactical flashlights are no exception. There are options running in the price range of hundreds of dollars. My quest was to find an alternative to the high priced tactical lights that would take the abuse that I could put it through and continue to survive. Out of the many I examined and used first hand, this Streamlight Protac made the cut. Right out of the package this light felt lightweight yet rigid and sturdy. The extended shell over the switch and lens looks rugged enough to actually use in an emergency situation as suggested by most of the more expensive tactical lights with the same design.
The most noticeable feature of this tactical light is the amount of light the white LED element produces. It's rated at 180 lumen and this is by no means an exaggeration. I've compared it side by side with another tactical light that was about the same price but utilized a zenon bulb and was rated at just over 90 lumen. There was no comparison. The Streamlight literally washed out the light from the other tactical light. I've even compared it to another LED tactical light that was rated at 140 lumen but cost almost twice as much as the Streamlight and it was bright but the Protac was considerably brighter and had a much wider flood.
There are three settings available for this light; one click for full on illumination, two quick clicks for strobe, and three quick clicks for 10 lumen illumination for battery saver mode when only needing a tiny bit of light. The strobe could be useful in a defensive situation if you can make it work. It takes me a few different attempts to get the light to drop into this mode. The 10 lumen illumination made more sense to me for times when I'm camping and only need a small amount of light to show me the way. Battery life seems to be outstanding as I have yet to replace the batteries and the light has been with me on several trips with average usage.
Overall I've used this light for a wide variety of uses and for the money, it's a very good purchase. You don't spend a fortune and you still get a very bright and durable tactical light.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

reviews: I love this light I am an hvac mechanic a hiking/camper and an offshore fisherman and this light does it all from spot buoys and marker flags at distance to turning the creepy bear and coyote filled darkness into nothing more than mere well lit woods. apart from the fact that it does strobe on low, spinning parts appear to stand still or run backwards one could make the mistake that the machine is not running but if your sticking your hands into spinning things without double checking first you don't deserve to have fingers. this light is a darkness buster. the battery life is fair if you use it on constant high its going to die quick. I change my batteries about every two weeks with normal work use camping and fishing is a different story. Just an update I have now had this light for 6 years and it is the best light I have ever owned hands down. About a year ago the lens cracked and I feared the worst till I contacted streamlight and they where more than happy to ship a new lens cap an no cost. They actually stand behind they‚Äôre products. Great light great company won‚Äôt bother buying any other light.

review_title: Only thing that would make this 5 star is a lower cost
reviews:
This is a very durable tactical penlight. Bright, intense high beam, low beam, and strobe. Like most pen lights the on/off button is on the end, making it easy to turn on with your thumb. It takes a little practice to get the various modes to easily turn on. Push once for bright beam, push twice (quickly) for the strobe (and don't look at it - it actually flashes so fast I'm sure you could probably get seizures! (o.k., I'm only partly joking about that). And push 3 times to get the light to go to the low beam. The package has the battery life spelled out for each mode - obviously continuous high beam will burn your battery within several hours.

The end near the light is shaped so that your penlight won't roll away on a flat surface - one of the reason's I chose this model. I have this for my EDC.

I wanted a good quality, small, durable flashlight, so I expected to pay a little more. However, I do think that $28 dollars is quite 'out there' on price. I would see this being more reasonable at about $19. Thus the reason for the 4 stars.

review_title: VERY BRIGHT, strobe effect is perfectly disorienting
reviews:
This is the brightest hand sized tactical flashlight I've ever seen. It is expensive, but is well worth it.
This is a great tool for home security/inspection, as it blindly lights up any room. As a strobe effect, it will easily disorient any intruder in your home. It's so bright that looking at the light on the floor is enough to cause slight temporary blindness in your own eyes.
In lower power mode, its still very bright, probably as good as any normal flashlight, but obviously using much less power.
The only downside is that I've had to replace the batteries sooner than I expected. I don't have an idea of lifetime, but I'd say that if you left it on full power for about 90 minutes it would probably drain the batteries. The batteries are expensive (123A).
Overall, I am very happy with it, and I just use it when needed, not for play.

reviews:
Streamlight Protac HL 3:
This Tac Light, is awesome. It is not cheap by any means compared to some other ‚Äúhigh lumen‚Äù lights, but you get a solid, hefty well built flashlight. I trust Streamlight since I own 4 of the Protac 2L's that are really good and reliable considering their size, but this light far outshines the 2L in beam length and has a much wider usable beam coverage area. I initially was going to get the HL but I am glad that I decided on this HL 3. I wanted something a whole lot brighter with more coverage area. Well, this is it. Although the HL 3 costs twice the price of a 2L, you get 4 times the performance.
I conducted a heat test with New batteries. After 7 minutes on High the temp at the hot spot was 99.5 degrees F. I doubt I will ever need it on High for that long, since once you acquire your target at a distance, you can either switch it off or go to Low. I don't see heat as a problem at all.
The Strobe feature may be a good self defense alternative to my 357 S&W although I have not found willing test subject.

review_title: Exceptional Performance for Size, Weight, and Price
reviews:
After a good deal of research I ordered this flashlight (Protac 2L) and have had a few days to assess it. It is very bright - enough so to disorient an attacker in the dark. As a 'premium' light running on CR123A batteries, it easily whoops my other basic LED flashlights in terms of brightness & throw (the others run on 3xAAA and 1xAA). Belt clip is sturdy. Activation button is straightforward, and only took a few minutes to get the hang of (bright - strobe - dim). It is small but not too small - just the right size to fill the palm of one's hand. Included batteries were of the Energizer lithium brand and provide no room for complaint.

This is a great light for EDC or for off-hand use while operating a sidearm with the strong hand. At the price I paid, I couldn't be happier. This light will join me on many adventures for years to come, assuming I don't lose it!

The only thing I'm not enthralled with is the holster. Velcro, nylon, and spandex... just doesn't seem as robust as it should be, considering the quality of the light riding inside of it. The addition of a leather holster would be optimal, and worth a few extra dollars, but I have enough faith in the belt clip that I can reasonably ignore the holster altogether.

review_title: A good have with batteries that will last
reviews: Purchased the Streamlight with 2AA batteries too. I think the advantages of this one are (1) it has a stronger intensity light, (2) one does not have to worry about the batteries leaking during storage in the flashlight. The CR123A batteries have a ten-year battery life so you can keep the flashlight w/batteries in the glove compartment of your car for emergency use. Granted, the batteries are more expensive than the AAs or AAAs, but when you pay so much for a quality flashlight, you don't want the batteries to leak and ruin your flashlight. I have Inova, Fenix, and Streamlight flashlights. The Streamlights are good for the money. I would not say one manufacturer's flashlight is better that the other; its what matters to you as terms of what you regard as important to you in a flashlight. When buying a flashlight, I resort to researching Amazon.com and read the reviewers' reviews. Thank you Amazon.com and all the reviewers.

reviews:
Super Bright, quality build. Clip is easily removable. Uses 3 x CA123 (9V), so it's longer than most 2 cell CA123 (6V) flashlights. Perfect for a house, car or tool box, buy a bit too long for a pocket carry.

Would recommend using only SureFire or StreamLight Lithium Batteries, as these batteries are specially designed for flashlights which have a high current drain. Other CA123 batteries are designed for cameras, not flashlights. Avoid no name brand batteries. I bought this flashlight with 12 Streamlight batteries, but I also use Surefire batteries - both are good.

Regular D-Cell Flashlight batteries contain water, which will freeze in your car during the winter. CA123 Batteries are rated to -40¬∞, and have a shelf life of 10 years. This is the best kind of flashlight for a car or truck.

This was highly recommended on http://www.The-Ebola-Survival-Guide.com/ and http://www.Economic-Collapse-Survival-Guide.com/

reviews: Great light! Slightly smaller than I imagined but that's not a bad thing. It's perfect size for everyday carry. 350 lumens from a light this size makes it an amazing tool to always have in your pocket. I've carried a flashlight everyday for more than 10 years and this is the best one I've had yet, and the brightest. Smooth going in pocket and just as smooth coming out, no sharp edges to get hung up like some other lights I've carried. Pocket clip holds it securely and is flexible enough that it's not difficult to clip it on. It's also VERY lightweight. For the money I doubt you'll find a better light. If I had paid double what it cost I would still be very pleased with it. I've seen several reviews where people have received counterfiet versions, that's horrible. Thankfully I received a genuine Streamlight. Always verify that it has the Streamlight logo on the tail switch, the Ten-Tap programming works, and it has a serial number on body of light. As long as it has all 3, you can be sure it's authentic. If you're looking for an affordable, dependable, and effective EDC light, look no further. Highly recommended!

reviews:
I've only had this light for a week, but it's proved itself to me already. I'm currently using the hook and loop attached holster that came with the light. The combo is very comfortable for EDC and is so light I hardly know it Is there. Access is fast, albeit a little noisy due to the hooks being removed from the loops. The light draws well for me. I haven't used and have no intent to use the clip. The clip is tight on the light's frame out of the box, and I could see it staying that way without frequent use. However with frequent use I'd have to believe any clip would loosen up.

Someone else mentioned it is or was almost too small for their hand. I'm 6' 240lbs with big hands. I can hold and operate the light with no issues. Any shorter though and the back of my palm would fold in front of the lens. Of course everyone is different so ymmv.

The light is plenty bright enough for pretty much any use I can think of. Use of the strobe and low beam settings were easy to adjust to accessing after a few trial runs getting the feel of the switch. The construction material is a quality metal. Time will tell how it holds up to EDC but I have high hopes. Battery door is sealed with an o-ring to keep dirt and moisture out. I haven't run down the included battery yet, but I have replacements on order. So far I've mostly used it on the brightest setting off and on so I expect to replace it about once a month.

Initial thoughts lead me to believe this is a quality product and I'd recommend it to anyone.

review_title: switching modes takes some practice with this almost perfect, versatile light!
reviews: This review could deserve 5 stars, but one feature of the flashlight I have not personally mastered even after extensive attempts, and that is changing the modes, its a momentary multiple presses of the button without engaging the button, and you have to do it quickly, otherwise it doesn't take. #83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Good but eats batteries fairly quickly
reviews:
I have had this flashlight for about a year now.

PROS:
Sturdy - I can be pretty harsh on my equipment but has held up well even on multi-day hikes.
Bright - The brightest setting when on new batteries can illuminate paths well 100+ meters and while I have never needed the strobe light, it is fairly disorienting.
Low-Mode - The low mode is more than sufficient for most tasks that do not involve fast moving objects as it is really a super fast pulsing strobe light.

CONS:
Battery usage: A week of light use with the occasional High Beam seems to do the batteries in, while still powered the drop in performance is very noticeable.

Verdict:
I definitely like the make and brightness of the flashlight but in the future I would get something that is either rechargeable or without such a drop off in brightness.

UPDATE: I had an issue with the light shutting off prematurely and the warranty/repair process was quick and hassle free. I got the flashlight back and it works great. I increased my rating from a 3 to a 4.

reviews:
This flashlight is BRIGHT. This flashlight is so lightweight you will carry it everyday. You will find that you use it multiple times a day. It's small, but not too small. It should fit any hand perfectly. It's powerful. If you use the high setting it's truly dangerously bright.

I loved this flash light so much I bought one for my dad - who reported to me today that after 3 weeks of use he absolutely loves it. He uses it everyday for tasks around the home. We programmed it to be on the low setting on first "click."

For self defense purposes I'd say this light is a great medium. When pointed into potential assailants face it will buy you time, but not overreach boundaries as much as you'll get by firing a taser, or even spraying mace.

Imagine working at a computer after hours. The lights are off - it's dark. The doors are locked. You hear someone open the front door but can't see them 100 feet ahead (It's a huge building). You shout out "HELLO?" No response. You turn on your Streamlight 88031 and blind a man carrying cleaning supplies.

Oh, it's the night janitor I didn't know we had. And he's listening to headphones. He was probably partially blinded but he said he didn't blame me.

reviews:
I. LOVE. THIS. FLASHLIGHT.

I have a Surefire E2D Defender that I like but just doesn't put out enough light and LED conversion bulbs are insanely expensive for something so small. I bought a pelican LED flashlight to try and make up for the lack of light output, however, for requiring two 123As the light output on the pelican was worse than my Defender. I ditched that quick and did some research. I've never owned a streamlight but I have heard amazing things. So I took a chance with this ProTac 1L-1AA. This flashlight is amazing, the size is perfect and the light output is perfect, not too bright and the ability to choose between bright or dim. I use the dim setting quite often at work as this flashlight is carried daily. The description claims you'll get a higher lumen output with the lithium. However I have noticed there is no difference in output between a lithium and a AA. Seeing as how AAs are cheaper and easier to come by I use them primarily.

If you are looking for an EDC flashlight, work light, emergency light, bug out bag light...... This is the flashlight to get.

reviews: Ultra-bright center that spreads to a diffused wide beam. This is the one you want. When I inserted the batteries, I briefly clicked it on. The flashlight was facing my computer monitor and the reflected light was so bright that I recoiled, turned my head and closed my eyes, exclaiming to myself "WowI That's a bright light." I also have a Streamlight on my pistol and have a little tiny Streamlight on my rifle. I prefer the small one on my rifle because it is light-weight and I can swing my rifle onto moving targets faster. Not that I actually swing my rifle onto moving targets, but less mass near the end of the barrel means less inertia to overcome and less energy required to bring the weapon to bear on moving targets. That equals faster target acquisition for targets out to 20 yards or so, which will be normal in close-combat (inside and around a house). This reviewed light is larger, brighter and suitable for weapons mounting if you expect to engage at night out to 100 yards or so, obviously outdoors.

reviews:
I buy a lot online, but don't often write reviews unless it's really good or really bad. I've given probably a hundred 4 and 5 star reviews and only a handful of bad. I only used this flashlight a few times and it worked for less than 2 months. It's dead. Of course the "window" has closed for me to exchange it to Amazon so I had to call Streamlight direct. They told me to go on their website, fill out a service request and mail it to them and they will repair it. A big pain in the rear. I have thrown items away rather than go through this hassle. But for $87, I have no choice but to waste my time finding a box and stuffing and since my printer is down, go to the library to print the label, then off to the post office to spend more money mailing it to them.

I have a lot of flash lights and this is my first and last Streamlight purchase. A GREAT company would mail you a new one and tell you to send the broken one back. A good company would at least mail you a return box and label for shipping. I have 5 Surefires that I paid $2 to $8 for, are just as bright, and have never let me down. My expectation is much greater for the price of this light and reputation of this company but it failed the basics by simply not working. Then, they don't make it easy to exchange. I will update my review to let you know of any positives and any more negatives of the exchange process. Thank you.

Great job Streamlight!

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
Fenix, Inova, Coast, GG&G, Pelican, ElZetta.
I refused to buy a SureFire, because at the time, I wasn't made of money, and don't really like hype. But in an endless quest to find the brightest and affordable flashlight, someone finally came out with a product that you really can't beat for the money.

1. A very bright, very white light. I'm not sure what the light temperature is in terms of Kelvin, but it is a very white light. For me, that is important. I like 6500K. It is the color of daylight. Warm lights are nice, and have their place... they provide a very relaxing environment for your eyes, especially when reading at night. 6500K is not that light. It pierces the darkenss and the colors of the objects are the same with your light as they were in the day when you were outdoors.

2. The 10-tap programming is excellent. If you are using this in a tactical situation, accidentally toggling through a strobe mode is, at best, inconvenient. At worst, you've befuddled yourself. I have at least two of these lights, and I keep one on HIGH only, and the other on LOW-HIGH. If you're the the opposite end of the flashlight for the bad guy, you get full power. If its the flashlight I keep in my pack, LOW-HIGH allows me long battery life and the ability to read a document without blinding myself.

3. Lifetime warranty. A lot of other companies do not offer this, and that is a shame. Kudos to Streamlight for standing by their product.

5. The size means it is easy to hold and use. The button placement is perfect, and it will not slip easily from your hand. The bezel is slightly crenelated, so a whack to your assailant would hurt, but it is not so aggressive as to tear you up accidentally.

6. Too big for your jeans. Unless you like that awkward look and feel.

7. Not as durable as an ElZetta, which is a better weapon-mounted light. They are virtually indestructible, but not as white.

8. Good beam pattern, with a definite hot spot in the center.

9. You cannot "stare it down." I don't care who you are. If this light is pointed in your eyes, you will flinch, and it hurts.

10. I really wish it could would be compatible with a pressure switch they already make, to make it more feasible as a weapon-mounted light. But that is simply icing.

11. Buy one. Or three.

reviews:
This fantastic flashlight really delivers in three important areas:
1) Compact and Bright. It has 600 lumens on high! This is amazing for a light that fits in my pocket. 2) Adequate low setting. The low brightness setting provides a comfortable amount of light for taking night walks without killing the battery. It is twice as bright as the Surefire low setting - which cannot be comfortably be used for night walking, in my opinion. 3) Self-Defense. It has a blinding and fast 600LM strobe that could help provide just enough time for you to get out of a bad situation.
I also considered the HexBright Flex, but didn't want to mess around with programming it. The Streamlight factory settings are just what I needed. They are also very easy to cycle through with quick taps on the button. You can't beat this Stramlight's value! It is priced right. This is definitely the most bang for your buck in tactical flashlights. Big time value and no buyers remorse for spending $100+ on something similar :-)

After fumbling around in the dark with small underpowered flashlights, I decided to try out one of the "premium" lights. Some friends had spoken highly of StreamLight. After doing some comparisons, I bought the ProTac 2L. While I've only played with this a few days, I'm very happy with it. review_title: This Will Light Up Your World
reviews: I now own two of these, and have ordered a third. I walk our two dogs every night, carrying this Streamlight flashlight. We live in a rural area of NH, at the end of a dead end road, so things are pretty dark. I am aware of everything that might move, including critters like skunks that can ruin a casual walk very quickly. With 600 lumens (brightest in its class), I have seen the eyes of animals peering back from the dense woods that surround our home. It can be very reassuring. at times, to be able to avoid "confrontations" by being able to see what might be "trouble", even before the dogs can sense it. My wife has one in her car, and I have recently bought an Elzetta flashlight mount for my shotgun for home protection, so that's why I need a third. There are a lot of fans of Surefire products, and good products they are, but I believe this particular Streamlight unit is the best for my needs. No problems to date.

review_title: This light, you need this light..
reviews:
This is a BEST VALUE + GREAT PRODUCT type of equation. I work at night, outside, looking for people. I don't use a light a lot, but when I do, I need it to be blinding. This light, oh this light is the best. Super bright. I mean bright. So much so, that they guys I work with call it the "Night Sun" (which is what the spotlight on the Blackhawks is called), they call it that, because, it's bright.

Now, it chews through batteries. I carry 2 lights, both surefire. I use the other one most of the time, it's ok, but it's no Night Sun. But when I need to find/blind a subject, I break this one out.

"Seems like you're a fan, why not 5 stars?" you ask...I've only had it a year. It's caught a ton of subjects, blinded a few so I didn't have to fight them and it's held up to the beating my gear takes. 2 minor things. Battery life and it gets super hot after about ten minutes.

Buy this light. You won't regret it.

reviews: Excellent flashlight that I use every day for work. This flashlight sat in salt water for an hour, completely submerged, and it still works just fine. review_title: Durable, reliable, amazing value, crap clip
reviews:
Just like the title states. I havent had a light in this price point perform so well. This is my personal edc choice. Great battery life, excellent output, water proof (to a point), solid construction. My one and only issue with this product is the pocket clip. I lost mine in the first week. If you try and carry it deep on the clip it wants to pull away from the light and pop off. Pretty much useless. I went and bought a maxpedition sheath for it(original that came with the light is garbage) and couldnt be happier with it. All in all, best value youll find.

UPDATE* 7/24/2015
The light has finally died on me. Its been nearly 3 years of hard use in rain, snow, high dust, and overall messy situations. Honestly its been exceptional in its edc roll and I had used it daily. The useless pocket clip was taken off about a year into service just because the only thing it did was act as a kick stand. Other than that I wish streamlight backed these with a lifetime warranty or atleast offered rebuilds because this thing has sentimental value at this point and the body of it is riddled with scars and wear from the years of use. If your on the fence, just buy it. You'll be glad you did.

review_title: Perfect EDC tactical light, my trusted companion
reviews: This has recently became my EDC tactical light. I especially like the double-tap-to-strobe functionality of the rear power button. Perfect for diffusing an escalating or threatening situation. The anti-roll casing is also ideal for drop scenarios. Clip is pleasantly sturdy without being too rigid -- clipping this within my back pocket is easy enough, and I trust the clip will keep it there. review_title: Great "Tactical" light that's easy to carry at a decent price.
reviews:
I have a Fenix L10D, L2D, and a P3D that are great utility lights, but the Streamlight 2L is an excellent Tactical light because of the very bright intensely focused beam, and especially with the functionality of an effective momentary-on switch. The incredibly powerful Fenix TK series tactical lights are just too big (and expensive) to carry everyday and their old L1T is underpowered in comparison.

With my particular Fenix lights you fully depress the switch then half press to cycle through the different modes. On the Streamlight you essentially do the opposite and half press the tail cap to cycle through the modes and then fully depress the button to click and select it.

In tactical use with the 2L you can quickly pull the light out and immediately it will blind a person at the highest output by a simple half press of the tail cap. A second half press will emit a disorienting strobe with the third press is at the lowest setting.

The size of the light is perfect, not too small and not too big, and easily secured in my front pants pocket with a detachable clip. The only improvements I would like is more aggressive knurling on the body for a better grip and less artifacts in the quality of the beam.

I've been using the 2L with rechargeable Tenergy LiFePO4 CR123A batteries which has been working well with this light so far. The Streamlight 2L currently replaces the also excellent Fenix LD10 1xAA as my favorite EDC light.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster
rank:
#9,282 in Tools & Home Improvement (See Top 100 in Tools & Home Improvement)
#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Very High Power plus a low power option
reviews: I'm a night shift patrol officer. I have my flashlight set to the low/high setting. When I first approach a vehicle that I stop, I double tap the switch so that I'm on high beam. I guarantee that everyone in that car who tries to look at me on my approach is completely blinded by this light. It's powerful. Once I have all hands in sight and my problem areas are controlled, I tap it down to the low beam so I don't blind myself with the reflections from DL and paperwork. It's nice having two options available. It has a little metal clip on it so I can hang it on my shoulder when taking notes. I'd highly recommend buying a pack of batteries though (Streamlight 85177 CR123A Lithium Batteries, 12-Pack) because it's not rechargeable. It takes two of those batteries, and I think they last me about a month or two before needing to be replaced. If it was rechargeable without sacrificing power, weight, or price, I would have given it a 5. I like the size of the flashlight too. It's small and light. It's also easy to hold while shooting. There is a strobe setting, but I don't use it.

reviews: This is one powerful flashlight. I have a number of flashlights for various purposes and this one by far is the most powerful for it's size. I can shine this across the field at my home and light the trees up about 100 yards away. Not just enough to see the trees, this thing is like the HID light on my motorcycle. The high power 600 lumen mode and the strobe mode can temporarily blind and disorient a would be assailant for a number of seconds. The low power setting is perfect for walking through the woods in the dark or looking through a closet or safe. The battery cylinder is 25mm and fits well in a 1" mount. The included holster is nice and if you prefer, the light is not too bulky to carry in the front pocket of your jeans using the attached clip. Switch operation is simple but takes a few tries to get used to the mode selection. Once you get it you will like it. I've got lights that are similar in construction and size that cost twice as much and don't come close to being this powerful. If your looking for a great quality and extremely powerful flashlight for tactical use, hunting, boating or any reason, this is it.

review_title: Great light. Excellent self defense even more so if you don't like guns.
reviews:
Fact check: this is a tactically designed light. It's intent is to provide observation abilities and strong deterrent effect strobe. Used properly with the "Double tap" then hold/click strobe functions anyone in a dark parking garage could point and aim it a 'creeper' while yelling, "STOP/LEAVE OR I'LL SHOOT". The perpetrator would bail out and flee in disarray. If it comes down to it, it's a better striking element than a closed fist. Trust me, I own a green belt and watched the movie "The Foot Fist Way" - (Directed by Jody Hill. With Danny McBride)

I use it to spot my little terrier in the pitch black Wyoming prairie among the winter wheat. Some Giant lights are bright, brighter and cheaper, each has it's place. Don't complain that a small light is only as good as a 3-5 D-cell sized club. This is smallish and brings home the lumens.

If you do own a gun, the light is your best friend!

review_title: Great Light- Works well as a shoulder light for LEOS
reviews:
I picked this light up after one of my friends showed me how well it works as a hands-free shoulder light for law enforcement officers. The light clips onto your microphone tabs on your uniform and is easy to activate with your support hand when needed.

The different levels take a bit of practice to get used to, but after a little practice you will be able to activate the low beam with ease. The low beam is perfect for writing down info in low-lit areas while keeping both hands free of a larger flashlight. The low beam is also good for checking if someone's pupils show equal dilation when exposed to light.

The high beam is bright enough to serve as a duty flashlight if needed. I would not recommend use of this light as your only duty flashlight, but it makes a great backup light. The included pouch is small and easily fits on a duty belt.

The strobe is bright and disorientating when shined in someone's fact, but I cannot see myself using the strobe feature very often.

After I used the light for a few nights, 2 co-workers said they had to have one! :)

I highly recommend this light for any LEO, security officer, EMT, or other professional who could benefit from having both hands free while using a light. A++

The pouch included has a wide enough belt loop for web gear and other very wide belts, almost too wide in fact for a standard belt.

*edit* I'm bumping this up from 4 starts to 5. I haven't found another decent sub-$40 light anywhere else. Are there brighter lights out there? Yes, but they're either a lot more expensive, or not as well made. This is a great deal for a great product.

reviews:
I purchased this light awhile back. I believe everyone needs to carry a light source of some sort. This light seemed ideal, it wasn't too heavy and was bright enough to use for defensive tool and locating missing items.

Then the negatives come into effect, I kept this light on my right side with my clip on knife. The clip would keep popping off. So I decided to glue the clip to it. That worked, then the clip started to bend outwards and one day it fell out of my pocket and it's gone for good. Had they made the clip stronger and thicker I wouldn't have lost it because everyday I still have my knife on me in the same pocket with no issues.

Also the button required a lot of strength to activate it. Great because the light never turned on in my pocket but bad because I felt if I had to turn it on when I needed it the most I would probably fail. This is coming from a big boy that when something requires to be lifted I am usually asked first.

I will be looking elsewhere for a new pocket flashlight.

review_title: Great light. I used to be a SureFire loyalist ...
reviews:
Great light. I used to be a SureFire loyalist until I lost my P2X Fury (I know, how dumb, right?). I knew I needed a good EDC hand light but I wasn't in a place where I could afford another Surefire. I used to kind of shun the Streamlight because of a few dumb misconceptions I had and that several people still seem to have but, now that I own one, holy bananas do I love this light. 1,000 lumens with an awesome hot spot and great flood. All for a fraction of what my Surefire cost. I'm not saying you should switch to the Pro Tac if you own a SureFire. If you're looking for a great light, definitely count Streamlight in the fight. Love this thing.

The only downside:
I carry with a Thyrm Switchback so you have to file the inside down a little to make it fit the protac. Not really an issue but, it's something worth mentioning since I'm sure many who are looking into high lumen EDC lights are probably considering carrying with a Switchback.

review_title: Good light, but controls are clunky.
reviews: I am a HVAC/R mechanic, and admittedly, I use a flashlight pretty hard at work. The idea of the clip so I can attach it to a brim of a hat, and the high/ low beam light is what sold me on this model. The flashlight is built well, but I give it a low rating because of the clunky button mashing to cycle between high/ strobe/ low beam. There is nothing worse then being in confined areas to work, then arguing with a flashlight to go to low beam. Having to click three times to get to low beam is a mess. It seems every time, I tried to adjust I kept getting the strobe effect (second click). When you‚Äôre in a dark, tight quarters, your body twisted and standing on your head and the high beam is too bright and you want to go to low, and then screwing up the clicks and have the strobe go off....first couple times it‚Äôs funny, then it gets frustrating after a while. If you can figure out how to control the light, it‚Äôs a good one. Me and my old mechanics hands, didnt get along with it.

review_title: If you had to have one flashlight, make sure this is the one
reviews:
This little light is a killer! I ordered this after reading many reviews online for a small light I could EDC in a pocket, but still gave some serious lighting ability. Coming from someone who owned only Surefires, I thought of Streamlight as a 2nd class of light. However after carrying this light with me every day since I bought it (a little over half a year now I believe) I am a true fan!

This light has been with me in the city, out camping, illuminated dark dirt roads in the middle of Wyoming, been dropped more times than I can count, and has survived all I thrown at it so far.

I love the multiple modes this has, the outstanding price for the capability, and the fact that I can carry this in just about any pocket of any pair of pants I own easily.
Size compassion with the Sypderco Delica 4 for scale.

Seriously, if you need a small light to EDC, but require over 100/150 lumens, you would be doing yourself a disservice to not pick this up. I love my Surefires still, but the fact this has been with me every day since buying it over them should speak for itself. That is mostly a size issue but still, this thing kicks ass- get you one.

review_title: From 1AA to 1L-1AA, I couldn't be happier. Another incredibly well executed idea from my favorite light company
reviews:
Can I add a sixth star? Having a ProTac 1AA for about four years, I was very pleased to stumble upon this new iteration. Originally I bought the 1AA for its very compact size, utility of a common battery, and good light output. Now with the ability of the 1L-1AA to use a CR123 for higher output makes it an outstanding light! Its slightly larger size fits the hand better than the original. It clips in the pocket very nicely, or even clips into a belt loop. Just be mindful of brushing against doors, walls or chairs. Even clothing may dislodge it, should you use a belt loop.

The light output with a CR123 is very impressive because it's a 3V lithium. I am even likely to buy lithium AA batteries for the notably longer battery life. Still, a standard alkaline AA will work if you have a bulk pack in your emergency supply kit. The high performance CR123 capability, combined with the standard and sufficient AA versatility is the BIG selling point for me. I may even get a second one soon, just to have it around.

reviews:
Had my 5-d Maglight for 25 years. Still love-and still use it- in spite of its cumbersome size. A while back I bought the small version and the twist on feature is so intermittent that it is never on. Huge disappointment. After some research and a few friends recommendations I settled on the Streamlight.

I am very impressed. The switch takes getting used to if you want to use the low power setting (don't really expect to use that). On mine I usually have to click 5 times when the instructions say 4. Otherwise it's sturdy, super bright and very handy.

At this point the only possible downside is the battery and I might consider getting versions that use AA/AAA or more standard battery from the same company. We'll see how long this one lasts so it might be a non issue considering I used to buy 5x D cells for the mag.

My best recommendation is that I immediately ordered one for my Dad's birthday.

If I run into any issues I'll be sure to follow up!

reviews: I originally purchased a 2 aa streamlight flashlight and fell in love with it. I used it on the job out in the country where there is no light at night. The low setting is fine for walking around your back yard in familiar area but when your in the boonies it's more light the better. I was so impressed with this light I ordered the 88040 ProTac HL when I returned home. This will be my light of choice now as the low setting is much brighter and the high setting turns night to day. Hard to imagine so much light from something this size. You get what you pay for and believe me when your out there all alone you won't be patting yourself on the back for saving a few bucks on a cheaper light. Buy some good batteries and give yourself some piece of mind when duty calls, I know it makes a world of difference for me.

review_title: Small in size, big in light
reviews:
I first heard about this light while reading a law enforcement publication. The entire back page of their technology section was devoted to this light. After reading the article, I continued to search more about the light on YouTube and other internet sites.

As a law enforcement officer, I had been carrying the same Streamlight since the early 90‚Äôs. It has served me well, and I have never had a problem with it, and only had to change the battery packs twice over the years. I also have a Surefire light that I had received as a Christmas gift years ago, which I know cost almost $200.00. However with the low list price and the big hype of lumens, I went for it and purchased the light. I am happy I did.

When I received the light, I played with the programming and adjusted it to the Low/High setting. This works great, as it can be used it in the car to look for dropped items and into my duty bag without blinding me. I used it on the low setting most of the time, however when you need the big lumens, just double tap the switch and ON WITH THE BIG LIGHT!

While the beam cannot be focused, it is very bright and really floods the area. Every time to turn on the high beam in a dark area, I always get the same response from other officers, ‚Äúholly cow (yes, cleaned up for Amazon) what the heck do you got there?‚Äù

I have since purchased five more for my family and as gifts. I also know six officers that have purchased one after seeing mine in action. I should be getting a free one from Streamlight for all the sales I have provoked!

Would I like to see it in a re-chargeable battery, sure, but I find that batteries last several month of normal use. For the weight, size, lumens and price‚Ä¶ hard to beat.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

The Maglite LED XL200 is yet to be beat. Five function switch Including a dimmer that dims by holding the switch and rotating the flashlight to the desired brightness and a setting that when you set it down and it dims to save juice. Once you touch it it lights again to the last setting it was dimmed to. The Streamlight however is worthy of the forty bucks. Its thin, light and really bright. I would recommend it to a friend. I will update this review if something worthy good or bad occurs. Doesn't hurt that it comes with a nylon holder and batteries.

reviews: This is a great little light. It runs on one AA battery which can be found just about anywhere. It has three brightness levels; the brightest is surprisingly bright for such a small light. And sadly, that was main thing I was looking for. I wanted a compact, durable, replaceable-battery penlight for pupil exams. I have yet to find one that isn't too bright. Nevertheless, this is a great compact flashlight, and is now my go-to for general purpose illumination. I also carry a 500-lumen Surefire Fury, which is great when you need a LOT of light, but it's often way too much for just checking something out. So this is now the flashlight I use the most.

review_title: Streamlight 88040 ProTAC HL High Lumen Professional Tactical Light
reviews:

One concern is that after a few minutes the front end does get very warm / hot to the touch, at this point that has not created any problems but I would be reluctant to leave the light on for extended periods of time. Cons:

review_title: Small, light, brighter than most in this size class
reviews:
I bought this to carry in my pocket at all times, and I'm not disappointed. It's very small, very lightweight, and more powerful than many other compact tactical lights. I've compared it favorably with other units in stores, and found the output on the high setting to be around the advertised 200 lumen area. (It's easy to get something brighter, but expect the end to flare out, increasing the footprint significantly.)

The push-button is very positive, with a good travel before constant engagement. I use the low setting occasionally for work, which is handy. The negative would be that you have to tap the push-button to cycle through the modes:

1 tap: High
2 taps: Strobe/High
3 taps: Low

Once you're in the right mode, you push in on the button all the way to keep it constant. To get a low-beam constantly on, I often have to try twice or more.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

review_title: A very light, very bright little flashlight!
reviews:
This is a fantastic little flashlight! It is very lightweight and fits comfortably into a shirt pocket or pants pocket without weighing the pocket down terribly. The three light settings are cool also. On the bright setting this light is incredibly bright for its size. The dim setting is nice for when you don't need a real bright light and want to save your battery. I'm not sure what the strobe setting is really useful for but my kids love it.

Negatives are pretty mild. The beam cannot be focused like you can with a "Mag Lite". It would be nice if you could adjust the beam but it really doesn't hurt the usefulness at all. Learning to work the switch to get the different light settings takes a bit of practice but most get the hang of it pretty quickly. The unusual CR123A batteries are a bit inconvenient also but the battery life is pretty long so it's not a big deal if you're not using the flashlight very often (like me).

I bought one for my brother-in-law. He's one of these guys that is really hard to buy for and he loved it! A really cool little flashlight that I highly recommend.

review_title: How do you follow a winner? With a winner!
reviews: I liked the Streamlight PT 2L so much I bought 4 of them. They are great flash lights and I didn't see a lot of room for improvement. Then I bought the 88040. It is in an entirely different league. To be fair, it is a larger, heavier light but it does put out 600 lumens. I know there is always a trade off with battery life but one of the biggest improvements in the 88040 in the tailcap switch. It is so much easier to select high, strobe and low modes compared to the PT2L. I thought I was going to use the programming feature to lock out the strobe but it is so easy to make the right selection that I just left it alone. I was very happy to have this and all my other streamlights during hurricane Sandy. The prospect of losing power was a little less daunting knowing that their were good tools to work with. I have taken my Streamlights on some fairly remote trips in the mountains. Bottom line is that I trust them as much as I trust anything that can break.

review_title: Awesome, will be buying another one soon.
