#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
AWESOME LIGHT. Just received this light and tested it. It comes with both a CR123A battery, as well as a quality AA battery. Both batteries inserted into the light without issue. Upon inserting the AA, there is a small amount of spring pressure put on the battery in order to close the tail cap, however, it is a non issue.

I tried the CR123A battery first and the light worked perfectly. The high setting is very bright with a good hot spot and plenty of spill. Very few, if any, artifacts can be spotted in the beam. The strobe and low setting also worked fine with just the right amount of light on the low setting.

I then inserted the AA battery. I was actually taken back on how much light was produced with a AA battery on high. Visually, it appeared very similar to the amount of light the lithium battery produced. Low and strobe also worked fine.

The light is very well made and should give you no problems. Streamlight has excellent customer service, so if you do have any problems, they are willing to stand by their products, from my experience.

I would not hesitate to purchase several of these lights, as the "duel fuel" capability is the best selling point of this model.

If you are looking for a great light, do not hesitate to purchase this one.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
I wanted a small light with a simple user interface for pocket carry and the Streamlight Protac 1L fills that role perfectly. About the size of a glue stick, this small light puts out a surprising amount of light. The beam is relatively narrow, mainly due to the reflector, but it is perfectly adequate for a light this size.

The light comes on HIGH with the first tap, STROBE with a double tap, and LOW with a triple tap. Anyone used to double-clicking a mouse will be familiar with the type of action needed to change modes. The forward clicky switch is recessed, so this light can tailstand. The bezel has very minor crenelations, not nearly enough to be uncomfortable in a pocket, but enough to make it unpleasant for a person to get hit with.

I use this light with 'expired' CR123A primaries and it works great.

reviews: I bought this product in December '14. Now, admittedly I am not the most handiest guy around--two left thumbs as a matter of fact, so I have never utilized this light in all of its formats. Reason: I'm agile enough to turn it on or off (applause!) but when it comes to its other assets, such as acting in a strobe mode, it has never worked for me--it's to darn difficult to get it into the position it should be in. However, my son who is a mechanical and engineering genius, tried it for a minute or two and was able to repeat the motions each time he tried in the same strobe condition. So a word to the wise--if you are seeking a high lumen light simply to turn on and off, this may not be the guy for you. But if you are in the high tech mode and find mechanical things easy to work out, this unit should work fine for you. Bright as hell in lumens but in exchange I have found that it gobbles up batteries fairly quickly upon heavy workloads. Back up its availability for it being there when called upon by buying extra batteries.

reviews: The light is bright and has better than average throw without too narrow a beam, but the switching layout isn't something that lends itself to intuitive law enforcement operation. It's probably best to program it for high brightness operation only if LE is its intended purpose. Furthermore, the low setting is achieved via pulse width modulation and the switching (flickering) is painfully obvious - very poorly designed. The brightness step down routine is necessary to preserve battery life and is done reasonably well compared to other lights at the same price point, but if used for more than 6-15 minutes continuously the light effectively becomes a 600 lumen light. Bottom line - it's a good light, but for the same price I prefer the slightly less luminous Klarus XT12 or the Fenix TK16.

reviews: I own four different lights from streamlight, that being said this is by far my favorite. this casts farther and brighter than the stylus pro, there is about as much difference between this and the stylus as there is, in brightness between the microstream compared to the stylus pro. the low mode is almost exactly the same as the nano. and the bright is 2 times brighter than the stylus pro. the strobe is very powerful given the size of this light. it is well worth the upgrade from the stylus pro. if you are skeptical about buying this and have never owned any streamlight product, I suggest spending 7 dollars on the nanolight, once you see how bright that little inch and a quarter light is you will definitely want to upgrade to a microstream,stylus or protac 2 aaa. review_title: Love this light, part of my EDC
reviews:
I carry this light with me every day. Not intrusive at all in the pocket, bright enough for 99% of applications. 3 modes are extremely useful. (Well the strobelight I havent found a use for yet other than driving cats nuts and bothering friends and family) The low setting is nice for maintaining night vision.

The only downside I have noticed after 6+ months of daily use (including being dropped and stepped on) is that occasionally I have to screw the bezel on tighter to get the light to activate. It's not a huge issue for me, however it would be nice if streamlight fixed that in future models.

2 AAA's makes replacing batteries a cinch, and the lifetime is actually pretty impressive.

reviews:
Plenty of reiews in here attesting to the overall quality of this little light .. I'm weighing in with a suggestion for anyone finding the tail switch a tad balky to get on/off.

I'm in pretty good shape, lift a bit, and work with my hands, so anyone else feeling frustrated by the inherent stiffness in the switch should not feel alone, lame, etc.

This relatively simple/free modification did wonders for making mine easier to operate:

Get an office/school supply type hole puncher - single or three hole doesn't matter - and an unused business card, as that weight paper is more convenient.
Punch out a few 'holes' from the card and save the little confetti circles the punch makes.
With a standard size hole puncher, they're a perfect size for what you're about to do.
Unscrew the very back cap that covers the switch, flip that cover over, and insert a few of the punchouts into the circular recess in the rubber switch cover.

For reference, mine works MUCH better with four pieces inserted.
I suppose regular paper would work too, but you'd obviously need more punchouts.

Aside from the switch stiffness, I find the finish a bit too slick for my liking, and have added just a bit of grip tape to remedy that annoyance, hence my 4 stars.

reviews:
I bought this flashlight for EDC (and on a budget) and have carried it around in my pocket for the last 3 months. It's very bright - brighter than I expected. When I show people how bright it is, they have all been very surprised. I think that the operation of this light is way simpler than some of the other reviewers. It has a half-push and a full-click (think focusing a digital camera, half-push, and taking a picture with it, full-click) that is very fast and reliable in my use so far. The strobe feature is awesome, and after trying it out on myself in a mirror I can say that it is VERY disorienting. The low-level light is also great, and is the mode I use the most. A lot of the time I don't need a blasting bright light, but do need just a little illumination, and this light is great for that.

There are 2 reasons for 1 star deduction. The first is that the batteries do in fact rattle around inside the flashlight, which is really just a minor annoyance. The second point and the only thing I really dislike about this light is the clip. I really wish this light had a low-ride type of clip. If I clip this light in my pocket like I do my pocket knife, the top sticks way out, and I don't like that. I wish it could ride below the top of the clip, so it would disappear into my pocket.

This light has been great, and overall I'm happy with it and would recommend it if you're looking for a pretty nice and bright little light on a budget.

reviews:
I walk at night. A few years ago, when I started to walk, I looked for a lightweight and bright flashlight. Up to then I used a 4 D cell Mag-Light. It was a club. I picked up a 90 lumen off the shelf flashlight at my local Wal-Mart. It did the job, but I wanted more light. At Home Depot I found a 200 lumen light that was even smaller and lighter. Unfortunately, it wouldn't stay on for more than 15 - 20 seconds before flickering itself to darkness. I sent it back to the manufacturer for repair or replace. The same light came back with the same problem. So, after some online research, I decided to spend a little more and ordered the Streamlight. The extra cost was worth it. Under high power night becomes day (exaggeration)! It floods whatever you point it at with bright white light. The strobe will attract attention from a mile or more away plus it can temporarily incapacitate (blind) anyone attempting negative behavior that looks at it. Low power is bright enough to be useful without becoming a battery killing beacon. A holster is supplied with an interesting feature - it can be removed without taking off my belt.

I can't comment on longevity yet. Other than that, I recommend the Streamlight 88040 ProTAC HL High Lumen Professional Tactical Light. I don't think you'll be disappointed.

reviews:
I bought this after watching a nutnfancy youtube video review and I'm glad that I did. I'll qualify, this is my first and only 'tactical' flashlight. It's a perfect size, puts out a quite a bit of light and has excellent build quality. I've had this for two years and the black body has some dings and scratches, but in not way do they compromise it's functionality. There are a couple of features that I love about this light. First off, the clip is excellent. It has good retention and isn't prone to snagging. I also love the switch on this light. The pressure on the switch is just right for me (enough to where I won't accidentally turn it on), and I love the tap features that cycle it between high/strobe/low beams.

I'll say it again, the size is just perfect in my opinion. It rides perfectly in a shirt pocket or pants pocket.

The only improvement that comes to mind would possibly be an integrated focus into the body (kind of like the mag lites have). Then again, not sure how that fits into the 'tactical' philosophy of use.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
I couldn't be happier with my purchase. I think it's an outstanding value. I love its compact size and extremely powerful beam. The LED's chromaticity and color rendering make it ideal for most any task. Inexpensive LED substitutes have an overly blue color temperature (chromaticity) and, very poor color rendering, making it difficult to perform tasks where discerning colors are important such as in electrical work. Do not fall for the inexpensive look-a-likes!

My original intent to purchase this flash light was for self-defense to employ with a hand gun, and the light's strobe option is certainly disorienting to would-be attackers in dark spaces. The on/off switch located at the rear of the unit makes it easy to actuate with your thumb allowing it to be employed with your free hand while managing your gun with the other.

I think it's a good buy and extremely well built unit that frankly has found more use in my life than just keeping it with my hand gun. Buy with confidence. I doubt you'll be disappointed.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

reviews:
The light is built with a great balance for ruggedness that isn‚Äôt too bulky. The amount of light this flashlight puts out plus the coverage is great. Overall this would be a great flashlight if it was dependable.

However, don‚Äôt expect this flashlight to stay on while in use. Unexpectedly, this light will turn off. I assumed it was a poor charge, so I gave this light another chance and let it charge for a full day but still the same outcome.

The on / off button will randomly cease to function correctly. At times you can click the button a dozen times after it unexpectedly shuts off and it may or may not choose to turn back on.

I work at nights and rely on a good flashlight. I‚Äôve contacted Streamlight and apparently this is a common problem in this model.

Five stars if this light will stay on when I need it, otherwise pick another light.

reviews:
Bought one of these before I went to Afghanistan and it was PERFECT for me! Small size and powerful light! Carried it with me everywhere - until it fell out of a pocket & I lost it one day. One minor drawback that happened with my last one was, if you smack the unit hard, it will change modes on it's own (bright/low/strobe). Not a big deal - just something to be aware of.
Do not use this on a firearm for the reason I just mentioned above. I never did - but have heard of people who have tried - and it will change modes when you fire. Use it as a personal device & you'll be happy. Comes with nice nylon pouch that you can attach to your belt, belt loop, a handle, wherever. Can't reccomend this enough!

review_title: Low mode - is fine for general tasks where high brightness isn't needed
reviews:
Pros:
High mode - extremely bright and will illuminate for approximately 50 yards. This setting shines a focused beam in the center, and wider, less-bright beam around it.

Strobe mode - appears to use the same brightness as the high mode and would be very disorienting if directed at someones eyes.

Low mode - is fine for general tasks where high brightness isn't needed, including outdoor use. Although I can't find it now, I read somewhere the average battery life on low is 28 hours.

Cons:
Battery life - the average battery life on the high setting is a little over an hour.

Batteries - this light uses proprietary Streamlight batteries that average $18 for a 12 pack.

reviews: This is a very good compact handheld light. It is very small and lightweight, surprisingly bright for it's size, and has a good battery life, especially when used sparingly on high. I use it as my house light and got about two months of use out of the batteries it came with. I realize many of the current crop of flashlights offer much higher lumen ratings, but also eat the batteries twice as fast. On high, this light illuminates out to about a hundred yards (very bright), and on low,about thirty. The low setting is good for moving around the house or walking outside when you don't want to lose your night vision. The light can be set on it's end and used as a candle, which would be handy in a tent or during a power outage. The tailcap switch interface is easy to use, although I wish it had the ten tap programming of it's big brother, the Protac HL. Overall, I consider this light an excellent value and highly recommend it to anyone looking for a utility flashlight.

reviews:
I purchased this flashlight to replace an old Browning flashlight that I have been carrying for almost ten years. The directions say to only use Streamlight, Panasonic, Sanyo, Energizer or Duracell batteries in this light. However I use rechargeable Ultrafire CR123 batteries and have no issues with them.

PROS
-Price
-Very strong, sturdy construction
-Lives up to its 180 lumen tagline
-Excellent blend of throw and flood

I compared this light to a Novatec SPL-120 (120 Lumen) and the Streamlight outshines it by a good margin.

CONS
-The pocket clip comes off too easily. Too many times I have been clipping it to a pocket to have the clip come off in my hand. Securing it with a screw instead of a clamp around the light would be better
-The flashlight does get a little warm near the reflector after being on for 15 minutes or more. Not enough to burn your hand but enough to notice.
-The programming takes a little getting used to, even if you read the directions. In the end you will spend a few minutes figuring out how to switch it from high to strobe to low. Very useful features for when you do not need the full 180 lumen power.

I needed a slim flashlight for my EDC and this one is perfect. Slim and not too long, fits in my pocket organizer nicely and also can use the included pocket clip.

I was worried about knock offs reading reviews for other Streamlight flashlights on Amazon, so i knew to check that it came with the batteries, that the tap functions worked, and that it had the Streamlight logo on the button. Gladly mine had all of those.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
The flashlight itself is great. Very bright. There are no instructions for how to program the light. I suppose the manufacturer assumes anyone purchasing this product knows how to program it...? Figured it out, but took a while since mine is defective. To program, depress the button 10 times, holding on the tenth press. This switches the program sequentially. While in operational mode, click once to turn on light. Click twice to switch modes.

My problem was, if I depress the button all the way (click) it will not program or switch modes. If I just touch the button (no click) I can program it and switch modes. Submitted a return of product, and waiting for a working light. I would have given 5 stars if the one I received wasn't defective - that's got to subtract from my review in my opinion.

reviews: Need a tactical light? Look no further. This thing is crazy bright. I use it all the time. The switch is super easy to use to toggle between blinding bright, pulse, and low beam. I have dropped it a few times and it totally held up. To me, the battery life is excellent for this type of powerful light. I use this at work, for self-defense, hunting, and around the home. I use it most every night, the batteries lasted four months. It's tough, and its very light not heavy at all. For me it's the perfect size. It will fit in any pocket you have. The clip also has held up and of course is very useful. The sheath is very tough and well made.

As for brightness this thing does its job flawlessly. I use the CR123's in it

review_title: Super bright and tough light! I recommend to anyone!!
reviews: Exceeded my expectations! It is super bright and has 3 modes: bright(600 lumens), strobe (600 lumens) and low (I think it is 30-40 lumens). It comes with Duracell batteries which are nice. Only thing is keeping it on the 600 lumens the batteries run down (still work) very fast but it says keeping it on high it will last 18 hours which it has. Another thing is its that ten touch programable thing, but mine never worked like that. Although it would be nice to have, I can use it just fine the way it is. I can switch from high to strobe to low. I do recommend this product! Oh and I did drop it on cement, and un like other lights, it was barely noticeable and didn't mess up any features or operation.

review_title: Most durable light ever! Buy this!
reviews:
This is absolutely one of the best small flashlights you can buy. It's the size of a pen or a marker, but gives an incredible amount of light. Great combination of light being spread out, to be able to see plenty around you, but also focused in the middle of the beam so it has a great range to it. Lumens mean nothing if they aren't focused right, and this focuses them perfectly. It can slip into your pocket and you'll hardly notice it there. Powered by AAA batteries, so no need to buy expensive batteries like some flashlights. Simple AAA. The clip can be moved to any place on the narrow part of the body, and turned any way you want it. I used it as a head lamp by turning the clip around and putting it on the bill of a hat. Perfect for dark mornings on the farm when greasing tractors before the day starts.

SPEAKING OF FARM WORK.....the real reason I came on here to write this review is because sometime last fall I dropped this flashlight in a cornfield when I was chainsawing trees on a fence line. One day it wasn't in my pocket next to my knife, like it usually was. I figured I lost it, and would just buy a new one. I was sad cuz this light was awesome! Here's the crazy part...I (luckily) accidentally left some branches in the field, and when my boss was planting THE FOLLOWNG SPRING, (yes, that's about 5 months later) he hopped out of the tractor to throw the branches off the field, and happened to look down, and hey, there is my Streamlight ProTac 2AAA sitting in the dirt. He picked it up and it turned right on, no hesitation, no problem.. This thing sat in the dirt, snow, rain, mud, and who knows what else for 5 months! And it still works as if brand new! This is not to mention the countless drops on concrete floors, rolling over on the ground with it in my pocket, (while doing vehicle maintenance/mechanic work) cold/hot, you name it, this thing works like its new. Its a bit scratched up now but no rust and still throwing out as much light as ever.

Also, a lot of the one-star reviews for this said that its hard to press the switch. No idea what they're talking about, mine is fine and normal. Strobe mode and low light mode are easy to get to, just a simple half press to get to them.

All that to say, one crazy year and a half later after purchasing this light, it has more than proven itself as a durable, bright, convenient, small but awesome flashlight. Every time I ever need a flashlight in the future, it will be a Streamlight. Six stars!!

review_title: Great flashlight for LE work as well as mounting to a tactical rifle
reviews:
I purchased this light mainly for the option of mounting it to my AR that I carry for use on my department's SWAT team. We seldom use long guns while typically only carrying our Glock 22s, which I have a Streamlight TLR1s mounted (yet another great streamlight product). However, in the event I need something for long range, my AR is ready.

This flashlight has 3 functions, and they all work superb. I am extremely happy with the programming of the led as well. I leave it on default but love that you can change it to fit your style.

If I am not mistaken, this thing also comes with a lifetime warranty. WOW!

The construction is great. It feels nice and rugged. I have no concerns of using this light in the line of duty. Furthermore, the fact it takes 123s is perfect. I have had bad experiences with rechargeables and would much rather replace them with disposables.

What am I thinking?! I can't believe I waited this long to talk about the strength of the LED. Boy, this sucker is bright!!! You can't look at this thing in daylight, much less in the pitch black. While camping the other night, I shined this baby into a tree about 150 foot tall and could see the entire canopy of the tree as bright as day.

The only negative this flashlight has is the lack of a mountable pressure switch. I ordered this baby thinking the regular streamlight remote would work but read several other pages that it would not. I have not tried it, but I do not want to be out the cash if it doesn't. Maybe streamlight will remedy this. Since it was my own fault when I didn't thoroughly research my decision, I will not discount the flashlight's rating.

You won't be disappointed, and yes, I would recommend to a friend.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

reviews: Have had this flashlight for about a month now, and I can definitely say it does the job. It's bright enough for just about every application, and it's relatively durable (dropped it once without so much as a ding on the frame). It's a bit fatter than I expected, but it does fit in the hand well. The button seems to work well. The low setting is probably sufficient for most uses, the bright light is good for basically lighting a large, dark room, and the strobe is wicked disorienting (I can't stand to look at for more than a second without my eyes starting to hurt, and the flashlight isn't even facing me). Obviously, the longevity and long-term durability will be big factors based on other reviews, but so far, so good!

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
I would have to rank this as one of the best purchases I've ever made. I've become so used to carrying it that I will go back to get it if I forgot it at home. It really messes up my day, if I don't have it with me. The reason being, is that it is very useful. Even during the day, it is powerful enough to be utilized. If a "lady" drops her keys under the table or sofa, you can be Johnny-on-the-spot with your Streamlight.
I am licensed to carry a handgun. I believe if you carry a gun you need to carry a tactical flashlight. You have to see what you're shooting at, and to blind and confuse "the bad guy". This Streamlight ProTac 2L is perfect for that. It's strong points are extreme brightness for its size, strobe feature, pocket clip and extreme light weight. I carried a Surefire for years that is 1/3 as bright and 3x the weight. This product is so light that you can "wear" it with anything. You don't even feel it on you, but it's there when you need it. The positives;

1. Very bright, extremely bright!! 3x brighter than the Surefire Tactical flashlights that have been used for years. (when I show it to people the first thing they want to do is to shine it into their friend's eyes, as a joke. I stop then because this can cause permanent eye damage)
2. The strobe feature is very useful. I used it coming out of a high school football game. We were crossing the street and a car was coming at us at a pretty fast rate. I aimed my Streamlight about 5 feet in front of me and hit the strobe. The car hit the brakes and slowed down (he probably thought I was police). Also used it to disorient dogs that have got too close.
3. The low power feature is best when you don't want to attract too much attention and to conserve battery life.
4. Battery life is deceptively short lived. I say that because I go through lots of batteries. I say deceptively, because I use it a lot. So, all in all, battery life is very, very good.

This product has very few negatives that, to be fair, it was not designed to do in the first place;
1. There is no free lunch, the small size of the lens and mirror does not give you a nice, sharply focused beam. Still, it is very bright and has a good amount of lumination to the surrounding area. It is best used, and I feel it was designed for, short range.
2. Due to its lightweight, it is not in the Surefire's league when it comes to durability and level of waterproof. Again, not something I feel it was designed to do.

All in all an awesome product. Highly recommended!!!
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Portable Sun, but not necessarily a good thing
reviews:
I picked this up just before Christmas on a Lightning deal on a whim. I already have a Stinger LED, an old-school Stinger converted to a Lite Pipe, and Protac 2AA, so I have no practical use for this thing, but i'm an admitted flashaholic, so whatevers. The first time I turned this thing on, it immediately caused a giggle fit. In broad daylight it was enough to blind me off the reflection from the hardwood floor.

GOOD: It's bright. Really bright. Insanely bright. Easily reaches several hundred feet. My other flashlights can blind, but I believe this thing could actually kill someone. Five stars just for how stupid bright it is.

BAD: Everything else. It's too bright to use in any kind of up close work except on low power. Any reflection off a shiny surface blinds you. I'm honestly afraid it might hurt someones eyes. The pocket clip is pointless, the head is as big as the stinger led, there's no way you could stick it in a normal human pocket. It takes uncommon CR123 camera batteries, which are like $2 each.

If you want a pocket flashlight go with one of the smaller Protacs. My 2AA is plenty bright enough for any task, it fits in my pocket, runs for a month with heavy use, and is a bit cheaper. If you want a bright, outdoorsy light, look into the HP series. If you want something to signal Mars, or burn the flesh off a vampire at 1000 yards, get a HL-3. For me, i'll keep it in the glovebox of my car as an emergency light. It was worth my money for the LOL factor alone.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
I had been following this flashlight since it's announcement and eagerly ordered it from Amazon once it was available. 600 lumens had always sounded appealing, but I never quite appreciated just how bright that is until I got my hands on this puppy. From 50 yards away you can temporarily blind someone of their night vision, get closer and it will disorient them even more. The bottom line is this: don't shine it at another person unless you really need to do so. Even with your eyes closed, this light will leave you seeing white halos for a 15-20 seconds if it is shined directly at you from close range.

Being in the fire department, this light is very handy for finding just about anything you lose, whether it be a tool in the middle of a house or a needle in a haystack, this flashlight will illuminate everything for you to see. The three function switch is handy, sometimes you don't need all 600 lumens to see what you're doing, and so simply tap three times and press the button in all the way. The beam is straight, with a little spread, but not adjustable. It is still incredible all of this power comes from just one LED.

Pros: sturdy, lightweight, easy to hold, packs a powerful punch, waterproof.
Cons: Goes through batteries like a sieve. 600 lumen output for the first 50 or so minutes of new batteries, then it rapidly decreases. Buy rechargeable batteries to use for this light, and you will be a happy camper. Otherwise I have no complaints. If you want what is easily the coolest and best flashlight for about $70, then look no farther. You will not be disappointed.

One final note, the low power mode does indeed flash the led at a hertz level faster than the human eye can see. The previous review was correct about how this could be potentially dangerous if examining machinery at night, since it could appear to spin backwards, or not moving at all. But I have experienced no issues with this.

Hope this helped, now go enjoy holding the sun at the end of your fingertips!
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

When toggling between settings it is easy to miss your desire setting because you only have to partially depress the button. If you push all the way down it just goes to the high setting and you cannot switch to strobe without switching it off-confused yet?
Partial depression high-click to maintain
Two partial depressions-strobe-click to maintain
three partial depression-low-click to maintain

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Best bang for your buck! and much better than the HL
reviews:
I was a bit hesitant to buy this flashlight at first because the Protac HL was priced exactly the same but offered 600 lumens. The reason I ended up sticking with the Protac 2L was for two main reasons. 1. This flashlight is small! It was much smaller than i anticipated and is perfect for edc. I'd rather have a 260 lumen light on my person than a 600 lumen one in my car or at home. I personally think the HL might not be best suited for edc becuase its bezel much larger and doesnt feel "right" in my pocket with an awkward bulge. Secondly, I believe that 260 lumens is very bright for my needs and would prefer the longer run time the 2L offers to a 600 lumen light. Also, if I needed to draw my weapon that did not have weapon mounted light and needed to clear my house/building or whatever, 260 lumens is plenty.

I dont want to sound like im hating on the Protac HL. By all means its a great light but I just think for EDC the 2L is a much better option and will give you much more run time--saving $$$ in battery costs. Plus, streamlight upgraded all the newer lights to 260 LUMENS! ITS NOT 180. For the price, you can't beat it!

reviews: I purchased the single battery light because I carry the light all day at work and wanted something small. I love the light and would definitely purchase again. The momentary on switch works flawless and is great for when you need to check something quick. At 120 lumens it is wonderfully bright and in certain situations I need to use low because it's too bright. I purchased li-on rechargeables separately and they'll last a day with normal use. I like the fact that when the battery gets low and the light shuts off, you can quick flick it to low and it will work for a while longer so you can finish what you're doing before having to flip in a charged battery. I've dropped mine a few times on a concrete floor from shoulder high and it was fine. Battery life could be an issue if non-rechargeables were used perhaps but I wouldn't know. Great light, if you're on the fence about it, go for it, you'll be glad you did.

review_title: Small light packs a big punch
reviews:
This light is one of the brightest I've used in my law enforcement career. I enjoy the small size, which makes it easy to carry in my shirt pocket. This saves me space on my belt to add another toy. This light is brighter than the Streamlight Strion I was issued and 1/4 the size.

I would recommend using rechargeable batteries because it will save you money in the long run but the light does not drain the battery too bad. It has three light settings: bright, strobe, and low beam. This helps it stand out from the rest of the flashlights the same size.

The only real issue is you cannot use it as a weapon like you could a bigger light but then again, this is not its intended use. I have used this light in the field and I love it.

review_title: Long-term reliability is suspect. Consider yourself warned.
reviews: Got this about 18 months ago. Started off excellent, light was bright, easy to carry. For the last few months it's not turning on reliably anymore. Yeah, if I keep pressing the button it'll eventually turn on, but then the next time the switch is wonky again. This won't cut it when you need light right away. #83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: No issues except for the clip.
reviews:
The light itself is very bright and works well. The switch works great and I am happy with its operation.

The only issue is with the clip. The clip barely wraps around 50% of the circumference of the light. If you try to clip it on your pocket, the clip just flies right off. The pocket clip is not to be trusted whatsoever and the only thing it is good for is to stop the light from rolling on an incline. If you carry this light, you will either have to put it in your pocket entirely or use the included nylon holster. The nylon holster is a bit cheap/velcro, but it at least works.

Overall it's a good light, it would be a five star review if it were not for the almost useless pocket clip.

reviews: I have about 15 lights, including one other Streamlight. I just received this 88040 light and like it a lot. Both Streamlight and Surefire are great quality, and although Streamlights are made in China, apparently they are able to exercise at least some quality control. This light was definitely 600 lumens, unlike almost most any light that comes from China, and claims that degree of brightness. I compared it to a great 200 lumen Surefire I have, and this is definitely much brighter. Note that there are many, many (no name)lights to choose from, mostly all China made, and take my word for it (or not) that you get what you pay for. You can not buy a high quality 600 lumen or higher handheld flashlight for $25. PERIOD. I have tried a couple--don't waste your money. I am sure the Surefire 500 lumen light is great also, but it was closer to $120, with shipping. The ony negative I have re: this light is that it has a broader beam than I would like. For walking the dog at night, this is great, but I was looking for a more focused beam. But, this is bright, has great throw, and will function well for why I bought it, namely as a tactical light to use in my home in case of intruders, to buy myself a second or two advantage. Note: I have several other lights in this lumen range, but they are all substantially larger--some more expensive, some around this price.

reviews:
Probably the best tactical mini-light I have owned. It has worked without a hiccup for several years of constant life in my pocket. Recently, it survived an accidental wash/dry cycle. The recessed lens is very well protected behind some aluminum prongs. To the point where I have dropped it lens first onto concrete with no loss of function. (Just minor scuffing on the finish.) The water seal is also amazingly good given that it survived a trip through the washing machine and drier with no loss of function or apparent damage.

One minor issue is heat buildup during sustained use in high intensity mode. In ~15 minutes the light gets a bit uncomfortable to hold, but that's to be expected given the LED output and the small size of the light. In any case, while the light was uncomfortable, it was still cool enough to handle.

Highly recommended.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Good manufacturing. No low battery warning. Just poof!
reviews:
I'm going to be a little harsh. The quality of the flashlight is very good, however. The little rubber thingie in the back disappeared one day and I have no idea where or how it fell off. The real issue with me is that there is no indication of the batteries running low. It works, then it doesn't. Lousy for any tactical situations. I can't afford to have a flashlight that "might" work when I turn it on. If I had some kind of indication - lights getting progressively low - then I could work with it. But it doesn't do that.

General size: awesome. Standard battery sizes: awesome. General durability: Good to great. Overall: Ehhh. Good for what I need it to do, but I always keep a spare battery pack in my bag. I made a leather holder for it. Photo should show missing button piece.

9 Sep 2017: Update
So my little Streamlight finally went poof ... and a permanent basis. The switch has been acting up, and although I ignored it for a while it just got worse. I just re-read the review "By Andrew on October 26, 2013" and it seems that there was an issue with the switch. The light itself (LED), the housing all seem both fine and durable. However, without a switch that works, the flashlight doesn't work.

So I bought a generic LED flashlight at Lowe's and that one works fine. I now have a paperweight. Sigh.
Purchased: 25 Mar 2016
Died: Sept 2017

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
Very, very bright and especially powerful for its size. I wear it clipped in my shirt pocket next to my pen. There's also a much dimmer setting. Tap the rubber on/off button on the end three times and you'll get the dim beam which is still as bright or brighter than most flashlights--saves the battery. (Batteries are about $2 each.) However, if you do need the power, the bright beam is sensational. It will light up a wall or trees 100 feet away with no effort. I use it (as a security guard) to examine the floor beneath radiators in a 30-story building to see if there are leaks. I can see clearly from 50 feet away and don't have to go in each room.

Expensive but worth it.

review_title: I've found my new everyday carry flashlight and I love it
reviews: I absolutely love this flashlight. Over the past few years I have used an Inova T1, which I also love. This Streamlight ProTac 1L only uses one CR123A lithium battery, though, while the Inova T1 uses two. Sure the T1 is slightly brighter on high at 211 lumens versus 180 for the ProTac, but the ProTac is quite a bit smaller and lighter, comes with a sheath and is $37 versus $55. Both flashlights are made of aircraft aluminum so they both shine in that aspect. Both also have a high, a low and a strobe. From now on, I think I will keep my T1 at home and use the Streamlight as my everyday carry.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
I bought this to keep in my work bag, as I work outdoors in all weather conditions and all times of day and night. That plan quickly went away when I realized how useful and small it was. Now I keep it in my pocket at all times and it sure has come in handy.

The high beam is a good mixture of spot and flood, and will reach about 50 feet reliably. After that it noticeably starts to dim. For up close work it's almost too much as anything light colored almost glows in the beam. If you're looking for small items under seats or trying to see what's happening on the other side of the street it's superb.

The strobe function is very disorienting. It has a reasonably fast cycle time and would work well for signaling as well.

The low beam provides a nice general duty level of light. It's not enough to see fibers in the carpet, but enough to read a map by or identify a person without blinding them.

As far as build quality it's tough, after a month in my pocket putting up with rain, hard impacts and my fingers fiddling with it it hasn't shown any damage beyond lint build up around the power button. The belt or pocket clip does swivel around the body of the light and is removable so over time this might lead to scratches, but nothing on mine so far.

An initial fear I had was that it would accidentally turn on in my pocket, but the switch has enough resistance it takes a deliberate firm press to activate it.

The pouch is a decent nylon sheath with a Velcro closure as well as a Velcro'd strap to go around your belt. The only issue I've had with the pouch is that when I sit down it gets pushed up my belt and presses into my back, and the Velcro over the opening is a bit small. If it catches on anything it sometimes opens up. I considered this an extra so I won't let it affect my overall review.

Pros:
Pocketable
Dependable
Well built
Bright

Cons:
Pouch belt loop is too big for normal belts
Swiveling belt clip
Strobe function being between high and low

reviews:
A good flashlight is one piece of recommended equipment while carrying a sidearm according to all the forums I have been reading. I had been reading reviews about tactical flashlights for several weeks before deciding on this light. My deciding factors were:

-brightness
-LED technology
-long shelf life of lithium
-low weight
-reasonable price

This light met all of my criteria in a trusted name brand. It is so light-weight, I did not notice the weight on my belt and this thing is bright. I do not own any other LED flashlights, but this little thing is brighter than my 3 D-cell Mag-light.

Controls are easy enough for my 4 and 5 year old kids to figure out so I'd say its easy to operate and worth the $.

I'm not disappointed.

reviews: Great light. Bright, small, and once you get the hang of how fast to click to switch modes or program, it's easy. One reviewer said it won't run on rechargeable batteries. It will run great on rechargeable NiMH AA cells (i.e. eneloop, powerex, etc). I don't know if you can use rechargeable 123 cells (RCR123 or RCR123A) since the voltage is higher (3.7 volts instead of 3). Run lithium AA for really long run times (will be as bright as with a regular AA, not the very high brightness of CR123 cells).

HL 4, Needed a lightweight spotlight on a budget and this is pretty much it.

The handle is thicker than it needs to be for 18650/cr123 batteries, this was likely done to make it proportional to the very large head.
Rubber overmoulding on the handle/body is nice and helps with the grip but has an offensive odor, it needs to off-gas for a while.

Very bright, good throw.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
Keep in mind what you are buying before you get it. If you want a feature packed flashlight with the newest tech, get an olight, nitecore, or fenix light, but if you just want something that is both bright, easy to use, and extremely reliable, than you should not look any further then this. I have used mine for two years now, and despite the countless times I have dropped this light, got it wet, or thrown it in the bottom of a 45lb pack, it has never failed on me once. On a fresh pair of Duracell CR123s, the light has a throw of around 600 feet.

PROS:
Reliable
Bright
Easy to access all three modes (High, Strobe, Low)
Good throw
CONS:
Lowest mode is still really high, which limits this to being a nightstand light and not my main camping/edc light

reviews:
When I was looking for a weapon light for a Maverick 88 12 gauge shotgun I was looking for something affordable to be mounted on the magazine tube. Once I found a suitable mounting device, this light offers the right amount of light for indoor home protection. It puts out high, strobe, and low functionality with a tap of the switch that takes some getting use to. For me, having CR123 lithium battery capability is great because the cells stay fresh for years and they fit in my other Streamlight weapon lights. If needed, I can remove the light and use it as a flashlight as well, increasing versatility.

If you are trying to put together a home defense shotgun that is very affordable, this is hard to beat.

reviews: I bought this because I know someone who has had one for about a year and really likes it. Unfortunately on the one I received the programmable switch did not function. reviews:
Great flashlight. I've owned it for several years. I use it in the cockpit of a fighter, and prefer it to the issued Surefire Fury P3X due to its small size, light weight, and uniform diameter. I've dropped it several times, and it still works.

The flaw: The sequence of click-operation is high, strobe, low. To activate low-intensity mode, which is what I use most often, I have to click through high and strobe first. Even a flash of high can hurt night-vision, and this is inconvenient if turning the light on and off frequently.

reviews:
Pros
‚Ä¢ Very compact
‚Ä¢ Easy to carry
‚Ä¢ Good light output for the size.
‚Ä¢ LED bulb for reduced power consumption

Cons
‚Ä¢ May be on the small side for users with large hands
‚Ä¢ Protac series have a HIGH/STROBE/LOW beam activated via the momentary button on the tail cap. To cycle through the modes, you just partially depress the button - once for high, twice for strobe, three times for low. To engage in the on position, cycle to the desired mode then fully depress the button until in clicks. I wish the modes cycle path was HIGH/LOW/STROBE.
‚Ä¢ One CR123A battery. Frequent use of HIGH will likely require frequent battery replacement if full light output intensity is desired.

reviews:
If you are looking for a light which has all the features of a self-defense light without wanting to spend the highers prices for professional-level tactical lights ($80-$150), this is the light for you.

The features which make this a great light for self defense:
- Small, but not too small, size. You can carry this on your belt easily without it getting in the way.
- Crazy bright, and I mean stunningly bright, light. This will stop someone in their tracks.
- The button is on the back end, so you can hold it in your fist.
- The button will turn on the light with gentle pressure instead of a full click and release (as most lights do).
- Three modes: normal, strobe, and dim are perfect (including the strobe rate).
- Crown bezel (probably the most minor advantage of the bunch).
- And a surprise feature I didn't expect: the belt clip is a snap release allowing for very fast deployment.

Potential disadvantages:
- Not rechargeable - it uses standard batteries.
- The batteries are not typical AA, or AAA, but still appear to be easy to find at local stores.

I would heartily recommend this light in a heartbeat! It is the only light I have found so far which fits the the self defense application well, and doesn't cost a hefty amount. If you are a pro who uses a light every day then you may want to spend the extra money for a rechargeable but this light is fantastic.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster
rank:
#9,282 in Tools & Home Improvement (See Top 100 in Tools & Home Improvement)

review_title: I like the tap functions A LOT
reviews: There is an advisory slip that comes with this light about suggested batteries with use of this light. After a week of sitting there won't be enough power to turn it on. I wonder if it's because of the ten tap programming in the tail cap. I have yet to test non rechargeable batteries. Now I just put in the battery when I carry it, and take it out during storage. I like the tap functions A LOT, they make mode switching fast and easy. For the price it's a good light. #83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Get thread-locker for the push button ring - otherwise it's a big punch in a small package
reviews: I have several of these, they work great; the compact size and small batteries allow for a sufficiently thin diameter to fit in my cargo pants pen pockets and pack a big punch for the size. Thus far I have only one complaint, the push button is replaceable and thus has a thin threaded ring to hold the rubber in place; unfortunately, that ring can come off easily due to normal use and even movement in your pocket. My recommendation is to immediately put some mild thread-locker on the threads for the ring, before using it. My first lost the ring and became flooded and died, all others have had the mild thread-locker (cheapo brand) and they have been working for years.

reviews:
The 2L is an awesome flashlight. I put it in my pocket and use the clip to keep it accessible at the top. I have the 1L too, but it is just a little too short for my liking (it is also dimmer and has less battery life - but only uses one battery). The 2L is a great size. Only two negatives. The first is that the batteries are a little pricey, but the batteries allow for the great size and performance, so I can live with that. The other is that the clip has come off the flashlight twice in about 6 months. It's not a big deal to pop it back on, as long as you hear it fall. Both times were when I was getting into car. The clip normally feels pretty stable, but just be aware that it does come off with extra pressure.

Carrying it with me everyday, I have been a little rough on it. It has some scrapes, but still works perfectly. If anything happened to my 2L, I would definitely buy another. Highly recommended.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Fantastic Flashlight. Perfect for technicians who need a good, solid, reliable flashlight.
reviews:
In my opinion, this is an excellent flashlight. The size is not to big but it has a substantial feel, unlike smaller diameter flashlights which feel small in the hand. The larger diameter of the body feels just right and when holding it. I am a maintenance technician at a manufacturing facility and I use this light daily on the job. It's absolutely perfect. The beam spill/throw has a tactical focus with a good bright center circle that doesn't have a sharp edge and gradually spreads out the further away it is shone. It spills some light to the sides to see where you're going. I also own the 2L version, which is slightly brighter, but not enough to justify the extra length. I've owned it for over a year now and have never experienced any issues with the tail cap switch. If you buy Duracell batteries off of Amazon in multiples of 10 or so, you can get them for about $2 each. I go through a battery every 2 months, give or take a couple of weeks. My only gripe would be the holster; it works fine but over time and repeated use the hook & loop (Velcro) on the flap closure deteriorates and won't stay closed.

UPDATE:
I have found rechargeable batteries for this here on Amazon:http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00FWN297W/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

They work great! For only $10 I now have two batteries that I can swap out as needed. No more need to buy disposable, one-time use batteries anymore! This makes this flashlight absolutely perfect! I used to use it sparingly because the CR123 batteries have a cost, but that problem is no longer an issue.

I modified the holster, as the hook & loop closure was worn out and had become completely unusable. I carefully shaved off the remaining hooks and loops with a disposable razor, then using an exacto knife I carefully cut open the stitching of the hook and loop patches enough to insert a small neodymium magnet into the closure flap and a small piece of flat metal into the holster. I then sewed them back shut with a sewing needle and black thread to secure them from falling out. The result is fantastic! The magnet allows the flap to quickly cling to the holster without worrying about alignment. It also makes opening and closing virtually silent. It is far easier to access the light now and to return it to the holster. I will soon be replacing the holster as it is becoming torn near the bottom where the tactical flares of the lens have been chafing the holster. It has held up remarkably well though, considering the use and abuse I've put it through. I will be shaving off the hooks and loops from the new holster and swapping in my magnet and metal plate over to the new holster as soon as it arrives.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Surefire quality at a Streamlight price
reviews: This light was purchased to carry on duty. I have a few older Surefire lights to compare it to. While I looked at the newer Surefire lights (and they are fine quality flashlights) there are two reasons I went with the Streamlight. One was price, while the quality of the Surefire is good they have kind of priced themselves out of the police market except for SWAT teams who have a lot of their gear issued by the agency, hence price is not a concern. The second reason I went with the Streamlight was the tail cap which has a rim on it to prevent it from coming on accidentally when you sit down in a car seat (I wear the light behind my left hip and on the Surefire if you don't back the tail cap out every time you holster it the light comes on draining those expensive CR123 batteries). Another positive was the 260 lumen output. If you take one of the older LED's (60-80 lumen range) and try to search a large open area the light dissipates too much to allow an effective search. For building searches I would have to break out the old halogen light (a Straemlight Super Stinger which is 15 years old, carried on duty all of those years and still works but is on its fourth battery by now). With a 260 lumen output I don't have to switch lights although I still go to the rechargeable light depending on how big the building is. The only downside to this light is nobody that I have found makes a good duty holster for it, but it's small enough I usually just put it in my shirt cargo pocket. Thus far I have dropped it once from about three feet on to asphalt and it still runs just fine. The jury is still out in terms of durability but as my other Streamlight is again 15 years old and still running, I suspect it will do just fine. On a side note it is supposedly programmable but I have not messed with that feature. If things were to go bad I want the light to come with all the power it has quickly, not be fumbling with what mode it's instead of getting a gun on the threat. It comes from the factory set to be either on at full power or off. I think that about covers everything.

reviews:
I've had this light for around 3 weeks now and I use it for work. I would like to start by saying that this is the second streamlight I have owned and it is bright for 180 lumens rating, streamlight is up there with surefire and fenix minus the expensive price tag. I leave for work when it's still very dark way before everyone wakes up and so I use this to walk to my car looking for anything unusual and where I currently live at there are bears, coyotes, and other creature of the night that I don't want having any interests in me as well as muggers. I also use this for backup light while I use my coast flashlight for vehicle inspections.

The momentary on is a great feature, changing modes on the light requires using momentary on which doesn't really bother me since all I really need the light for is to see what's in my surrounding or to blind a suspicious person during my job along with the use of OC should the person being inspected decide to start trouble. This light is small and compact yet gets the job done and won't get in your way of driving or work and additionally it is very lightweight.

It uses 1 cr123a battery to me this isn't a problem, so far my light is still bright and I haven't changed the battery yet therefore the runtime is excellent. It comes with a holster and already installed on it is a clip.

Overall, a good torch will light up the night very bright and uses 1 cr123a instead of 2 or more so saves me on money for batteries, having a holster is a plus but if you need to put it on a duty belt unfortunately it won't do. I would recommend to anyone who is in need of a bright compact light for use with almost anything.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster
rank:
#9,282 in Tools & Home Improvement (See Top 100 in Tools & Home Improvement)
#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
I recently swapped my Streamlight Protac 2AAA, which I've carried every day for about 2 years, for this gem. This isn't a lot thicker, but it's a few inches shorter, and it packs a punch for light output. My wife has had her Protac 2L for a year or so and I had to get one of my own.

I am a fan of the 10-tap programming, which isn't difficult to figure out, but I prefer the factory setting (High-Strobe-Low), so I didn't use this feature except to say I had tried it. The beam pattern is very even with no dark spots, and it has a nicely focused hotspot right in the center. When comparing to my Jetbeam PC20, which advertises considerably higher lumen output, I noticed the Protac 2L actually was brighter in the center area, which is where I'm typically focused when using my lights, anyway. The Jetbeam DID have more flood than this light, though, so that may be where the other lumens factor in. On this note, I have always felt Streamlight to be conservative in their lumen rating; when comparing to lights from other manufacturers, I have found time and again the Streamlights are actually brighter than lights with a higher lumen rating. I may not know how to compare a lumen to a candela, but I do know a light rated at 260 lumens should have less light than a light rated at 400 lumens. If you are new to LED flashlights or if you havent bought one in a few years, the amount of light pouring out if this compact light will wow you.

The body of this light is nicely finished and a good bit smaller than my jetbeam light that also uses two cr123 batteries. The clip is sturdy and isn't going to come off without a stout tug. The switch is recessed and has a good, affirmative click. It's also easy to do a momentary press without actually clicking the light into the steady-on position. I'm not too hot with morse code, but this style switch would make something like this easier.

When considering the build quality, the price, battery life, and light output, I felt this light was the best in it's class.
While I won't deny a Surefire is a superb flashlight, and I have owned them, their lights just don't deliver enough extra benefit to be worth the premium in price. A Streamlight lasts forever, and I have found time and again they will stand by their warranty if you do manage to break something. I've had my Stinger LED since 2008 and it's still going strong with nothing more than a few battery replacements. My TLR-1, TLR-1s, TLR-3, Stylus, and Stylus Pro have all shown consistency in this level of quality.

When I have needed repairs on my Streamlights (which is RARE), I take them by my local dealer who will either repair it in-store or ship it to Streamlight free of cost to process the warranty repair.I love a company who stand behind their products!!

review_title: I really like this light and have ordered 3 more for family ...
reviews: It's blinding! I really like this light and have ordered 3 more for family members. It's small enough to carry in my pocket or a purse and lights up the night. My purpose is more self defense/tactical and to blind an attacker to give me an edge, it does that very well. All it takes is a brief press of the button to instantly blind a person and startle them. I've given them to my wife, daughter, and son to carry when coming out of work or out and about at night. It's also a great flashlight to work on projects in tight places. The strobe function is a bit tricky to make work at first but works well once you practice. I would recommend this to anyone who's looking for a compact very bright light for any purpose.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: ProTac 2L-X. Almost perfect light. Will almost tail stand but not quite. Needs a small spring for the positive battery contact.
reviews:
This review is for the ProTac 2L-X

I really like most things about this light. I'd been buying cheap lights that advertise as 1000 lumen or more that have much brighter xml-t6 bulbs. Comparing them to this light, they're not any brighter. I believe this light to be more efficient or maybe the T6's being used by the cheapest flashlights are under-performing to where they're about 500 as this light actually is. The Ten-tap is awesome and works flawlessly. I do have a couple
gripes that would be easy for Streamlight to correct that I'll list at the bottom for easy reading.

Pros: Ten-tap works perfect
500 lumen is probably accurate and equal to the suposed 1000 lumen of the cheap lights
size and weight is great for edc

cons: light will not tail stand. The button is inset like it was meant to but the rubber sticks out about 1/8 inch too far.
the contact for the positive end of the battery is flat so some 18650 batteries will not work without adding some solder to them
The clip interferes with removing the switch for battery charging/swapping. I don't use it but if you do, it's annoying

These 3 cons could easily be corrected with inexpensive adjustments.

reviews: I just purchased two of these lights. One for the wife and I for our EDC. I opened the package up and was pleasantly surprised. It comes with a case and two batteries as promised. I was surprised at the size of the light . It fit in my hands with no problem. I compared it to my Techlight Lumen Master 200. Size wise they both are handy but the Streamlight is a little bit longer by an inch and a little heavier. They both feature a cap activation button with three modes. My Techlight is easier to manipulate between the different modes compared to the Streamlight. I have yet to get it to strobe or low mode. I'm still working on the instructions for operating the different modes. They are programmable, which I've never heard of before. This means you can customize it s little. The Streamlight has a pocket pen/pocket clip that seems to be sturdy enough. It fits in my 5.11 pants pocket with no problem. The case has velcro to fit on your belt and keeps it secure. I have not experienced any problems so far with it coming out, as stated in another review. We'll see what happens. My Techlight only has a lanyard. I couldn't wait till it got dark. I took the dog for a walk about 1am and man was I ever happy. I walk through the woods and this time I had more than enough light. I compared my lights and found the Streamlight to be much brighter. Wow! With 600 lumens burning it got warm to the touch. It's to be expected burning three times as much light. I really like it and will be using it everyday. For stranded motorist it will help you see and be seen. You can't go wrong with this light for the money, size and definitely for the brightness.

reviews: Years ago I was a Maglite fan, then Surefire lights came onto the scene and I "thought" I had solved all my lighting needs...then I discovered Streamlight. To me Streamlight is the Glock of the tactical illumination world. Well made, rugged, affordable and reliable. You get ALL the functionality and in most cases more than that of much more expensive lights for a fraction of the cost. Not to mention that Streamlight has WONDERFUL customer service. Here's a personal testimony; I own several PT 1L's. I carry one daily. Some how I managed to shatter the bezel on one of them. I have no idea how. I called Streamlight to inquire upon repair. They didn't even allow me to explain. I didn't have to. The technician simply said please mail the flashlight back via a trackable means and give us a few days. Approximately $9.00 bucks for shipping...Next thing you know I had a brand new PT 1L in the mail. No questions asked, no hoops to jump through. Streamlight has my business for life. Keep up the good work guys! Looking forward to future developments from your company.

review_title: Attn. Cops: Read this for real talk.
reviews:
Four stars. Here's why:

1. I work patrol at nights....I haven't found anyone with a brighter flashlight than this one. If we are looking for something/someone in the dark, everyone wants me beside them because this thing turns night to day. So incredibly bright when it's on the 1100 lumen setting. Words cannot describe how awesome this flashlight is when you need to cut deep into the darkness.

2. I really wanted to give it three stars, but it's better than that. I reason I almost provided a three star rating is because IT TAKES THE MOST EXPENSIVE BATTERIES EVER MADE. CR-123's do NOT come cheap, Streamlight! Come on now.... This thing needs two upgrades as far battery issues go: Make it a bit longer so it can have both a rechargeable battery in it AND some CR-123's. In times of crisis, 2 hours of the bright setting is not enough! We rely on these things when times get hard in the field....whether it be a homicide invest., car accident, kidnapping invest., searching for a bank robber in the woods..... It is not acceptable for the battery to die after 2 hours. Enough said about that.

3. Design and Functionality: Ughhhh..... It has a button on the rear of the light. It NEEDS a button there as well as a shaft button near the head of the flashlight. It just does. Other than that, it is built tough.

This is the my biggest grievance other than the battery deal: IT GOES FROM A BLINDING 1100 LUMEN HIGH SETTING TO 60 LUMENS ON THE LOW SETTING!!! 60 lumens?!?!? How did it never cross anyones mind that those are two extremely different settings and there needs to be a happy medium?!?! You've got 2 hours at 1100 lumens, then you've got 36 hours at 60 lumens....So why on God's green earth can I not have 250 lumens for 10-12 hours???? Every now and then, 60 lumens works, but it is often not enough...at which time I'll switch to the 1100 lumens high setting, but sometimes that is just too much brightness. Fix it Streamlight....Just fix it and email me when you do so I can buy 10 of the upgraded models.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
I've carried this flashlight every day for the last four months or so (recently broke it in a fit of rage, more on that later). I found it to be a worthwhile investment, but instead of buying another one I'm stepping up to a brighter light (at twice the price).

Fit & Finish - The finish on the body of the light is pretty durable. It wore through the coating on the ends of the light and on the high spots (particularly around the anti-roll part on the body near the LED). Other than that, the finish on the body has held up great to being washed, soaked in motor oil, soaked in brake fluid, and being dropped from 1-2m. It was dropped & exposed to the above chemicals daily and the finish was never damaged and the light never ceased to function. The only thing that killed the light was me throwing it at a concrete floor when I was mad (this scratched up the body some, knocked the "lens" off the LED, and messed up the circuit).

The end-caps did occasionally loosen themselves, rendering the light useless, but fixing that was as simple as tightening them back up. The batteries do occasionally jiggle in the body (I used SureFire batteries, your results may vary). The threads on the light are not the highest quality, but they certainly get the job done. The o-rings could be thicker as well, but the light never leaked.

The clip has a good tension to it. Not to tight and not to loose, works great in a pants pocket, but doesn't hold onto thin fabrics as well. It wore through the coating along the edges as one would expect, but it does not stand up to chemicals (particularly brake fluid) as well as the body. The finish didn't just come off, but it did fade/dull quite a bit.

Brightness - It could certainly use a middle setting. I found the low setting to be useless 95% of the time and the high setting to be overpowering on occasion. I can't comment on how it compares to other 180-lumen lights, but there are plenty of comparison videos around the net. The high setting is certainly enough to blind someone at night, even in the city, and the strobe will give them quite the headache.

Battery consumption - At full power, you'll kill the batteries in just over an hour.

Holster - I don't think it fit the light well nor did it sit well on a belt. I simply threw it away; the light has a pocket clip after all.

Switch - Took a little getting used to at first, but once you get the hands of it, it is really easy and quick to work. I never had any problems with it malfunctioning. I like the switch.

Misc - If it's on a flat surface that doesn't move/vibrate, I can get the light to tailstand. It will be tilted slightly to one side, but it stands. Lights a room up well tailstanding. Standing it on it's face (light shining down), not much light is emitted, even on high.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

review_title: A bright flashlight for a good price.
reviews:
This flashlight is very small and very bright. It has 3 settings accessible from the button at the base of the casing. A click turns it on.

I deduct a star because you must partially push the button in to change settings. If you accidentally push all the way and click, then the flashlight turns on. You then have to turn it off and try again to partially push down the button two or three times to get to the second or third setting. Other flashlights make this easier to do.

For the money, I'm satisfied.

It does have a thin barrel profile and had to improvise when mounting the 1 battery version of this light in a Phoenix mount. reviews: So far this has been one of my most used edc gear items. It is fantastic, its light weight, rides deep in the pocket put still easy to pull out, and also bright! The high mode was a lot brighter then I thought it would be, and it works great outside. Ive used it at night outdoors a lot, and its great. Indoors it lights up the whole room, and if you don't need that much light, the low mode is great too, especially is your just using it to read a book. The battery also lasts long enough and lasts longer then I expected. The only flaw it has, is one thing, which is why I give it 4 instead of 5 stars. Sometimes, when I do the soft tap, it wont turn on, and I have to hard click for it to turn on. Sometimes even when I hard click it, it wont turn on. Most the time I just kind turn it a little and barely bump the head of it and then it will work fine. It only takes like 2 seconds to fix, but as it is technically a "tactical flashlight", I expect it to turn on every time. It also could be some defect or problem that is just unique to mine. I would recommend.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: I love the products and have had ZERO problems
reviews: Including buying a couple for gifts, I have pruchased 12 Streamlight flashlights over the last few years. I love the products and have had ZERO problems. The Protac 1L I'm reviewing here, is a very convenient size, though my favorite medium-Lumens model is the Protac 2L. Streamlight flashlights do hold up well to dropping; (ask me how I know this). I honestly don't know if they will last as long as Surefire flashlights, which truly are quality products; but Streamlight hits the perfect Price / Performance threshold for me. The ones that are made of aircraft aluminum, (Protac series and others), are great tools, (yes tools), for convenience and safety. The Protac 2L and higher Lumen flashlights REALLY WILL blind a bad guy for at least a few seconds, during which you can get out of the area. Also, it is LEGAL to carry a flashlight anywhere, even in Europe. You may not want to think about it, but these flashlights do make a really good striking weapon, as a near last resort. A few reviewers write of getting a bad flashlight; no problem, just exchange it. Again, 12 flashlights so far, zero problems. I report, you decide.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster
rank:

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Great... But too BIG for EDC
reviews:
Nicely made, robust construction, very bright. Easy to charge with computer or iPad/iPhone charger. The bigger iPad charger works great. Can also be charged in the newer cars that come with USB ports, or with a USB cable in a cigarette lighter adapter. I especially like the rechargeable feature.
Unless you are going to carry this on a duty belt, I feel it is too bulky in length, diameter & overall weight for EDC in a pocket. I personally prefer my Streamlight Pro-Tac 1L with its single CR123 battery. I like the fact that the HL can use the alternate batteries such as 2-CR123A's or lithium rechargeable 18650.
Comes programmed for "bright-strobe-low" but easily changed to "high only" or "low-medium-high" using the 10 tap programmable switch. On a side note you may consider the Pro-Tac 2L as an alternative for EDC.
Overall, if you are aware of its size, this light is great and I would recommend it to a friend.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster
rank:

reviews:
I have used an original incandescent bulb Stinger and incandescent bulb SL20 for years (decades). I recently purchased a Stinger DS HPL (720 lumen) light as my primary light and bought this ProTac HL3 as a back up light. I am fully impressed with the brightness of the ProTac HL3 (1100 lumen).
My only critiques so far is the reported run time of 1.25 hours on full brightness (therefore, it will be my back up light for now since it uses CR123 batteries), and lack of an intermediate setting (similar to the Stinger DS HPL). With that said, you can't beat the lumens.

I will update if I experience problems with the light as others have reported.

reviews: I was looking for a small but bright light to leave in my backpack. The PT 1AA was not bright enough so i got the PT 1L instead. It is significantly brighter. The light provides a great beam with a good spot and nice peripheral light. The things i dont like is that it is a bit too short. The 1AA was just about perfect. My hand has a tendency to block the beam a bit on the PT 1L. Also the order of the modes is not ideal for general use. It would be better for general use if the order was: low, high, and strobe. Granted i understand this is a tactical flashlight so the high, strobe, low order probably is best for police/military. The build quality is fantastic and the nylon holster is a nice bonus. If youre looking for a full size light, i would recommend the surefire g2x pro though because it is a bit brighter and the mode order is low then high.

This one replaced a Streamlight Stylus Pro that I keep in a tool kit that I take with me whenever I travel... I liked that light, but ended up donating it to someone somewhere on the eastern seaboard last month, so I got the ProTac as a replacement- mainly because I like the idea of having a high and low setting. Sometimes you want a blindingly bright beam, sometimes you want something a little less pupil crushing... not to mention the option to conserve battery life (I really like the idea of 30 hours on one set of batteries on Low).

Cycling through the modes is easy once you get the hang of it- as another reviewer mentioned, do so using "half-presses" of the tail switch, not "full clicks"- only "click" the button when you reach the desired mode.

Speaking of modes- I REALLY have no use for the strobe. I don't think 99.99% of the population does either. Even if I were using this light in conjunction with my pistol in a "tactical" situation, I'm 99.99999% sure I still wouldn't used the damned strobe. I'd just turn the flashlight on. Get rid of that useless, silly function- K.I.S.S.- keep it to "high" and "low" settings and I'll give it 5 stars.

UPDATE: I just thought of a use for the strobe function- impromptu living room dance parties during blackouts! Just kidding. I still hate it.

reviews: 4.5 stars rounds up to 5. The size is perfect for pocket clip carry. Works well with my K2 rechargeable CR123 (old Surefire brand) and Goal Zero AA and it does work with AAA, even though instructions do not recommend any of these. This is a triple fuel light. Beam is slightly yellow compared to my ProTac AA but that light is very blue and this resembles more a Surefire beam and the colors are true. Just bent the pocket clip, many reviews fault the design. Quick fix 1. Put on MacGyver 2. Get a small butane torch, glove and pliers 3. Heat up the bend until hot and use pliers to squeeze it a little and then cool off. This returns the tension. This is my new EDC light and I will buy more for the kids' rooms, go bags, vehicles and gifts.
