reviews: My only other light is a olight m-21x warrior, which is great but I wanted something smaller and more comfortable for every day carry in pocket. I chose this because of the small size, price ($30), and use of available anywhere aaa batteries, and I can use the low 10 lumen setting for patient assessment. The high 80 lumens is pretty bright considering the size, i find it acceptable coming from the m21x (m21x has farther throw and larger bright spot as expected). It seems pretty sturdy even though it's very light, i wouldn't hesitate to use the crenelated bezel and i like that it has it. The black on mine started to rub off in a spot cuz I clipped it next to my pocket knife (won't do that again), so be aware of that with keys etc.. The button is stiff but makes it easy and intuitive to switch through modes, as well as not accidentally turning on in the pocket (hasn't happened yet!), so I like it. I like that the clip can be removed and place closer to the tail. I think my next light will be the olight m3x sold here on amazon- a little bigger but insanely bright and crenelated on both ends

reviews:
I had been looking at expensive high-end flashlights for quite a while, but just couldn't bring myself to spend $100+ on just a flashlight. That's when I found the Streamlight PT 2L on Amazon.com!! I have had it for just over 6 months now, carry it every day, and have had ZERO problems. I've even dropped it on concrete multiple times, and have used it as a door stop a few times too. This little thing is just amazing, outrageously bright on the high setting! The brightness to size ratio is incredible, I can shine my enormous 3D Maglite on the wall, and this PT 2L almost completely drowns out the light from the Maglite. The CR123A batteries are relatively cheap and long-lasting. Plus, they won't corrode inside the flashlight, even if you leave it sit for prolonged periods of time.

You don't realize how many times you could use a flashlight, until its right there in your pocket. At first, my friends tried to give me crap for carrying the flashlight around with me, but now they are constantly asking me to, "Turn on the sun!" =D

I HIGHLY RECOMMEND this flashlight to anyone looking for amazing performance, in a small, inexpensive package!

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
Good product for the price. Pocket clip is strong and functional. Nice that it can be clipped to a hat without having to take the clip off and flip it backwards. Nicely redesigned. Light is bright with a neutral tint. Low is useful at 40 lumens, high is well suited for a variety of tasks both indoors and outdoors. NOTE: I am referring to 350 lumens high setting with a CR123 battery. The dual fuel capability is versatile and more and more lights will probably have this feature moving forward. Comparing the beam to a Streamlight ProTac 1L (180 lumen CR123 light) the hot spot in the 1L-1AA is larger and hotter. It fills more space with more light giving better peripheral vision. The low setting of 40 lumens is (IMO) more effective for indoor tasks that require more than 12 lumens but not 180 (high ProTac 1L) or 350 (high for 1L-1AA with CR123). This gives enough light to easily see indoors without going through your battery too fast. The light feels nice in the hand. It's slightly longer than the ProTac 1L and the tail cap has knurling which adds a more secure feeling when you hold it.

Now I want to talk batteries. There is a rechargeable that is safe to use with these lights. You can also use these batteries with Surefire lights. Amazon sells them. Here is a link.

K2 Energy LFP123A Rechargeable Li Ion 3.2V Battery Replaces CR123A - Single

These batteries are fully charged at 3.65v. They can be used safely to 2.8v. They have a nominal capacity of 600mAh. The chemistry is Lithium Iron Phosphate or LiFePO4. They maintain a steady 3.2v. This means your light will maintain a high level of light output. If using the light for a long time the microprocessor may stage down the light output because of thermal regulation, but not due to the voltage dropping. 3.2v is maintained for more than 90% of the charge cycle. Once the light enters "low mode" turn the light off, and charge them up. Simple. Over discharging can damage them. The runtimes are decent in the Streamlights I own. Protac 1L, ProTac 1L-1AA. I also use this in a Gen 2 Surefire Fury, 600 lumens. (no runtime test yet conducted on the Surefire with these batteries) It saves money in the long run and the fact that you can charge them up at any time means you will not have to guess how much power is in your light. When you turn on your light, you're getting max output, sustained. One battery charges in 80 min and 2 batteries charge in 160 minutes. Those charge times reflect 2.8v up to full at 3.65v. I use the charger that came with the batteries made by the same company. There is a picture in the link above. You can charge these batteries ONLY in a charger that specifically states it can charge LiFePO4 batteries! Here is another example:

XTAR VP2 Independent 2-Channel Battery Charger w/ Dual Voltage Display, USB Power Bank for 18560 and similar Lithium Ion and LiFePO4 Cells (Simple Kit - no Car Charger included, A/C adapter only)

Do not charge above C/1. The capacity is 600mAh so charge at NO MORE THAN 600mA or .6A. Really 300mA (.3A) to 500mA (.5A) is safe and still fast. Keep a spare set with you and be ready. Most chargers come with or offer a car adapter to charge on the go.

Asp Law Enforcement CR123A Link Case (Pack of 4)

*update*
It's now Fri, 25 Aug 2017. After having this light for several months, I change my rating from 5 stars down to 4 stars. Here's why: The body of the light is too smooth. The knurling on the tail cap is not aggressive enough to provide a secure grip. The body having no knurling on it baffles my mind. The light output, beam quality, function, etc all remain excellent. The pocket clips dual use feature is still awesome. It simply needs to feel more secure in hand. I am still using and loving K2 LiFePO4 cells in this light.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

reviews:
Just a quick tip... This light ROCKS!!! It's small, compact and light weight. This light gives off a bright beam of light into the darkness. Good center beam. Good amount of side spill to light up the surrounding area. It has a strobe and dim led setting for various needs.

I turned off the back lights and went into a dark yard. My yard is about 180 feet long from wall to wall. I stood at one end and lit up the far side. If there were an animal of any sort or a bad guy lurking in the corner, it would have been spotted with ease and clarity!

A fellow co-worker who is extremely into tactical gear had purchased the smaller Pt1 version {(1)CR123 } battery and showed me how bright it was in the office.
After seeing it, I wanted one also. I just went with the (2) CR123 battery version. It does have a bit extra lumens for the bang factor.

Make sure you choose the light with the type of batteries you carry / use. I almost bought the AA version instead of the CR123, but observed the mistake before I bought it.

Great for a bug out bag or vehicle center console for those "uh-oh" moments when you need a light!!

This is not a "tactical" pistol grip style light. It's merely a light!!!! You can use it that way in a pinch, but not full time. It's pretty small for that.

The lights are not too expensive. Around 38 bucks or so, plus shipping costs.

It comes with a metal clip attached and a small carry case. The clip seems pretty sturdy with "heft" and will do the job! The carry case is plain and simple. It's a case guys. Dont make a purchase decision over a case.

Buy one and try it out!!! I dont think you will be sorry and have anything to complain about!!!

Here is the sarcasim...If you do complain, I'll bet you would complain about everything and anything.

I'm so pleased I bought 2 more.

Hope this helps you decide on buying this light!!
Have a better one!

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
The Streamlight reputation lives on nicely with the ProTac series. This one is the 2L (meaning it needs two lithium batteries).

At a compact 4-5/8" long and just under 1" thick, it's nicely-made for a pocket. The finish is anodized aluminum in black, and I love the matte finish Streamlight puts on their lights. A pocket clip is included, which can be removed. It keeps the light at the top of your pocket, ready to go. I have no complaints about the tension or the design, but it leaves quite a bit (a little over an inch) of the light sticking out of your pocket. Bump into the corner of a room, or a car, and the light pivots around the clip and comes out of your pocket. A basic nylon holster is provided, and it closes with a Velcro closure. The holster will fit a belt up to 2" wide, and to be honest, mine hasn't held up too well in daily use. It's basic and inexpensive. Two Streamlight-branded CR123A lithium batteries are provided. If you're an 18650 user, you can't use them in this light without boring it out.

The reflector appears to be plastic, and it's smooth. The lens is also plastic. I haven't seen any artifacts or rings in my ProTac at all, and the smooth reflector adds to the distance the beam can go. The beam is a nice combination of flood and throw, being just a little bit more throw-oriented. The tailcap has three modes: high, low, and strobe. The specs list high as 180 lumens. In my testing, it's about 140 lumens. Low appears to be accurate at 10 lumens. Strobe is 140 (listed at 180) lumens at 9 Hz. I didn't test runtime, but knowing Streamlight's specs, it should be about 80% of what's listed. The tailcap has a forward clicky switch, and it comes in in high, then low if you press it within half a second, then strobe if you press it within half a second of that.

The reason the ProTac doesn't get a higher rating with me is because it's a bit overpriced. Honestly, you can go to many flashlight websites and find a light with multiple modes, higher (and lower) output, with pretty much the same quality, at lower prices. Many Romisen lights have the same features as the ProTac, at 80% of the build quality, with half the price.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster
rank:
#9,282 in Tools & Home Improvement (See Top 100 in Tools & Home Improvement)

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Light is amazing and high quality known for Streamlight
reviews:
Light is amazing and high quality known for Streamlight. Don't waste your money on cheap flashlights that say they are high lumens because they can vary significantly and are usually falsely advertised. This states 1100 lumens which it may be as it is much brighter than my 420 lumen light high quality light I have which recently malfunctioned. That light was almost twice as much and even though its covered under warranty the value is diminished when compared to a light for half the price with equal quality and higher performance.

I've bought lights that state they are over 300 lumens for $50 and under but they are no brighter than a 90 lumen light I have.

I use this light is for police work and has a reasonable size to be mounted on a duty belt and fits your hand perfectly. If your not using a light for police work, cheaper lights will work just fine for you even if lumens are falsely advertised. But when you rely on illuminating as much as possibleto protect yourself or locate someone this light will get the job done.

One issue I have is the tail cap switch being recessed as much as it is but still functions as needed.

I haven't used it outside at night as of yet but have used it in a dark room and it illuminates everything with an acceptable focal beam. Based on this I would assume it will do just fine outside. I have used many flashlights over the years from Surefire, other Streamlight products and other cheap lights. This is the real deal for not a lot of money (under $90.00) where I have spent hundreds on others and this is comparable to any of those.

It does use the CR123A batteries and I wish it used AAA or AA batteries based on cost but I prefer standard batteries over rechargeable anyways because when it dies I can just replace the batteries instead of waiting for a recharge or spending $$$'s for a spare rechargeable battery that will eventually lose its life over time anyways.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
At 600 lumens, this light puts out a enough light to make a perp see spots when shined in their beady eyes. (don't try this at home!).

Other lights may have 660 or even 1000 lumens, but are either not in the same cost/benefit wheelhouse, or are overkill IMO. What's next, a light saber? I had one of those when I was a kid and it didn't scare anybody.

I just love, love, love how these manufactures weaponize these 'tec lights'. Come on now, they're not selling these high power lights to find your car keys. The lens has relatively sharp, 'sawtooth' corners surrounding the lens bezel. Only there to inflict more...um... discomfort from the multiple edging. There I said it. If you buy the corporate line that those corners are there to 'prevent roll away', then I have another Democrat for President for you.

There are limitations to this light however.

The strobe feature --now all you liberals cover your eyes---which is DESIGNED to disorient the aforementioned perp, is activated by tapping the power button. The only problem is that it takes some fine motor control in your finger to tap it just so. NOT going to happen in times of stress.

The 3V lithium batteries (yes, this light comes with batteries which arrived at a healthy 3.59 volts), do not like sustained cold temperatures. Or more correctly, they can tolerate the cold but need to be warmed up to generate reliable voltage. This means this is not the light to leave in your glove box during cold weather. You will have to work around that unless you just want a mini baton.

And speaking of batonage, the eye for a lanyard is part of the clip-on belt clip. This light would make for a nice, modern Flail if the lanyard loop was cast into the aluminum body. Because of the tension clip, I'm sure your light will reach escape velocity if you try too hard to go Medieval on someone. It's best used as an eyesocket probe at that point as the movie "Kill Bill" flashes through your mind--you know what I mean Hillary

So good luck and I hope you only use it to find your keys.

Just remember, never bring a flashlight to a gun fight.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster
rank:
#9,282 in Tools & Home Improvement (See Top 100 in Tools & Home Improvement)

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: how do you pick a flashlight?
reviews: There are so many brands and models of flashlight available I didn't know what flashlight to get. I finally decided that having ordinary batteries (AA or AAA) was important to me. That eliminated a lot of the really high lumen lights but it's a trade I was comfortable with. Streamlight 88039 takes AAA and the 88033 takes AA. Would 88039 be too small or 88033 too big? I finally decided to order them both. 88039 is a great size to carry clipped into your front pants pocket. It's not heavy or bulky. It's an amazingly bright light, a strobe mode, and a low light level. I really like it. The 88033 is the bigger brother. Everything is the same it's just bigger and brighter. I drop it into my pocket every morning and every night when I head outside, in the dark, to check on things in the barn. The high setting on 88033 seems to put out more light than my car headlights. Both lights illuminate a wide area, not a narrow beam. Very solid construction, easy operation. I'm very pleased with both flashlights and can recommend either of them.

review_title: Streamlight 88039 ProTAC 2AAA Battery Powered Tactical Penlight with white LED
reviews: I purchased this Streamlight ProTAC 2AAA powered Tactical Penlight on February 28, 2014. I carry and use the light almost every day. I am pleased with the light's compact size, brightness and the ability to switch to different modes. The one problem I have had from the first day is the tail switch is so stiff that it actually takes the use of two hands to switch it from "momentary on" to "constant on." I have to hold the light's body with on hand and push the click-switch with a finger or thumb of the other hand. I don't know if it is the switch itself, the rubber tail cap or the combination of the two that is too stiff. It could be the rubber tail cap, because when I remove the cap the switch is easier to activate. I have lived with it this far, hoping something would "break in" and the switch would become easier for me to work. It has not happened. I have had a Streamlight Stylus Pro with the same type of tail switch and it worked very well. Unfortunately, I lost it (which is why I bought this ProTAC light. Now that I have kept it this long, I will have to keep it and try Streamlight's customer service for parts replacement, if available. I will update this review when I find out.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews: For the price it can't be beat. To the eye it is no brighter than my surefire fury p2x tactical which is 500 lumens. Makes a great weapon light, will light up objects 80 to 100yrds away with no problem. Just used it at a night two gun competition, and it did excellent. Like the ability to lock it on high only for tactical use. The switching system between settings is a pain but no big deal really. The finish is not quite as nice as surefire's and neither is the push button in my opinion. It is easier to keep the light on with the streamlight than the surefire which you have to twist for constant. Overall probably the best light for the money, it isn't a surefire but you have to split hairs to find the difference. Durability only time will tell but I see no reason it will not take all kinds of abuse. Still running an original tlr-1 that has been thru a lot and is still going strong. I pretty much only use surefire or streamlight products and love the quality and value you get with streamlight.

reviews:
Bought this as a thin flashlight for my EDC pouch. (Checkout the Maxpedition Mini Pocket Organizer for that review.) It fits really well, because of this thin size. However, it isn't too thin to be difficult to grip. It is probably about the diameter of a Sharpie but a little longer.

The pushbutton activation works well. The light is VERY bright; 80 lumens will do the trick for sure. It feels pretty durable, but I haven't put it through any hard work yet. I also liked that it was power by AAA batteries, because I have a Streamlight MicroStream that lives in my pocket, which also runs on AAA's.

Overall, my experience with Streamlight products has been great. Save the $$ and try a Streamlight before you shell it out for Surefire. You might be happy you did.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Great tactical light for the price!
reviews:
I bought this for on-duty use, serving hi-risk warrants primarily in the dark. Having a Streamlight Strion rechargable issued from my Dept., I was able to test and compare this ProTacHL to that and saw an immediate difference justifying this purchase. With my primary light worn on my outer vest and in my chest's center, I somehow carcked it's glass(!) lens with a side-folding stocked 870 shotgun on the range while slung. The light was a week old. I called Streamlight and they immediately shipped me out a new lens and had it back to work 3 days later.

Customer service, quality product, made and serviced in Pa., and priced right for 500 lumens! I saved $35 finding it here vs. Cabela's in store price. If it wasn't for the lens, it would be a 5 star for me. That and I added grip tape to the smooth sections. The knurling is there, but far from hi-tac or adequate in rain or sleet and shooting with it in your off hand, as well as retention.

reviews:
I have had this flashlight for about 4 months and I am VERY happy with it. I carry it in my pocket wherever I go. This flashlight inspires user confidence.

Pros:
-Amply Bright (I use it when locking up my Church at nighttime and it easily lights up the large sanctuary)
-Lightweight (I carry all day everyday and often times forget that it's there)
-Perfect size (Fits well in my hand and in my pocket)
-Durable (I have dropped it countless times on concrete... still works like a charm!!!)
-Waterproof!!! (Just last night I used it in very wet conditions for about 15 minutes. It was getting as wet as possible without being totally submerged and still works perfectly.)
-Perfect Tail-cap switch (People complain about it being too stiff, but it's not... it's perfect. It has never turned on in my pocket, yet is easily actuated by my thumb or index finger.)
-Perfect settings (High, Strobe and Low in well organized order.)
-Looks Really Cool
-Great Ergonomics
-Simply cleaning and replacing of batteries

Cons:
-None

The firmware in this flashlight is awful...why should I need to program it every single time I turn it on? One night it fell out of my pocket onto the carpeted floor in my entry way and shattered the head glass.....so this flashlight is worthless to me. #83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: A great deal and great light
reviews: I bought this in March of 2012 and I love this light. It's bright and disorienting and light wait. This is part of my EDC and has come into use many times. People make fun of me for carrying a light but when they see how strong it is they buy one. The beam is strong goes pretty far but I would not recommend this light as a primary flash light. It's good indoors and for the city streets. The only down side is it does scratch easily and the anti roll device doesn't work that well. Other wise it's great to have in your pockets and doesn't weigh that much. The strobe is very disorienting and the removable clip is great. You can reverse the clip and wear the light on a hat for hands free objectives. Over all I would recommend this flash light to any one who wants a utility, tactical, or just a simple bright light to have with them at all times. Oh and I submerged my light in the water while turned on and it did just find. And it comes with 2 batteries and a nylon case which is a plus. Amazing long lasting durable light. I'm very happy

reviews: Great flashlight! I love this thing and carry it with me every day. It's programmable so you can either have low come on first, high come on first, and/or turn off the strobe function if you won't be using it. The low setting is plenty bright for everyday usage. Then with a simple quick double push of the button, you have the light of 1000 suns (Note: may not actually be THAT bright). It's a nice compact size with a clip that holds it firmly in your pocket. One thing that might bother people is that it scratches easily. I carry it in the same pocket as a knife, and the area that contacts the knife all day is scratched to hell. But, I want it for function over form so it doesn't bother me. If you're thinking about buying a great compact flashlight that will light up the darkest of rooms, here's a helpful tip...don't think. review_title: Very close to a professional headlamp, but...
reviews:
Very close to a professional headlamp, and its quality really well worth for its price!!

It is very simple and great constructed headlamp for general utility and recreation purposes, but definitely not for military and tactical zombie-defending type of works.

-no longer made in US
-no light defusing adjustment
-not dimmer-able
-annoying strong focus beam at center of the overall lighted area within 25ft (wishing if there is a diffuse lens to make the lighted area more averagly flooded )
-123A battery standard is rare for typical households
-missing waterproof+recharging option (does cost that much these days)
-not recommend to people with hand/finger problems who cannot perform actions like "Double-Click" on a computer mouse, because this light even requires performing "Triple-Click" actions as a dimmer switch

Well, at least its mental housing is decently built, with one button only, and adjustments are simple. The next level-up gear would be lights made by SureFire, which burns my wallet badly always.

ps. I remember seeing another model comes with 30+ adjustments through one button, and the user manual was confused as a treasure map.

reviews: Streamlight is known for making excellent products. Having said that this light has a few things that cause it to fail in getting a higher rating. Don't get me wrong this is a nice little light. But there are some flaws. Flaw number1: The end tail cap switch will fail to turn on the light occasionally when depressed all the way. There have been a few times that it has taken a number of clicks to get it to come and stay on. Flaw number 2: If you run it on it's highest setting too long it will get extremely hot! As a result, it will eat batteries if left on it's highest setting faster than what it is rated for. Momentary use of the brightest setting works extremely well. No issues there. So, what is good you ask? 1/ Construction. Build quality is very good. 2/ Size. I like it because it's light weight and fits in pockets very easily. 3/ It uses only 1 CR123 battery. 4/ Brightness level is more than adequate. It is rated for 110 lumen at it's highest setting. I'm thinking that this might be a little generous. It does throw a good light pattern up to about 80 feet or so. So, best uses, IMHO, great back up light or back pack light or nightstand. I've been using it as my main carry light for personal use as I use a Surefire G2 for work. I am thinking of replacing this though and getting something that runs on AA batts rather than 123's. Overall, a decent light just not a fantastic light.

review_title: Great small backup duty light and everyday carry pocket light!
reviews:
I'm a police officer and I've worked nights for over 10 years, so I learned long ago to carry as many flashlights as I reasonably can when I'm working. It's a dreadful feeling when your flashlight starts to go dead when you're tracking suspects through the woods, on a lengthy car stop on the side of a busy highway, or working some other incident where there's no ability to stop and go recharge your light. My primary light carried on my duty belt is a Streamlight PolyStinger DS LED, my secondary is a Streamlight Strion LED, and for my third light I used to carry some cheap no-name pocket LED light that was essentially worthless but that I figured was better than nothing.

I decided it was finally time to find a good quality backup pocket light for my third slot. As you can tell from my other lights I like Streamlight, but I'm also willing to carry whatever I feel is best for the job. My bias towards Streamlight is that they makes good quality durable lights, many which are rechargeable which is a huge plus when you're paying for all your equipment costs on a cop's salary. They back their products (they've repaired/replaced lights at no cost when I've managed to kill them in the past), and they are more affordable than some of the other manufacturers out there. I know SureFire is the big thing in the tactical arena, and I have used and do like some of their lights (I've currently got their weapon-light on my primary duty weapon), and others like Fenix have cult followings as well. But Streamlight puts out quality, durable, feature-packed lights that are just as good, and they do so at great prices. That being said, I did research several other ultra-small pocket lights (this size was about as big as I wanted to go) and I ended up choosing this Streamlight ProTac 1L.

I've been carrying the ProTac 1L for about 6 months now and it's been a great little light. The very small size, coupled with the more than adequate light output, are the two biggest reasons I love it. There are other similarly-priced small lights out there with a higher stated output, but very few that're as incredibly small as this one. Many require two CR123 batteries (or AAAs in others), while this one just needs the one CR123. It's not rechargeable which is what I love about my PolyStinger LED and Strion LED, but then again I doubt you'll find any lights this size that are rechargeable. At least using a CR123 the batteries have a long 10-year shelf life, so if I bought one of these and left it in my truck or wife's car as a spare emergency light I wouldn't have to worry about the battery running dead quickly. Now with only one CR123 versus some other pocket lights having two, that does mean this one isn't going to have quite the battery life as the others, but to me the trade-off is worth it because I'd rather carry a very small light that I may need to change the battery out a little more often instead of a larger more cumbersome one that lasts longer but that I might decide to leave at home at times because it's bigger/heavier. When I'm already wearing/carrying 25 lbs of gear at work, and I need a light to fit in my pocket, I want to keep it as small and lightweight as possible. This one fits the bill perfectly. It's about as long as my index finger and even with the CR123 battery it weighs hardly anything. According to my scale the actual weight with the battery (I don't use the pocket clip) is only 1.81 oz, which is hardly noticeable at all.

The physical design of the light is perfect. It's rugged and waterproof, which are two must-have features for me to carry it on duty. I have dropped it and banged it around plenty already and it's never skipped a beat. Even if it does end up failing it's got Streamlight's lifetime warranty which I've tested before and have faith in, plus it's only a $40 light. As far as design, a lot of the cheap small lights have the annoying cheap twist-on twist-off cap switches or a tailcap that's got a little rubber end to mimic a switch but is just spring-loaded to turn it on and off. This light has a bonafide tailcap switch, and it seems to be of the same quality and tactile feel as my Strion and Stingers. It works flawlessly for quick bursts of light or for clicking it on to turn the light on fully. The positioning of the tailcap switch allows me to easily use it as a light in my support hand while my weapon's in my strong hand without having to first rotate it in my hand to find the switch like you have to do with ones with a side-mounted switch. The contours of the body of the flashlight, instead of it being completely smooth, gives you a little more positive control over it and makes it that much easier to wedge it between your middle and ring finger. It's got an anti-roll head that works but the flat-sided rings just aren't as large and prominent as they are on larger lights. That's good because it keeps the overall size of the light down, but it does also mean that it's a little more apt to roll than those larger ones.

The light output is selectable. The "Ten Tap Programming" lets you program it by clicking the power switch ten times in rapid succession. You can choose from High/Low/Strobe, which is how it's programmed when it arrives, High only, or Low/High. All that means is if you keep it on High/Low/Strobe then when you click it once it turns on High, click it twice rapidly and it turns on Strobe, and click it three times rapidly it turns on Low. On the Low/High it just allows you to alternate between those two outputs as you choose. I don't bother with any of those and just programmed it to High only. If I need a light I need all the output it has so I'm not worried about being able to use the Low mode to conserve power or the Strobe to gain attention (just rapid pushes of the momentary-on switch accomplishes the same thing as Strobe if you just need to strobe it for a few seconds). Keeping it on the High only setting is just simpler and more intuitive. Grab the light and press the button and I've got High power, I don't have to worry about if I accidentally double-click it and it starts strobing when that's not what I want. But if I'm ever in a situation where I do need to rely on the Low setting (say an extended power outage and this is the only light I have) or the Strobe setting, it's a quick process to use the Ten Tap Programming to switch over to being able to access those modes at that time.

The output on High power is admirable for such a small light. I know everyone throws around lumens and I know there is science behind it, but after having carried numerous various lights from different manufacturers over the years I don't bank on those numbers too much after seeing how they work in the real world. For one, there's no standardized process across the board for measuring the lumens, so I don't doubt that there's some room for a manufacturer to use the most appealing rating even if it's not measured the same way as their competitors. Secondly, I feel that the beam pattern and concentration plays a big part too. A highly concentrated lower lumen light is probably going to seem brighter because of it's narrow piercing beam, and be more useful when it's a pocket light like this, than a widely diffused higher lumen light that just illuminates a much wider area but isn't very concentrated. This light offers a good compromise; the "hot spot" (the area of the beam where the most light is projected) is fairly narrow and concentrated, but there is a good amount of spillover to also illuminate a wider area near you to a lesser degree. The beam's not adjustable (which is good, an adjustable head can risk the waterproofing) so I think the setup is optimal for the size of light and it's intended use.

Overall I'm very pleased with this light. It works great as a small pocket light while on duty, and I now carry it religiously in my jeans or shorts pocket when I'm off-duty. And I didn't mention much non-police uses, but in addition to now having a light when I'm carrying my gun off-duty (which is almost a cardinal rule in my book), I use it for all sorts of tasks around the house or in the garage when I unexpectedly need a light. It's handy having such a powerful and capable little light on me at all times and not needing to go retrieve one. Now that I've carried it long enough to see how good it is I'll probably buy several more eventually since it's so small, light, and useful. Throw one in the junk drawer, one in my nightstand, one in each vehicle, and probably another one or two for work in my gear bag and/or my rifle case for additional spares (again, a night shift officer can never have too many lights).
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

reviews: The Streamlight 88039 ProTac 2AAA light is a powerhouse. I wanted a pocket light and found it just a tad too large for that so I have my Microstream (1AAA) in my pocket. My 88039 rides either in my briefcase or occasionally in its holster on my belt. The 88039 has multiple settings and is programmable as to the order in which they activate. The high setting is almost as bright as some "tactical" lights. The lower brightness is more than adequate for most flashlight jobs. The small size and AAA batteries makes it most convenient to have with you, especially for those who are "on the road" a lot. Streamlight quality is very high and if you've previously used a hardware store flashlight tri-pac on sale for $8.99 you'll notice the difference. Get the real thing, get a Streamlight.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Failure: Have owned 4 of this model, all with same short-out problem.
reviews:
I am a fan and heavy user of streamlight products in my work, as a cheaper option to the traditional duty models from Surefire, so it pains me to write this review.

I have owned four of the Streamlight ProTac 2L in the past two years, and will be replacing this most recent one with a different flashlight. The problems have consistently been with a shorting connection in the tail push-button: where the light will randomly just shut off with the button clicked on. It never seems to happen with the quick-on feature, just with the constant, and it doesn't seem to matter which mode it's in (high-strobe-low). Other than this fatal flaw, it is an excellent light, but I cant depend on a light that might shut off in a life-threatening situation. I have a handful of other Streamlight models I use for work, from the tiny ProTac 1L, up to the Stinger patrol light, and their WML handgun series, and have had zero issues with those over the years.

Hopefully Streamlight will get this model rewired into a more reliable version, because undependiability erases all the great features of this light.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
My criteria for an Every Day Carry(EDC) flashlight is simple, a rugged, decent illumination, easily portable with a simple clip. The Streamlight Protac 1L fits that bill perfectly. It has to be reliable and work when needed. Initial click on the switch is alway the brightest setting, which I prefer. There is also a strobe function, but I don't use it and does not accidentally gets triggered, which is a plus.

I use to carry a Surefire E1L Outdoorsman that also use one CR123A battery. Although also a very rugged light, it is bigger, not as bright and cost three times as much. The Surefire initial click is always the low then takes a second click to get the brighter setting. I prefer to have the brighter setting first.

EDC light is something I do not think about much, it comes with me like my wallet. It is just another tool that I have with me. The Streamlight 88030 Protac 1L fits the bill perfectly without the excess.

review_title: This is a great product for the price, buy more than 1!
reviews: This is a great product for the price. Nice and bright at 180 lumens. Fits well in your hand and can be operated with your thumb, plus has multiple settings. There are other ‚Äúmore aggressive‚Äù style tactical flashlights out there, but they typically cost more and are not a sleek as the Streamlight 88031 Protac Tactical Flashlight 2L. This is the very flashlight (along with the 1L version) that we recommend in our Texas CHL classes at DoubleActionCHL.info. My recommendation is that you buy several and keep them where you have quick access to them. You never know when you will need a good quality bright flashlight, and of course, make sure to have one on your person. The 2L fits better in the hand, but is slightly bulkier (because it is longer) then the 1L when stored, but is brighter than the smaller counterpart.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
I've carried a Streamlight Protac 2AA for about the last four years. I work in a machine shop and have absolutely beat the thing up and it hasn't missed a beat.
But it is (in my opinion) too large for pocket carry, and so I've purchased several smaller lights to try to find one that could match the features and durability of the 2AA Protac without success. (Cue bad dramatic music)
Until now.
This thing is probably about as perfect an ESC light as it gets. The clip is awesome- I keep it lens down in my pocket, but the clip still allows me to clip it to the bill of my ball cap to use as a headlamp when I need to. It's plenty bright with good run time off of rechargeable AA batteries (buy Panasonic Eneloops, you'll thank me later) and with a CR123A it pretty much matches the performance of my TLR-1s, though the beam is a little yellower.
If it's as durable as my 2AA (which I anticipate it will be) I expect to be carrying this for years to come.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster
rank:
#9,282 in Tools & Home Improvement (See Top 100 in Tools & Home Improvement)

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Big light, from a small package.
reviews:
UPDATE Not fragile at alI! I have dropped this thing several times, and I can't understand why people have such a hard time with the tail switch. Its simple, and firm enough to not turn on accidentally.
I think this light will please you.
I have tried many lights in this size and price range and I think this is a good value.
The tail cap switch is easy to use and will not accidently turn on. You may need a few trys at first, but its not hard and a previous reviewer explains it well, press and click =bright - press twice and click =strobe - press three times and click =dim.
As you now know it has a strobe mode let me say that its really no problem to bypass it and go to dim, and I assume most people will just click on, and off, never concerning themselves with either dim or strobe. Its also possible to press down without clicking to use the light in either mode briefly and release when you are through.
You get plenty of bright light from this little tool. I can do what I need easily with the dim setting which is similar in brightness to the Streamlight Microstream which I also own and reviewed. If you like check it out.http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00143JZ08/ref=oh_details_o00_s00_i01
You get plenty of product with this light, and out should least a long time.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
While I keep a tiny flashlight on my keyring, I like to keep this pen sized flashlight in my purse for those times when a little more light is needed. The light has three modes that you switch between on its switch. It has a low, high, and strobe. I use all three modes. Low is good enough to get around a campsite or a darkened room without ruining your night vision. High is great for spotlighting things in the dark, but it is so bright I would be careful to not point it at anyone. You don't want to hurt people's eyes. The strobe I have used to help people find me at night or to warn away cars from my vehicle while on the side of the road. I was not sure if I would use a strobe feature in a flashlight, but I am glad to have it. It is possible to disable the strobe if you decide you'd rather not be bothered with it.

The only negative that I can see about this light is that it is too tactical looking for me. I get funny looks from people if I pull it from my purse when there is no lighting emergency. The ProTac is also larger than my previous Stylus Pro and is harder to tuck in with my writing pens. I finally found a single pen case that was large enough to conceal the penlight in and which protects other items in my purse from being scratched by the anodized metal. I do like this flashlight and carry it with me every day, but there are times when I wish I had found a less tactical looking penlight.

reviews: I purchased this flashlight about one month ago. It took about a week to get to me here in Iraq. I was a little dissapointed at first when I opened the box and saw how small it really was. I could not believe a light this small could be so bright. My co-workers were very impressed. Everyone else started looking for flashlights that would be brighter than mine. They were spending between 70 to 170 dollars for these 300 lumen flashlights. But the streamlight was just as bright as their expensive ones. The dim setting is very conveniant for saving battery when you dont need to blind someone. I'm still not sure what i would use the strobe setting for other than playing around. It also comes with a belt holster which comes in handy. Even if you dont wear a belt you can still put your light in it to keep it protected. I am very impressed with my flashlight and would definately buy it again.

With this light I was literally able to light up the whole street. It also is great during the recent hurricane sandy, for a first line defense on anyone near the house. With 600lumens it would instantly disorientated anyone that was in its way and make them think twice about coming closer. Would definitely recommend and now I actually have two. If your on the edge of buying it or not just think where your going to buy a light for $70 that's 600 lumens that almost every fire department across the country Relies on on a daily basis.

reviews:
I started looking for a tactical flashlight and I thought I was going to have to spend the money for a more expensive, well known brand. I came across this flashlight on an Amazon search and decided to buy it based on the positive reviews. Let me tell you that I am not disappointed! This flashlight is bright! It is solidly constructed and it fits my hand perfectly (I have large hands). It was a little tricky to switch between the 3 modes (you have to click once for steady brightness, double click for strobe, and triple click for low power), but I got the hang of it after about 10 minutes.

Overall I would recommend this flashlight to anyone in the market for a tactical light. You'll love the light and be glad that you saved money too!

reviews:
The light is of the highest quality as I have come to expect from Streamlight. It was much lighter than I had anticipated making it an even better choice for Every Day Carry. The holster that it came with is of good quality and holds the light very securely.

The operation of the light is very straight forward. The default program for the modes of High-Strobe-Low seems to make the most sense for a light you would carry for personal protection or as a tactical light for CCW use. I found it very simple to access the other two programs, High-only and Low-High. The Low-High program would be more use for a medical application or for more discrete tactical situations.

review_title: I bought it, then another one.
reviews: I've had this flashlight for a couple months now and I carry it with me often. I like it but, as with most things, it's not perfect. The clip is not screwed on so it is very possible it will come off. This is not a big deal for me, but I can see how it may be for someone. It is somewhat expensive replacing batteries. Again, this isn't a very big deal, but it may be an issue to some. I have also noticed with prolong use the bulb of the light does tend to get hot. Of course, it's expected to get hot and it's nothing I think is dangerous but it does happen. Overall, I am happy with this flashlight, in fact, I bought another soon after my first. Even though i focused on whats wrong instead of whats right, I think this is a great buy.

review_title: wow. get one and you'll never go back
reviews: Quit living In the dark. This Is hands down the best flashlight ive ever owned. Its quality and usefulness are unbeatable. First off It fits clipped in your pocket so nicely it aint even noticable. Its extremely potent for its size, on high It lights up my 100 yard shooting range. And flexible, with the low setting it runs for 50 continuous hours. That is unheard of. For those of you on the fence about It because of the kind of batteries It takes QUIT WORRYING, Im a elevator mechanic I work In the dark every day and use this light every. Single. Day. Its batteries last forever. I mean It, the last set lasted from november 8-jan 4. That 2 MONTHS out of one set of batteries! 2 batteries cost 5 bucks. Yes that Is less than a fancy Starbucks drink every 2 months for me. Which ,by the way, Is much cheaper to use than that aaa light your looking at that eats batteries like candy. and dont worry about the low lumen count on the low setting, it Is more than enough for 95% of times you need a light. When It aint high setting Is a hand torch. The feature not highlighted enough that sets this light apart from all the rest is it is SOLID STATE power regulated! That means its the same exact brightness from fresh batteries until completely dead batteries! Again almost nobody else can say that! Normal lights only get to make the claimed lumens for the first 5 minutes afterwards its constantly gettin dimmer, not so with this light. Quit looking and order this thing. It will be one of the best investments youll make.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
This product is now complete garbage! DO NOT BUY!

I have two ProTac 1L-1AA flashlights that I purchased last July, they work FANTASTIC!

I bought another one in preparation of Hurricane Irma, and was disappointed to find that I could not change the TenTap settings, one of my favorite Streamlight features.

I called Service and they said to return it to Amazon.

I received a SECOND ProTac 1L-1AA from Amazon and it had the same issue, I could not change the TenTap settings on this flashlight either.

I called service and this time I was told to try switching out the tail caps from one of my working flashlights with the one on my new flashlight.

This is where it gets weird.

The tail cap from my old flashlight, does not seem to fit the new flashlight. It screws in but when fully screwed in I cannot turn the light on or off. If I slightly loosen it, the flashlight works, but I am unable to set the TenTap to HIGH ONLY mode.

I then tried to put the new tail cap on my old flashlight and it wouldn't screw in all the way, it stays slightly protruded. However, even with the new cap on my old flashlight, my TenTap setting of HIGH ONLY stayed set, which leads me to believe that the TenTap settings are stored on the flashlight, not on the tail cap.

The service representative said I had two options, I could return the flashlight to Amazon AGAIN or pay out of my own pocket to send it into Streamlight.

I'll just be buying a Fenix flashlight instead that can actually function properly, if two different flashlights of the same model aren't working, it is probably a widespread production issue with Streamlight. STAY AWAY!
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster
rank:
#9,282 in Tools & Home Improvement (See Top 100 in Tools & Home Improvement)
#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews: These are decent lights but I wouldn't consider them for heavy duty and/or personnel defense. These lights don't feel heavy in the hand. The build quality is lightweight but not cheesy. The body feels thin and is devoid of any checkering. I use this light for around the house and it works fine for that purpose. Small and light enough to clip in the front pocket without getting in the way. I really like the tail cap switch. Comes on in high mode. Quick off/on and it comes on as strobe. Quick off/on again comes on in low mode. Runs off 2x CR123a batteries. Light gets VERY hot when run a long time in high mode! It's rated for 180 lumens on high. I have two of these and I've noticed a huge difference in the hotspot uniformity. One looks like a little milky way galaxy and the other is fine. I haven't done a drop test but I suspect with such a lightweight build quality it would not stand up to the abuse. If you need a light duty light for the car, a go bag, etc. then this may make a good choice. If you can afford it go with SureFire or Fenix.

reviews: Just received it in the mail today. I've had many duty type flashlights over the years as I work in private security so I'll definitely complain when equipment doesn't par up. The ProTAC looks, feels, and functions very well from what I can tell. It is bright as hell too. All I need is a decent holster for it because I don't like using velcro holsters for flashlights because it is an item on my duty belt I'd be reaching for quite a bit. I'll be looking forward to testing out battery longevity and build quality to uphold the test of time but I doubt it will be a problem. This light has no parts/battery rattle, has a heavy feel, and when I tried it in the dark I was impressed with the light spread and focus. I compared it to the light I currently carry which is quite bright but the ProTAC light made it look like a match even with my other light on high. I hope this helps for those trying to make a buying decision.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: I personally love this flashlight and will never go anywhere without it
reviews: I personally love this flashlight and will never go anywhere without it. I got my first when they were 180 lumens, went to get a back up because I kept missplacing it and SURPRISE! 260 lumens! Ive bought several as they are lent out and never returned and im exited to see any new changes. Looks like a new clip. Would certainly be an improvement for someone who uses it every day. The one I carry has never failed, dimmed or waverd. Its been in rivers, out in the rain for days. Thrown, dropped, beaten, fallen on. Just a week ago I woke up to a late night mountain lion in my camp site and this light gave me an edge on the cat. I could blind him, ruining his nighteyes and giving me time and space to figure out my next move. This light is a necessity for anyone walking at night in the mountians. Its scared off a bear in town aswell. Wont leave my side. Her name is ethyl.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
Money to Quality ratio here you can't beat it. The light is extremely well built, very durable. I've been using it for a several weeks now on duty. This light will fit nicely into an old leather mag light holster. I really don't like the frosted lens because I feel like it dampens this light's true potential, but not enough to dock a star for.

Lets get one thing straight, this is NOT a throw light. You won't be able to shoot a concentrated beam for several hundred yards with this light, but that's not what it's made for. This light is made for massive close range flooding. I've lit up back yards like it's daylight with this light. I've had other coppers say "holy bleep" when i turn on my light in a dark yard or during a traffic stop. They're jealous their light's not this bright lol. For what I use it for it's perfect, big time bright flooding over a small radius.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster
rank:
#9,282 in Tools & Home Improvement (See Top 100 in Tools & Home Improvement)
#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Fantastic Broad Beam and Throw Combined. Highly Recommend.
reviews: This is a great high end flashlight that performs as advertised. I changed the default setting (low-high-strobe) easily with the Ten-Tap feature so it comes on at low, a second tap changes to medium, and a third changes to high. High is awesome! The downside to my personalized setting is the loss of the strobe feature, which is small tradeoff for my intended use. Not only does this Streamlight Pro Tac HL4 have fantastic throw, there is a also a very broad beam that surpasses that of my other high end lights. This is probably due to the glass lens which resembles a fresnel screen in an SLR camera. This broad beam is great for any search application as there is very high illumination of the immediate surrounding area as, well as a very long distance illumination. I highly recommend this flashlight, and as a retired L.E.O. wish that there was something comparable in my law enforcement years, because this could brightly illuminate vast areas, such as warehouses, ship yards, parking lots, alleys, woods, etc.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

reviews: I was totally let down at first because it came with a short fat little battery and one of the reasons i bought it was because one of the reviews said that it ran off AAA batteries. I busted it open and shined it on some pine trees about 100 yards away and it lit them up like it way day time; i was amazed. It is very small (about three fingers) and is activated buy a button on the back; one click is bright, two quick clicks is strobe (this is very disorientating and would be great to confuse an attacker) and i would assume three quick clicks would be dim but i haven't been able to make this work in over a month. all in all, a great little light.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
After researching and handling numerous lights from various brands like SureFire, SRT, etc., I found the Streamlight Protac 2L to be the best all around light. 260 lumens is bright enough to be effective, while the low 13 lumens is great for more practical everyday use. The push button tail switch is super easy to click through all 3 main features, and makes accessing strobe really quick (with a little practice). The diameter is slim enough to easily fit in causal pant pockets, and utilizes the length for the increased lumens, which is still relatively short overall. It's also very lightweight, feels solid, and comfortable to handle.

Although other lights are tempting, still can't commit to carrying anything else.

Bought another as a Father's Day gift. Highly recommend.

reviews:

reviews:
Bought this light about a month ago and absolutely love the brightness of this flashlight. The brightness and clarity of the light is amazing. It is blinding in normal mode, but completely disorienting in strobe mode.

For any of you looking for a light that will blind an attacker, this is the light for you.

It is easy to use, comfortable to hold both for recreational purposes and in a self defense situation.

I highly recommend this light. Reviewers of this light have complained about the pocket clip breaking, however, I have not had any issues. Seems fairly strong, but I'm also not an officer and using it as repetitively as an officer may use it.

The price is right and it is a well built flashlight.

reviews:
A fine light for your rifle (remove the light's clip).
Mounted in my fore grip, the light responds perfectly to my trigger switch, which pushes the light's tap switch. Super bright beam, I am able to put out street lights with PV sensors at 30 yards or so (flashlight makes them think its day time and they shut off). Strobe is very rapid and, just as a strobe should be, momentarily blinding. For comparison, the flash light's lighting element is the same type used in camera flashes.

reviews: Precision manufacturing using the finest materials makes this tactical light a joy to just hold in your hand. It goes through batteries fast enough that operation is prohibitively expensive unless you buy the batteries in bulk, such as the Streamlight 12-pack. reviews: I just bought this to add to my collection of cheapos and higher ends. While I'm still a Fenix fan, I have to say this light, for the money or not, is awesome. Serious brightness, great mode control. I thought I would hate the all in one button (momentary, and mode change) because I like a separate mode button, but honestly it hasn't been an issue. The strobe function is excellent, and yes, different price points have different strobe quality. This one is fast and harsh like it should be. I will be buying more of these because I've decided to use gun brackets and these lights rather than the inclusive gun light like my tlr1 and tlr4. review_title: Streamlight Tactical lights are affordable quality
reviews: I have always been a fan of Streamlight products. They are well made and are affordable. I use them at work and in the field. These lights can be used for work, security and non-lethal defense. Most Streamlight products have eye scorching,high lumen values,(Protac 2L has 180+ lumen C4 LED, powered by 2, 3volt CR123A batteries), that will confuse and dis-orient any aggressor, even in bright sunlight. The CR123A batteries a little more pricey, but they are powerful, have a very long shelf life and last long under heavy use.My job requires me to work at night,(3rd shift). I purchased my first Protac 2L in the summer of 2010 and I am still on the first set of batteries. I also have Streamlight products on many of my firearms. Streamlight products are a good value.

reviews:
It appears to me that many of these 4 and 5 star reviews are for a different older model. Even the pictures are not showing this light (see all the ones with a bezel that is even with the body). THIS model, the HL-X had a wide bezel that protrudes approx an 1/8 in all around past the body of the ligtht.

So, I don't like it. Here's why.

1. 1000 Lumens my rear end. Comparing this to several of my other lights I would put it in the 6-800 range.

2. The ability to select the light mode is imprecise at best. Even crappy Chinese Fenix lights have a better system.

3. The quality of the light and it it's throw is far inferior to what I expected from this light at this price. If you are looking for a replacement for your Stinger, this one is not it.

4. It's huge. Yes, it takes an 18650 battery but this light is so bulky in comparison that it will not fit nicely in a pocket or belt. Not an EDC light.

Is it a terrible light? Not really. But for this price and as "streamlight" I expected way better. You can get the same quality for half the price in a lesser brand. And no, I would not trust my life or safety to the performance of this light.

And as I was packaging it up for return... wonder of wonders... made in China. Figures.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster
rank:
#9,282 in Tools & Home Improvement (See Top 100 in Tools & Home Improvement)
#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: GREAT flashlight for Every Day Carry
reviews:
By far my favorite EDC flashlight! I first received one of these flashlights as a gift for christmas and I carried it with me everywhere. It is slim enough to be carried in front pocket or rear pocket without weighing you down or adding too much bulk to your pants. There are 3 modes to the flashlight and they take a little bit of practice in order to get used to them, they are: High, Low, and Strobe.

I also like that the clip is removable, this allows you to place it in a different spot on the flashlight or to be removed all together. The sides of the flashlight near the front are also squared off, this helps keep the flashlight from rolling away if you set it on a flat surface.

I lost the first one I received as a gift so I purchased one myself. I lost that second one (but later found it) so I purchased a third one. My losing the flashlight isn't a fault of design but more so my clumsiness.

Now that I have 2 I keep one of my truck and the other in my backpack, I don't carry in my pocket anymore as I don't want to lose another flashlight.

review_title: Nice torch, just gets hot like one too.
reviews:
Overall it's a fairly good duty flashlight.

The upsides are that it's fairly beefy, but has a clip to slip onto a molle panel quickly or throw into a pocket. Oh, and it's bright with a good beam focus.

The only downsides are that 1) takes a while to charge, and 2) it gets HOT on the highest setting. Hot as in ridiculously hot.

But for a quality flashlight, I'll take the minor scalding here or there. There's no way you'll accidentally leave it on in a pocket, that's for sure. If you do, have some burn cream ready.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Great light, lame method of changing settings
reviews: I have been using this for a few weeks and I really like it. I use it when walking my dog at 5a every morning in my small town where street lights are few and far between and some of our morning jaunts involve a pitch-dark golf course. I've gone through a bunch of lights, searching for perfection. This one isn't it, but it's closer than I've ever come. It runs on either a single AA or a CR123, and both fit in the same place without anything to alter, remove or install. With the CR123, you get a claimed 350 lumens, and it sure looks that bright. There are lower settings and they are useful in various settings. I knocked off a star because of the idiotic way you change among the alternative brightness settings. You have to switch to off, then push the tailcap a certain number of clicks, quickly, then a final push to hold the setting. You also alter the mapping with a series of button pushes, NINE in one case. This can't be the best they could come up with. Great light, ridiculous method of changing the light setting.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
I work in a power house, and am constantly working in dim lit areas. I wanted to get a light with high lumens that would let me see the 40' ceiling from the floor and past flood lights. This flashlight does it with no problems! I can now see everything in the ceiling without any doubt that I'm actually seeing what I'm seeing. The low 35 lumen mode is great for close up work, but when you need that burst of light, this torch will provide all the light you need, plus some. I have had this light now for about a month and have people asking me all the time where I got it. I would not hesitate to purchase this again and again!
When the light first showed up to my door, I took it to my basement to try it out. Mainly because I have low light there. It was like someone opened up the wall to the outside and day light was pouring in. I tried it just yesterday in the full sunlight, and from chest height, I could see the beam on the grass! It was brighter than the sun from that distance, very impressive.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster
rank:
#9,282 in Tools & Home Improvement (See Top 100 in Tools & Home Improvement)
#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
I almost sent this back thinking it was defective. I was double clicking it and it wouldn't change to strobe. I re-read the instructions and watched a couple youtubes. Turns out you need to double tap not double click. The on/off button has a momentary on/off and a click on, click off. They call the momentary on/off a "tap".
Pros: 600 lumens, great price, hi beam, strobe, water proof, metal, small, well made
Con: I wish they had an additional mode I could put it in. I would like a mode where momentary on/off is hi beam and click on and off is strobe. If an intruder breaks into my home at night I would use this mode. High beam on then off then move. Repeat. High beam on, see intruder, just press harder for the click on strobe. Double tap with your weak hand thumb under stress is not that easy. I would buy a 2nd one if it had this mode. And I would rate it 5 stars.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: I expected better than mediocre quality from Streamlight.
reviews:
When my ‚Äúgo to‚Äù light went missing in action, I decided to try the Streamlight ProTac HL 750 as a replacement, based on that company's good reputation, but I was so disappointed with what I received that I packaged it up and sent it right back.

The first thing that I noticed was the lightweight feel of the flashlight. The chassis walls are thin and do not inspire confidence. The threads are coarse and gritty, even after careful cleaning.

As one other reviewer noted, CR123 batteries rattle noisily within the flashlight body. This annoyance is not a result of any defect or bad design; it is the result of CR123s being slightly narrower than the 18650 rechargeable batteries this flashlight can also use. Flashlight manufacturers who make their lights wide enough for 18650s do so knowing that the CR123s will be smaller. However, many manufacturers deal with this by either including a plastic sheath to use with CR123s to prevent rattling, or engineer the spring tension within their flashlights to do so. Streamlight chose to do neither, thus the annoying rattle. Is this a big deal? Of course not, and if it had been the only thing that I did not like about this light I would have fashioned a sheath of my own, or wrapped a little tape around CR123s to silence them, and carried on.

But this was not the only thing that I did not like. Which brings me to:

Beam quality. The Streamlight 88040 ProTac HL 750 beam consists of a tight hot spot with a ringy, inconsistent spill. The tight hot spot is neither good nor bad; that is just a matter of taste and preference. However, the ‚Äúringy‚Äù corona is a different story. It is not terrible, nor is it bad enough to have make my decision to return the flashlight. It was just the last straw. Back the light went.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster
rank:
#9,282 in Tools & Home Improvement (See Top 100 in Tools & Home Improvement)

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Epic failure after 20 minutes of use ‚Äî hand-held light with a strange control issue...
reviews:
Updated review:
Downgrading to one star. Like several other reviewers (whom I mistakenly ignored when purchasing this flashlight) this flashlight suffered a catastrophic failure just one week after being received. I used it for less than a total of 20 minutes and yet the brightness of the flashlight is now less than 25% of the reputed 1000 lumens. I did not drop it, kept it in the case when not in use, and turned it on for no more than 2 minutes at a time. When it worked (that is - for the first few days) it was nice and bright. But it suddenly and inexplicably stopped shining at the published lumens. (Just to make sure it wasn‚Äôt stuck on the low light setting, I activated the low light - it was then no brighter than a tea light!) I have $5 flashlights that are more reliable (and now brighter!) than this one. This is the first and last Streamlight product that I will invest in. Very disappointing.

Original review soon after product was received:
Solid construction. Very bright light. Clip is awkward and thin. Gets pretty hot. My biggest beef with this is the alternate settings - strobe and low light. The triple-click control is incredibly difficult to execute and frequently takes three or four tries to get the timing just right... Thankfully, I don't need either strobe or low light, so just leave it on the default/single-click (bright) setting.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
I'll be honest with you guys, I am not too impressed by the Streamlight. I picked up both the ProTac HL 3 and the HL 2 to compare with my TakLite Apollo & Poseidon.

The Streamlight is definitely bright BUT the light is very concentrated in the middle of the output. This is also called a hot spot. Outside of the hot spot, you have rings, artifacts, and generally a lot of spill. My TakLite doesn't have any of that..it's just a consistent display of light. You can see the attached photo (not mine, found it on google) to show what I mean.

Overall build quality is decent but like I said...just not what I was expecting. I own a lot of these UltraFire flashlights and it's absolutely comparable. The streamlight has some better defined knurling and perhaps a little bit more weight to it but it's not the knight in shining armor I was expecting.

Conclusion: not bad, but I prefer my TakLite.

review_title: Glad I went with this one
reviews:
I've had this item for about a week. So far, I couldn't be more pleased with my selection. I saw it at a popular retail outfitter. I asked if they price matched w/ Amazon on the exact same item. They said no.So I purchased here for half the price.
As a couple other reviewers aptly stated with their short and concise product review: Just buy it. You won't be disappointed.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

review_title: Purchased one a year ago, recently malfunctioning badly
reviews:
Negatives: I purchased one of these flashlights a year ago for frequent carry, but infrequent use. I have carried it nearly daily, but only used it on a handful of occasions. It has been subject to a little rough treatment in my pocket, but nothing outlandish, nor has it ever even been dropped. It recently began malfunctioning badly (light only works intermittently at best). If you plan to use it lightly it may work okay for you, but let's be real about one thing: nobody buys a tactical flashlight for anything short of tough use. Repairing submarines for a living I no longer carry this as I sure as hell wouldn't bet my life on it working when I need it. Also, this light gets extremely hot when left on high for more than about a minute. I'll be placing my faith in an American made maglite for the time being.

Positive: Excellent projection of light at a good distance.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster
rank:
#9,282 in Tools & Home Improvement (See Top 100 in Tools & Home Improvement)
#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews: I own the protac 1L, 2L, and a 360 lumen surefire. The surefire was way too big for EDC, the 1L was a bit too short to use as an impact weapon (I wear large size Mechanix) and the 2L was a bit longer than needed for impact use. Neither the 1L or 2L could match the power of my surefire, but had good battery life and didn't heat up much; all three required CR123 batteries that had a nasty habit of going dead on long trips when I would forget to pack back ups. The Duel Fuel strikes a perfect balance between the 1L & 2L in length (in order to accommodate AAs) being long enough to strike with but not taking up too much pocket real estate, and maintaing the slim profile of the 1L and 2L. The most impressive thing about this light is how bright the high mode is, rivaling my surefire for both intensity and spread. The big selling points are the new S clip that allows you to choose bezel up or down in the pocket and use it as a headlamp on a hard hat or baseball cap, the output, and of course the ability to use cheap and commonly available AA batteries at half (but still bright) power. The only real downside is that this bad boy gets sizziling hot and eats through a CR123a very, very fast necessitating the use of low mode when high isn't needed, and making the AA compatibility very handy. Overall it's my new EDC and a great value.
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster
rank:
#9,282 in Tools & Home Improvement (See Top 100 in Tools & Home Improvement)

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
This just arrived yesterday and I could not be happier with this purchase. Very bright. Easy to use. Tried it out on the tree line about 50 yards from my front door. Lit everything up like it was day. I bought this to replace a Mag-Lite LED XL100 that finally bit the dust and stopped working. The Steamlight is larger but then it's also 10x brighter. Easy to go from full on to strobe to low light. I do like the clip on the side. Fits well and snug in the pocket of my cargo shorts. I haven't tried to belt holster yet but on examining it it seems well made and fit the flashlight tight but not overly so. It does heat up at the light source but that's to be expected for such a powerful light. The body of the flashlight remains cool. It would have been nice to be able to adjust the focus from a flood to a narrow beam but that's not a deal killer.

Addendum: Well, this flashlight just stopped working. No rough treatment, new batteries. It just stopped. Contacted customer support so will see how that works.

I registered this flashlight at Streamlight then contacted Customer Service online. I was emailed instructions on returning it to them to repair or replace. It was found that the on/off switch was faulty and was replaced. From the time I contacted Customer Service to getting it back was about a week. Was able to do all this without having to deal with a person and without any hassle. Thank you Stream Light
product_name: Streamlight 88065 Pro Tac HL-X 1,000 Lumen Professional Tactical Flashlight with High/Low/Strobe Dual Fuel use 2X CR123A or 1x 18650 Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries and Holster
rank:
#9,282 in Tools & Home Improvement (See Top 100 in Tools & Home Improvement)

review_title: Outstanding Light Output for the Money
reviews:
Mounted this light onto the magazine tube of my 12 gauge Mossberg Tactical Shotgun, the light output is 690 lumens using one CR4 LED powered from two CR123 Lithium batteries with a full power run time of almost two full hours (yes, I tested it). Solid construction has withstood over 50 rounds of 3" magnum 00 buckshot. Has a three function programmable switch, and the strobe mode will definetly cost your adversary their night vision. If your looking for a tactical gun light for a weapon with moderate to haevy recoil, this is it.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews: I am a hunter and that is what I bought this flashlight for. In the evenings after sundown and dinner, we ride in a vehicle up and down the main ranch road and spotlight small animals, i.e. hogs. This light will light-up a huge area for me. It is amazing. It is as bright as the high beams on a half ton truck. It runs on 4 x CR123 batteries, which cost $1.25 each. Expensive. It may last about 2 hours on a new set of four batteries, dimming a little as the batteries drain over 2 hours. So I use the flashlight intermittently to save batteries and $$. Another light I also use for this purpose is the Stanley FatMax SL10LEDS 10 Watt Lithium Ion rechargeable LED pistol grip spotlight. Available at Amazon. The Streamlight floodlight is brighter than the Stanley spotlight for distances up to 75 yds. The Stanley shines a small light a little further. For my purposes and distances that I need to light-up, the Streamlight is the way to go. When you need the light, sometimes you just have to pay for the batteries.

#83 in Handheld Flashlights

reviews:
If you are looking for a super incredible bright flashlight, than look no more. As an ex-police officer I have owned my share of good bright flashlight in the last 20 years. However I have never seen anything like this light. It is so bright and white that if you aim it at a close object, it will feel as if you are looking at the sun. Not kidding!
No I am not paid to give this review and I did not receive any discount or promotions of any kind. I am simply impress with this light.
With that said. I have only had it for about three days as of this writing and so I can't comment on longevity. But if it stops working, I will jump back in here and let you all know. Everyone that I have shown the light to has the same reaction as I have. Which is, wow, dang, that's bright. As for distance, I have shined it at objects 50 yards away under street lights and it lights them up. I hope I made my point and I hope it was helpful for you.
